PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax: Schools
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
Whereas the fringe benefits tax will place a costly and unfair burden on independent schools.

The fringe benefits tax will have the most damaging impact upon schools which provide boarding accommodation for children as they are also required to provide accommodation for staff members to live in and supervise the boarders. Independent schools have limited resources and this additional impost will ultimately have to be passed on to parents, many of whom are already heavily committed to the financing of their children's education.

Your petitioners therefore call upon the Parliament to recognize that the future of Australia depends upon the education given to its children and to exempt schools from the operation of the fringe benefits tax.
Your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled, your humble petitioners showeth:
1. The proposed Australia Card will have a dramatic impact on the lives of all Australians.
2. Therefore your petitioners request a national referendum on the Australia Card Bill before the proposal is re-submitted to Parliament.
As in duty bound your petitioners will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we the undersigned, having great concern because of the threat to personal freedom posed by the introduction of The Australia Card, call on the Government to withdraw the enabling legislation on the following grounds;
1. Expert opinion does not agree ``that a National Identificaton Card system for all Australians'' would necessarily ``combat tax evasion and fraud''.
2. Once established at enormous cost to the taxpayer, the system would be here to stay.
3. The potential for the invasion of individual privacy by persons unknown to the private citizen is so great as to be unacceptable to us.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will protect this society by rejecting the Bill outright;
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that the proposed Australia Card is an intrusion into the rights of the individual in a free and democratic country.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Government not proceed with this legislation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth that:

The Hawke Labor Government's I.D. card proposal is the most far reaching and intrusive piece of Australian legislation yet introduced, and that on all the evidence available it will not tackle in the most cost-effective and effective manner tax and social security fraud.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Reject Labor's I.D. card proposal to prevent a gross waste of taxpayers' money and a significant infringement of civil liberties.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned Australian citizens shows that:
An ID Card numbering system for all Australians would give future governments tremendous power to collect sensitive information and use it against us.

Criminal elements could benefit by forging cards and documents needed to obtain them, or by illegally accessing the data in the system. The dangers are much greater than with current systems such as Medicare, as the Australia Card number could link so many different confidential records.
The cost to government and private enterprise of implementing the ID Card would be enormous, outweighing any gains. Tax cheats can be stopped more effectively by better checks in the present system.
Your petitioners therefore pray that you will reject the Australia Card Bill.

PETITION.TITLE: Identity Card and Taxation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled: the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we the undersigned whilst opposing tax evasion strongly reject the I.D. [Australia] Card as a means of increasing Government revenue. The I.D. Card, by its intrusive nature, will be an invasion of our historic rights to privacy and freedom for all Australians. No democratic nation has an I.D. Card with such detailed computer surveillance, which will be provided by this system known as PIN [Personal Identification Number] or SUI [Standard Universal Identification] where every Australian citizen will have a personal dossier on computer.

Your petitioners therefore, humbly pray that your Honourable House will protect our privacy and freedom, and totally reject the ID [Australia] Card, which will not stop welfare fraud, nor deter organised crime, nor prevent illegal immigration, nor expose tax evasion.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Identity Card and Taxation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned citizens, respectfully showeth:
that we are totally opposed to the introduction of the Government's Identity Card;

that this form of national and compulsory identification will be intrusive, costly for taxpayers and business and will not be effective in combating the growing problems of tax evasion, illegal immigrants or social security;
that we call upon the Government to improve management systems within the Australian Tax Office and other Departments to crack down on tax evasion and fraudulent practices.
As in duty bound your petitioners will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Embryo Experimentation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The petition of the undersigned expresses concern that some scientists in Australia are intent on undertaking destructive experimentation on human embryos. This subject was examined exhaustively by the 1985-1986 Senate Select Committee on Senator Harradine's Human Embryo Experimentation Bill which received 270 submissions and more than 2,000 pages of evidence. The report of the Senate Committee recommended in October 1986 that the Commonwealth Government make unlawful any destructive experiment which frustrated the development of the human embryo.
Your petitioners therefore request the Senate and the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to:
Implement without delay the major recommendation of the Senate Select Committee to outlaw destructive experiments on human embryos.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Harradine (from 115 citizens) and Parer (from 249 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Construction of High Rise Hotel: Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Senators of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
This petition of certain residents of the Australian Capital Territory shows:
That we are totally opposed to the imminent construction of a highrise hotel on the parkland area between the Boulevard and the CAGA Centre and Akuna Street and Allara Street.
Your petitioners therefore request that the development of this hotel not proceed and the further destruction of parkland and recreational areas within the city cease.

PETITION.TITLE: Sale of Belconnen and Fyshwick Markets
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of the Australian Capital Territory respectfully showeth:

That the present stallholders of the Belconnen and Fyshwick Retail Markets have made an offer of $2 million to the government for each of the markets, and although this matches the government's estimate of the markets worth, the offer has not been accepted. Failure of the stallholders to retain the markets could result in their sale to other commercial interests with the displacement of the present stallholders and increased costs being passed on to consumers.
Your petitioners therefore pray that:
The present stallholders of the Belconnen and Fyshwick Markets should be given the first option on the sale of the markets.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I inform the Senate that the Special Minister of State, Senator Ryan, left Australia on 6 November for official duties in the United States of America. She will return on 24 November. During her absence I will be Acting Special Minister of State and Acting Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women and for the Bicentenary. Questions on these matters should be directed to me. Senator Tate will be the Acting Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health and will represent the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Questions on these matters should be directed to him.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment and the Arts. Is the Minister familiar with an article entitled `Eco-Defence' published in a recent issue of the Australian magazine Simply Living? Does the article describe in detail the practices of monkeywrenching and ecotage, both of these terms referring to the deliberate sabotage of plant and equipment by conservationists or for environmental causes? Is the deliberate spiking of trees, a practice which has already led to serious, indeed almost fatal, harm to American timber workers, one such practice described in the article? Does the article in fact describe in favourable terms many such techniques and advocate the greater use of drastic and direct techniques of ecological sabotage which could easily endanger lives? Is the author of the article one Simon Balderstone? Is Simon Balderstone a member of the Minister's personal staff?

—I will answer the last part of the question first. Simon Balderstone is certainly a member of my staff, and a valued member at that. Over the years he has been the author of a great many articles on the environment. I am not familiar with the article in Simply Living although, judging by what Senator Puplick has just had to say, I should become familiar with it fairly quickly. I shall do so, and will then give a response to the detailed allegations that the honourable senator has made. However, I make the general comment that the deliberate spiking of trees is not a practice that I would at this stage endorse, and I have not endorsed any activity that causes danger to any people, whether working in a forest or anywhere else. I would have thought that no one on my staff would ever have exhorted anyone to indulge in an activity that could cause harm to a person.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Why did the Minister find it necessary to insert the qualification `at this stage' in his answer? Is the Minister not prepared to give an unequivocal assurance that neither he nor any member of his staff will now or at any stage in the future ever advocate the use of such practices, and will he make it abundantly clear that he finds it incompatible for someone to be both a member of his staff and an advocate of those sorts of practices?

—I make it abundantly clear to the Senate that at no stage would I ever endorse, nor, I hope, would any member of my staff endorse, any activity that can cause harm to a person. I thought that I said that clearly enough.

—My question, which is to the Minister representing the Treasurer, relates to the effects of the Government's crackdown on taxpayer subsidised lunches on employment in the restaurant industry. Can the Minister provide any Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) figures on employment in the restaurant sector? Do these figures indicate a contraction in employment in the sector in the two years since the Government's crackdown?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The figures do not indicate any decline in employment in the restaurant sector. Indeed, the figures indicate a very major increase in employment. I believe it is still the case, unless it has changed very recently, that the ABS does not publish categories of employment specifying or restricted to restaurants but it does have two related categories-restaurants and hotels, and restaurants, hotels and clubs. As at August 1985 employment in restaurants, hotels and clubs totalled just over 214,000. That figure had grown to 238,000 by August 1986 and to 255,000 by August 1987. So there has been an increase in employment in that category of more than 19 per cent. Separate data, which is available on request but not normally published, for the more restricted category of restaurants and hotels shows employment at 176,000 in August 1985, the figure increasing to 188,000 in August 1986 and 212,000 in August 1987-an increase in that category of just over 20 per cent, as distinct from 19 per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: It is not conceivable that an overall growth in employment in the hotels and restaurants category of above 20 per cent could have been achieved without a very large increase in the restaurants category although, as I have said, that data is not specifically available. Indeed, if the abolition of the free boozy lunch-which the Opposition remains committed to restoring-did have any effect on the demand for hotel and restaurant services it may even have been a good thing because I understand that as a result of the very heavy increase in foreign tourists coming to Australia the capacity of hotels and even some restaurants is being pressed hard by the demand and tourists may have been crowded out, which is obviously not good for the country as a whole.

The final point I want to make is that these figures show just how wrong the Opposition was yet again. Senator Messner, just over two years ago, used to come in here with assertions day after day, week after week that the restaurant industry was headed for disaster because of the imposition of the fringe benefits tax. He was as wrong about that as he was about the effect of a sales tax on wine and indeed as wrong as he and the Opposition in general are about almost every prognostication they make about economic outcomes.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for the Environment and the Arts. In the final determination for World Heritage boundaries in north Queensland, will the final boundaries either include or make provision for the subsequent inclusion of buffer zones?

—As Senator Puplick and all other honourable senators would be aware, a great many people in the Department and elsewhere have had a chance to look at the boundaries. There was provision for a number of forest areas which were not rainforest and cleared areas around rainforest areas which could have acted as buffer zones. Those boundaries are currently under review and I hope to be in a position to make a submission to Cabinet on them within the next couple of weeks. Obviously, I shall inform the Senate as soon as that is done. I would not, of course, be prepared to discuss those boundaries in any detail until after the Cabinet submission has been made.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister having failed to assure the Senate that the boundaries would not include buffer zones, I ask him: Is he aware of a letter signed by Chris Eccles of the rainforest unit addressed to a bank manager which says in part, `I am also writing to advise that the proposed boundary does not include buffer zones nor will any be included'? Is that still the Government's position?

—If there is any need to clarify my earlier remarks I will do so but I would not have thought that there was. There is no intention on the part of the Government now to locate buffer zones and put them within the boundaries. In respect of the original boundaries, a number of different areas have been preserved around the rainforest. If you like, they can act as buffer zones but no study is being made to include buffer zones, nor was one made. All we have done is seek to draw a boundary which will give maximum protection to those magnificent rainforests, and I think we have done so pretty well.

—Can the Minister for Finance and Minister representing the Treasurer say what would be the macroeconomic effect if Australia were to adopt the approaches to health insurance and delivery of hospital and medical services proposed by the New South Wales Australian Medical Association (AMA) branch President, Bruce Shepherd, and the shadow Australian health Minister, Wilson Tuckey, in particular to abandon the community rating system for health insurance, abolish Medicare and move to what Dr Shepherd describes as a `free enterprise' system of doctors charging `what the market will bear'?
—He is not President of the AMA.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand Dr Shepherd is the President-elect of the New South Wales Branch of the AMA. I am not sure when he actually becomes the President. It is very difficult to answer that part of the question which refers to the shadow Minister for health because the report of his views in the Australian on 5 November-most of which I should mention was in direct quotations-shows Mr Tuckey's comments to be riddled with internal contradictions and nonsensical statements. As an example of the latter, he is quoted as having said:

ANSWER.PARA: Community rating is a dream for these companies because they can be selective.

Community rating, by definition, of course, is a law, a principle, or a concept-whatever one wants to call it-which is enshrined in the legislation which requires health insurance funds to charge the same premium to individuals and to families, regardless of their health record or the size of the family. The effect of that, it is true, and it is fairly obvious, is that the relatively healthy subsidise the relatively unhealthy. Single people and smaller families or childless couples -childless couples in particular-subsidise the health services of the health insurance premiums of people who have children. The more children they have, the higher the level of subsidy is.

I thought that that was supposed to be the sort of policy of which the Opposition was in favour. Mr Tuckey explicitly said, `The first thing I want to walk away from is community rating'. As an example of the nonsensical statements-and this is not a direct quote-he is reported as having said:
It would be compulsory for private insurers to accept the chronically ill young at the same premium rates as healthy young people, so long as they had previously been insured.

That, of course, is not entirely consistent with walking away from the community rating principle. More importantly, it does not explain how young people first become insured. A child, presumably, is not expected to insure himself or herself-certainly not from the moment of birth.

TALK.START.PARA: —The parents--

—Thank you, Senator Sheil. The parents may or may not be insured. If Senator Sheil has helped to clarify that point, I am grateful. Apparently, what it means is that those children who were insured as part of their parents' insurance will, when they reach adulthood, however that may be defined, be entitled to cover, under a community rating principle-from which Mr Tuckey has already walked away, which he said in a different place-regardless of whether or not they are healthy. If, however, as Senator Sheil has clarified the policy, children whose parents were not privately insured happen to be unhealthy they will pay a penalty premium, on the ground, I suppose, that the children should be punished for the sins or shortcomings of the parents. I add that Mr Tuckey was promptly dumped the next day by the Leader of the Opposition, who realised how politically catastrophic it would be to push the abandonment of the community rating principle.

ANSWER.PARA: It is clear, notwithstanding all those shortcomings, that although Mr Tuckey is somewhat more incoherent than other Opposition health spokespeople and Dr Shepherd, his views are no less predicated on ideological prejudice. The thread which is common to Dr Shepherd, to Mr Tuckey and to the Opposition in general is that of allowing private insurance and abandoning any limit to private insurance-allowing up to 100 per cent cover-and allowing people to insure for medical expenses, no matter how high they might be or no matter how high the payment for any individual service may be. The consequence of that, as anybody who knows anything at all about the operation of markets or of adverse selection and moral hazard in insurance would know, of course, inevitably would be a huge blow-out in the total cost of health services in the country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to recent statements and proposals by the Federal Government to develop flexible and effective guidelines for offset participation by overseas owned companies. What steps have been taken to ensure that offset programs developed for Australia are truly national and cohesive in their approach and design, rather than fragmented, parochial efforts which reflect the interests of State governments and not the national economy and interest? What is the status of the discussions between the Commonwealth and the States and, in particular, the status of present discussions between the Commonwealth and the Victorian Government, to develop a national offsets policy which reflects genuine national interest criteria and a need for a uniform and rational approach to this issue?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In March 1986 the Commonwealth Government revised the previous offsets policy. At that time it indicated that it would be appropriate to review the new guidelines after a period of 12 months. That review, involving State and Federal government departments and other interested parties, has been undertaken. A number of changes to the guidelines are proposed-I do not think I need to go into those-and the Government is hopeful of obtaining a national civil offsets program which will be implemented as of 1 March 1988.

ANSWER.PARA: I take the point which is contained in Senator Macklin's question about the undesirability of fragmentation in offsets policy and the primacy of the national economic interest in trying to provide a uniform offsets policy. It is with that in mind that the Commonwealth Government is working towards the provision of uniform guidelines by 1 March 1988. That matter will be discussed and, hopefully, a conclusion will be reached at the Commonwealth-State industry Ministers conference, which I think takes place on the first two days of December.

I am unable to say what the precise status of the discussions with the Victorian Government is at this time. I know that State governments approach changes of this kind sometimes with a degree of apprehension. That was certainly so when the national industry extension service was put in place. Ultimately, agreement was reached on that undertaking which I think has proved to be not only a cost saving measure but also a success. I anticipate that there will be some apprehensions about the national guidelines and the agreement on the national civil offsets program to be implemented by 1 March 1988. Officials of my Department currently are having discussions with the various State governments in order to try to resolve any difficulties which they have.

Let me say by way of preaching, if one likes, as distinct from providing information, that it is of fundamental importance that we get agreement on these issues with these States if we are not to have fragmentation. It is particularly important that we get agreement in respect of a number of Commonwealth Government initiatives relating to the information and high technology industries and that that agreement does not reflect parochial interests but rather national interests.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is also directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, concerns the recent announcement by Mr Lang Hancock that he has recently completed negotiations on a counter-trade or barter agreement with the Government of Romania under which he could supply iron ore to that country in exchange for a range of manufactured goods. I ask the Minister: Firstly, is he aware of the agreement? Secondly, is he aware of concerns voiced by a number of organisations, including the West Australian Trades and Labor Council and the Heavy Engineering Manufacturers Association, about the proposal? Thirdly, is he aware of statements by the Premier of Queensland promoting similar arrangements concerning coal? Fourthly, has the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce examined these proposals or otherwise explored the impact that such proposals for counter-trade may have on the revitalisation of Australia's manufacturing industry? Finally, will the Minister convene a meeting of all parties impacted by the presently proposed barter deals, as requested by the Heavy Engineering Manufacturers Association?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am certainly aware that Hancock Mining has a counter-trade arrangement which would allow Australian iron ore to be supplied to Romania. I am certainly aware of the representations that have been made by the various bodies to which Senator McKiernan referred, particularly the Heavy Engineering Manufacturers Association and the West Australian Trades and Labor Council. Under the agreement between Hancock Mining and the Romanians, 53 million tonnes of iron ore would be supplied over a 15-year period starting late next year. I do not have access to the full details of these proposed private commercial transactions. To the best of my knowledge, the details are yet to be worked out between the parties. However, I am informed that the Mount Newman Mining Co. Ltd, which is involved with Hancock Mining in the plan to supply iron ore to Romania, might take some Romanian equipment by way of barter exchange.

ANSWER.PARA: As I said, I am also aware of the concerns which have been expressed and the announcement made by the Queensland Premier, prior to his announcement of his retirement next year, that he was an enthusiastic proponent of development markets for Queensland coal through counter-trade arrangements. My Department and the Australian Trade Commission, Austrade, which now falls within my portfolio, have been following these developments closely. Their examination of the issues naturally relates to my concern that the promotion of exports of Australian raw materials through counter-trade might affect the Government's effort to encourage the revitalisation of Australian manufacturing. The arrangements under consideration are private commercial transactions, the full details of which have not yet been settled between the parties and about which my Department could not at this stage expect to be fully informed. I assure the Senate that we are keeping an eye on the matter.

Senator McKiernan finally asked me whether I would convene a meeting of all the parties that might be affected by the deals. I understand that the Premier of Western Australia will conduct a study to examine the costs and benefits of counter-trade and the arrangements being set up by Hancock Mining with eastern Europe. It seems to me that at this stage interested parties might do best to concentrate their efforts on contributing to this inquiry and analysis. Of course, at the same time, my Department and Austrade will continue their monitoring and analysis of information about the deals as well as monitoring the interests and concerns of unions and business groups that might be affected.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment and the Arts. Since the purport of the Minister's previous answer to my earlier question on World Heritage listing was that formal buffer zones will not be required, I ask whether he is aware that section 14 of the operational guidelines for the implementation of the World Heritage convention adopted by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation in January 1987 requires that buffer zones be provided and that Mr Bernd von Droste, the Director of the Division of Ecological Sciences at UNESCO, has written:

QUESTION.PARA: The World Heritage Committee will require buffer zones to be provided to protect the intrinsic merit of the Queensland rainforest if formally nominated.

Is it the Government's intention deliberately to submit a flawed nomination to Paris to get itself off the hook or does the Minister claim that Mr von Droste is in error in stating that the World Heritage Committee will require buffer zones-or is the Minister being less than frank with the Senate?

TALK.START.PARA: —The only claim I would make is that Senator Puplick should listen to the answers more clearly and more carefully.
—I am listening to the answers and you are getting into deep trouble.

—Finally we have heard from Senator Boswell in Question Time about north Queensland. He has not been game to ask a question about it but we long for that. I get back to Senator Puplick. I thought that I had explained that, in preparing the boundaries, the Government had not declared formal buffer zones but had included within the boundaries a great many areas of sclerophyll forests, wet and dry, and cleared areas which could serve as buffer zones. I am more than confident that the final boundaries will satisfy all the problems that Senator Puplick has just raised. More importantly, the bank's concern, as expressed in the original question, really is a matter of saying, `Will there be a boundary for the World Heritage area and outside that will there be a buffer zone?'. The answer to that, clearly, is no.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. The Minister concluded his answer by saying in relation to the question, `Will there be a buffer zone?', that the answer is no. I draw his attention again to the specific letter from the Director of the Division of Ecological Sciences of UNESCO which says:

QUESTION.PARA: The World Heritage Committee will require buffer zones to be provided to protect the intrinsic merit of the Queensland rainforest if formally nominated.
I ask the Minister: Does he now repeat that there will not be formal buffer zones?

TALK.START.PARA: —I find this exchange increasingly tiresome, but nonetheless I will bat on. I have said that there is no need to have buffer zones declared outside the area that will be within the final boundaries and I have said that, within those final boundaries, there are areas which will serve as buffer zones. I have said this four or five times, and I am not sure how many times I should say it, but I do hope that, when asking the next question on this-given that we have had three today, or even four-Senator Puplick and the Liberal Party of Australia will say whether or not they support the nomination of the wet tropics rainforest instead of running and hiding at every opportunity. Perhaps Senator Puplick can tell us where he stands.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the Government been influenced to change its fiscal policy settings by calls yesterday from a leading businessman for a mini-Budget to produce a $3,000m surplus? If so, what factors persuaded the Government to change its policy settings?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I assume that the leading businessman referred to is Mr Elliott, the President of the Liberal Party of Australia. I do not think that Mr Elliott's comments would have much influence on the Government-they certainly do not have much influence on me, and for that matter they do not seem to have much influence on the Liberal Party, either. If the Liberal Party takes no notice of Mr Elliott, I do not see why the Government should take any notice of him. In making this comment Mr Elliott has again done what he has said that he would not do, which is enter into the policy debate in a political way. Today's editorial in the Age refers to Mr Elliott's statement that the Liberal Party has plenty of chronic underachievers in State seats. One would have to agree with that judgment because one can see so many of those chronic underachievers across the aisle in this chamber. They will need to have safe seats if they are to survive Mr Elliott's recurrent incursions into the policy debate.

ANSWER.PARA: The call for a $3 billion surplus is quite incompatible with the policy which the Opposition put to the electorate just a few months ago, which had something in it called a `balanced Budget'. However, that was predicated on a whole lot of unspecified expenditure cuts and blue sky windfall revenues arising from incentivation and better enforcement of the Income Tax Assessment Act. It is also incompatible with such proposals as providing for a couple of billion dollars worth of personal tax cuts in this year; abolishing the assets test, at a cost of $70m this year; and abolishing the fringe benefits tax, the entertainment tax, the capital gains tax and so on. All of those measures were a part of the Opposition's election policy. The Opposition would not have been able to produce anything like a balanced Budget, even taking its own shonky figures as being accurate, let alone one with a surplus of $3 billion. If Mr Elliott has any specific suggestions as to how an additional $3 billion could be cut off government expenditure, I would welcome those suggestions. I certainly do not say that I would act upon them or advocate that the Government act upon them, but I would welcome them just as I would welcome that list of expenditure cutting proposals which Mr Howard promised the Australian Broadcasting Corporation three weeks ago, but on which he has welshed.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, in that capacity and in his role as Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. The Minister will recall that his colleague Senator Walsh, in a speech made in August, expressed grave concern that the Government had not been moving as quickly as it should have in terms of economic policy adjustment. I note that the Minister, referring more specifically to industry policy, said in a speech on 6 November:

QUESTION.PARA: The question can legitimately be asked whether the pace of adjustment has been sufficiently rapid, and there is no doubt that sectoral plans developed in 1983, for example, in a totally different economic environment, require further adjustment.
I ask: Has the pace been sufficiently rapid, in terms of both industry specific proposals and macroeconomic policy? What sectoral plans does the Government intend to adjust and in what respect?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question whether the pace of adjustment has been rapid or not is a matter for some very subjective judgment. I suppose governments have to make subjective judgments about those things. The point I was simply making was that in the economic context of 1983 when the country was in deep recession, judgments were made which, with the wisdom of hindsight and the enormous improvements in the competitive strength of the Australian economy which have come about under this Government's stewardship, may not seem to be--
—Do you mean through devaluation of the dollar?

—I did not mean that. Senator Chaney interjected and asked whether I meant as a result of the devaluation of the dollar. Yes, in part; yes, as a result of the implementation of the Government's wage fixing policy and a wide range of measures which have enhanced the competitiveness of Australian firms, those things, in addition to the devaluation of the dollar, have been important in the changed circumstances which have come about.

ANSWER.PARA: But insofar as the industry's specific plans are concerned, all I can say is that at the moment the steel industry plan, which was introduced in 1983 in the context to which I have referred, will terminate at the end of December 1988. There are no plans to change that. The motor vehicle plan, which was introduced in 1984, is currently subject to a mid-term review. The only other sectoral plans which might be of relevance are those relating to shipbuilding, where there is a progressive phase-down of bounty, which is the only assistance offered to the shipbuilding industry. That phase-down has been quite steady and firm. Let me just say in relation to the textile, clothing and footwear plan that the Government made that commitment in 1986. There would need to be a very considerable reflection about what alterations, if any, might be made to that plan in the current context.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer but I ask him in light of that answer: What did he mean when he said, `There is no doubt that sectoral plans developed in 1983 require further adjustment'? To what plans was he referring, or is the statement meaningless?

—The statement is not meaningless at all. I said in my answer to the question which the honourable senator originally asked that the motor vehicle plan was currently subject to mid-term review and that the steel plan would expire, in spite of some requests that it continue. I use those by way of illustration of what I was saying on that occasion.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: FITZGERALD COMMISSION OF INQUIRY INTO POSSIBLE ILLEGAL ACTIVITIES AND ASSOCIATED POLICE MISCONDUCT

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Justice and Minister representing the Attorney-General. Has the Minister seen weekend Press reports referring to requests from the Queensland Government for amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Act and the Telecommunications (Interception) Act designed to broaden the powers of the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct? What action does the Federal Government intend to take in response to these approaches from the Queensland Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen some weekend Press reports referring to requests from the Queensland Government for amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Act and the Telecommunications (Interception) Act which were said to be designed to broaden the powers of the Fitzgerald inquiry. At present, no formal request has been received from the Queensland Government, but it is true that Mr Fitzgerald has approached the Federal Attorney-General with a view to obtaining amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Act and the Telecommunications (Interception) Act to aid him in his work. I understand that that approach by Mr Fitzgerald was concurred in by the Minister for Police, Mr Gunn. With the support, therefore, of the Queensland Government one might say that an approach has been made by Mr Fitzgerald to the Federal Government. That request is being considered with extreme urgency. In light of Mr Fitzgerald making that request, I can assure honourable senators that the Cabinet will be giving attention to his request probably later this afternoon.

ANSWER.PARA: Last week Senator Black asked in general terms whether the Government was prepared to amend the Income Tax Assessment Act to provide for access by the Fitzgerald inquiry to tax records. I indicated then that this Parliament had seen fit to make an exception to the general rule to enable the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union and other Commonwealth royal commissions to have such access in particular circumstances. I believe that Mr Fitzgerald's approach to the Commonwealth Government will be favourably considered.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask the Minister to table the document from which he has just read.
—Will the Minister table the document?
—I will.

—I refer the Minister for Transport and Communications to a letter of 18 March this year from the former Minister for Communications, Mr Duffy, to the Chairman of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, Miss O'Connor, requesting certain confidential information on the financial performance of every commercial radio licence in Australia for the years 1980-81 to 1985-86. Is the Minister aware of Mr Duffy's undertaking to the Tribunal, in the course of writing to Miss O'Connor, that the relevant information `will not be published or divulged in any way that would enable identification of any individual station's advertising revenue'? Will the Minister explain why he breached this undertaking by divulging the relevant revenue amounts in the case of the Gold Coast, Geelong, Gosford and Shepparton AM radio stations in the course of announcing the decision to introduce an establishment fee system for new FM radio licences? Does the Minister consider that such information is commercially sensitive and would not have been provided by the Tribunal in the absence of an undertaking by Mr Duffy not to publish or divulge the information in any way, given the requirements of section 124, sub-section (5), of the Broadcasting Act? While the Government is proposing to amend section 124 of the Broadcasting Act to allow the Tribunal to provide the relevant information to the Minister, does the Minister agree that he breached Mr Duffy's undertaking in the first place?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was certainly not aware of any such undertaking by Mr Duffy when making clear publicly the terms of the new establishment fee proposal and describing the financial implications of it for the areas in question. I have only just had brought to my attention the particular matter that Senator Messner has raised. I have not yet had an opportunity to see for myself what the terms of that original communication might have been and to satisfy myself that what I did say publicly may arguably have been at odds with it.

ANSWER.PARA: The particular matter that I put into the public domain was simply an estimation of what the establishment fee, in round figures, would be for each of the areas in question pursuant to the statutory formula which is proposed now to apply and which, of course, will be related, in a quite complex way, to an estimate of what the market revenue is for the service area in question. It is a necessary corollary of going down the route of an establishment fee of the kind we are proposing that there be a nexus to the existing revenue capacity of the market in question. As Senator Messner has pointed out, the legislation now before the Parliament will establish procedures for getting that information into the public domain and giving it a firm statutory base. Under the circumstances, I think it would be well understood by all those in the radio industry what the basis of my announcement was and it would be well understood what the circumstances were that led me to identify the dollar amounts in question.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Are we therefore to believe that the answer to all questions was yes?

—No, Senator Messner is not entitled to make any such assumption. I made it clear that I have not yet seen the terms of Mr Duffy's original communication, such as it was. Accordingly, I am not in a position to verify that anything that I may have said was in any way at odds with it. I am simply explaining the context in which I made my statement. Most people in the broadcasting industry were most anxious for me to make the statement in order to quantify the implications. In fact, Senator Messner was most anxious that I make some statement, and he vigorously pressed the cause with me, of what the dollar implications of this would be. Out of the goodness of my heart, I told him. Being filled with an abundance of goodness of heart, I told the community at large and the industry as well. Now Senator Messner comes in here and churlishly castigates me for it. He will be seen for the churl that he manifestly is.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF SOCIAL SECURITY: TREATMENT OF PENSIONERS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. I draw the Minister's attention to an article in the Adelaide News of yesterday entitled `Pensioners treated like animals: report'. According to that article, an internal report conducted in the Department of Social Security showed that the clients were treated in some instances with little or no respect at all. Can the Minister assure the Senate that, if the report is accurate, the Government will do all in its power to see that all Department of Social Security clients are treated with respect and dignity?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the article that appeared in the Adelaide News and in a number of other papers; it got a pretty big run around the country. I have not seen a copy of the letter which the person concerned wrote; that is an internal matter for the Department. The allegations about the treatment of Department of Social Security clients were not based on any research, review or report. Rather, these gross distortions happen to be the opinion of one person, in this case a social worker for the Department. Therefore, they are one officer's perceptions about what went on in one office, presumably at one point in time, and they cannot be taken as indicative of general staff attitude.

ANSWER.PARA: I am sure that all honourable senators will be aware that the Department of Social Security employs some 17,000 people in 220 offices throughout the country. That makes it one of the largest office networks in Australia. It services thousands of people every day. Since this Government came to office, we have attempted to ensure that each one of the 2.7 million pensioners and beneficiaries has adequate rights in terms of social security payments. I assure the Senate that it is Government policy that Social Security clients be treated with dignity and respect. Since this Government came to office we have taken a number of steps to make sure that this is so.

During the last four years the Government has introduced a new approach to administration. For the first time it has instilled into staff the values of sensitivity and respect for clients. In 1985 a new departmental charter was introduced at the Minister's direction which reflects Labor's concern to improve service to clients. The Department's charter reads as follows:
To deliver social security entitlements and services in accordance with the policies of the government in a fair, sensitive, helpful and friendly manner with efficient and effective use of resources.

The Government has ensured that this new charter is displayed prominently in Social Security offices throughout the country and that it has been brought to the attention of staff. The Government expects the charter to be enforced; the staff understand that. New training programs have been introduced to teach staff the skills necessary. Although isolated incidents may occur-with a staff of 17,000, obviously there will be some-all Social Security clients and all honourable senators can be assured that the clients will receive the best possible treatment and service.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. Recently in the Senate the Minister clearly acknowledged that corruption in State police forces could threaten the security and, therefore, the success of National Crime Authority (NCA) operations. The Minister would also acknowledge that, given the case of police commissioners Allan and Lewis in New South Wales and Queensland and the position of the New South Wales Minister for Corrective Services, the danger of corruption does and could exist at the highest police force and political levels. Will the Minister recognise that the suggestions he has made to Mr Justice Stewart are merely tinkering with the problem and are, therefore, inadequate? Will he take immediate steps to review the fundamental mechanisms for informing, approving and/or vetoing NCA targeting and operations? Will he acknowledge that, without this step, the NCA remains fatally flawed? Given the fact that there was no reference to the NCA of the corruption currently the subject of the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct, is it not naive and stupid to believe that, when corruption does occur at the highest level, there could be any hope of a reference to the NCA as such a reference would be compromised from the start?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —There was so much in that question that I do not know that I have managed to make a note of all the elements of it. But I reject that statement in the early part of Senator Newman's question that my letters to Mr Justice Stewart and Commissioner Grey concerning the fresh approach to the question of how one might appoint liaison officers with State police forces to understand the operations of the NCA within their jurisdiction represented a mere tinkering with the problem. To say that that is merely tinkering with the problem rather than trying to deal with it in a fundamental way is, I think, unfair. Until I receive a response from Mr Justice Stewart-I have not yet had a response from him to my letter-I would not assume that he would share the view of Senator Newman, apparently, that my proposal that the National Crime Authority have a more clear process of coming to a mutual agreement with the State police force concerned as to the person to fulfil the role of liaison officer is a mere tinkering with the problem. I think that it is a very important aspect of the successful safeguarding of the NCA's operations.

ANSWER.PARA: I expect that when we come to the meeting of the Inter-governmental Committee of the National Crime Authority next Thursday week in Hobart and the meeting of the Australian Police Ministers Council the following Friday in Hobart we will be in a position to come up with, if not a formal promulgated set of rules to govern that relationship between the NCA and State police forces, certainly a better understanding-perhaps a tacit but well understood means of dealing with this very sensitive and delicate question. Obviously, one would not want to have such a formal structure of coming to mutual agreement as to the person to fulfil the role of liaison officer that any suspicion that was held by the NCA would, by being formally communicated in a very structured way, alert that person to the fact that he was possibly under surveillance and under suspicion. It is a very sensitive and delicate matter. It is also very fundamental and is not a question of merely tinkering with the problem.

As to the general question of the Inter-governmental Committee and its role regarding the granting of references to the National Crime Authority: as I recall it, the ultimate safeguard for the NCA in relation to State governments which might, as is implied in the question, because of their own corruption be disinclined to give a reference to the NCA which has been sought, is that the National Crime Authority can make that known to the Parliament. I do not have the National Crime Authority legislation in front of me, but, as I recall it, there are provisions in the legislation passed by this Parliament-provisions which were intentionally put into that legislation-that if the NCA is refused a reference it can make that known to this Parliament. In that way, it becomes a matter of public record and leads to the sort of questioning and pressure in the political domain which will bring such a corrupt government, refusing to acquiesce in a reference sought by the NCA, to account. In the seven references that have been sought so far, there has been no question at any stage of any of the State governments concerned, co-operatively with the Commonwealth Government, refusing to co-operate in the fullest way with the National Crime Authority in the granting of those references. I expect that that will continue. In fact, we will be looking at a new reference at the meeting on the afternoon of Thursday week in Hobart. I would expect that that will be approached with absolute integrity. As I said, the runs are on the board in that regard.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I asked the Minister whether it was not naive to think that when corruption does occur at the highest level there could be any hope of a reference to the NCA as such a reference would be compromised from the start. I am not questioning whether there have been any references knocked back, but is it not naive to think that the NCA would even propose a reference if it believed it would have to go through compromised and corrupt hands?

—I understand what Senator Newman is driving at, but I do not believe that, if Mr Justice Stewart and the two other members of the Authority came to the conclusion that ordinary law enforcement methods had failed in relation to a particularly serious form of criminal activity harming this nation and its citizens, they would not be able to find a way of putting a reference to the Inter-governmental Committee and that that reference, having been put, would not put such pressure on the State government concerned that it would comply. These are all matters of great delicacy and I would acknowledge the point that has been made by Senator Newman, but from my workings with the NCA over the last five or six months, I believe that its strength is such that it could deal with the particular misgiving that she has.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Zakharov Sen A.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Local Government whether she is aware of an article by Senator Stone in the Sydney Morning Herald on 19 August 1986 in which he claims:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . the Commonwealth Government has no good reason to be involved in local authority finances . . .

The article then proposes drastic cuts to Commonwealth payments to local government. What would be the effect on local government activities of Senator Stone's proposal that $300m be cut from their grants?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Zakharov for her question. This issue was first raised by my colleague Senator Walsh, who is, of course, a great supporter of local government and who is very concerned--

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Walsh, just 10 days ago, raised this issue in this place, and was very critical of Senator Stone for daring to suggest that local government could be cut by such a drastic figure. What would a cut of $300m mean to Australian local government? It would reduce Commonwealth funding to local government by more than one-half and that, of course, would have a dramatic effect on local government throughout the country. We could expect that rates would double, unemployment would grow dramatically and there would be a very serious situation. Let me take a lighthearted look at what Senator Stone's proposal would mean. Perhaps all the lights in the cities of Australia would go out. Street lighting would depend--

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps street lighting would have to be paid for by the consumer on a quarterly basis. If one had not paid one's street lighting account-just like a Telecom account-maybe one's street lights would go off. In terms of funding for sewerage, no doubt the old-fashioned term `spending a penny' would take on a totally new meaning. I am prepared to accept that Senator Stone did write this article over 12 months ago, before he became a senator and before he had the opportunity to hear from local councils throughout Queensland. I am sure that Queensland local councils will be very keen to discuss Senator Stone's proposal with him and I suggest that they all write to Senator Stone to ask him to justify this quite draconian measure of cutting local government expenditure by half. Furthermore, I think Senator Stone had better talk to his colleague Mr Ian Cameron, who is the shadow spokesperson on local government. I am sure he would be very concerned because he would effectively be out of a job in Queensland if he had to try to sell Senator Stone's proposal.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr President, I am a very reasonable person and I am prepared to accept that Senator Stone, as a new senator, does have a lot to learn, and perhaps he does have a lot to learn about local government. Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen said recently that he was surprised about some statements that Senator Stone had made which criticised the good Queensland Premier. He said that, after all, Senator Stone did get into the Senate holding on to Flo's skirt.

TALK.START.PARA: —Dress.
—Dress. Thank you, Senator Ray. I am prepared to be yet another Queensland female senator who will assist Senator Stone.
—Whose skirt did you get in on?

—I am not offering Senator Stone my skirts in any sense, but I am offering to take him under my wing to teach him about local government. I am sure that officers of my Department would welcome the opportunity to give him some very serious instruction about the importance of local government and the importance of Commonwealth support for local government programs. Furthermore, as I have just returned from the 1987 National Awards for Innovation in Local Government, I would like to extend an invitation to Senator Stone to come to those awards with me next year so that he can meet with a number of local councillors. There were 400 entries, which shows that local councils are very interested in innovation and in cost-effective management. I am sure they would welcome the opportunity to discuss some of Senator Stone's reactionary views on local government. Firstly, I invite Senator Stone to take advantage of my offer to find out more about local government funding in Australia and, secondly, I extend an open invitation to him to come to the National Awards for Innovation in Local Government next year. I would welcome that opportunity, and I am sure local government would welcome the opportunity to tell Senator Stone what it is doing and why it cannot afford to lose $300m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to comments of the Foreign Minister on the Walsh Report on 12 November 1987. When speaking of the payment former Foreign Minister Diro of Papua New Guinea (PNG) acknowledged he received from General Murdani, head of the Indonesian military, to help with electoral matters, Mr Hayden said:

QUESTION.PARA: What takes place, however, between Indonesia and PNG is a matter for bilateral concerns and exchanges and not for Australia.

I ask the Minister: Is not the stability of the PNG Government a matter of concern to Australia? Is not the statement of the then Acting Foreign Minister Matiabe, who remains a member of the Government of PNG, that it was normal for PNG political leaders to receive funds from foreign interests of concern to Australia? Is not the subsequent statement of Mr Diro, who, I remind the Minister, is a former head of the PNG military, that PNG was ripe for a military coup of concern to Australia? Now that the Foreign Minister and, finally, the Defence Minister have visited PNG, will the Minister advise the Senate what actions the Australian Government will take towards supporting stable government in PNG or are we now, under this Government, as impotent in influencing events in PNG as we were in Fiji?

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia's relations with Papua New Guinea are of acute importance and significance to both countries. That is fully acknowledged and is coming to be articulated in a new way with the treaty of mutual understanding arrangements presently being put in place. I do not think that anything that has happened in recent times in any way puts at risk that relationship. What would put it at risk, were we to go thundering around like a herd of bulls in china shops in the way that Senator Hill seems to propose, would be our commenting on everything and anything that happens in regard to our neighbour and, in particular, making strong views known on matters that are obviously of sensitivity and that are being dealt with manifestly very effectively within that country's own political system. The reference to Mr Matiabe still being a member of the Government fails to make the point, which I would have thought was far and away the most obvious one in the circumstances, that he is no longer the Acting Foreign Minister, apparently as a result of what he had to say on this particular subject matter. It is perfectly evident that Mr Wingti, the Prime Minister, has responded decisively and, as one in this country might think, appropriately to the particular circumstances with which he is confronted. Beyond that I simply repeat what Mr Hayden has said-that this is a matter for the Papua New Guinea and Indonesian governments to deal with as they see fit and that it would be inappropriate for the Australian Government to comment.

—During Question Time, Senator Puplick referred to an article called `Eco-Defence!' written by Simon Balderstone. I said that I was not familiar with the article, but I have now read it. In answering some of the questions that Senator Puplick raised, I think it should be noted that the article does not at any point advocate tree spiking. It merely enters into a discussion as to the pros and cons of legal and illegal direct action by conservationists. Of course, Senator Puplick, as a participant in direct action by conservationists in blockades and demonstrations, would no doubt applaud it. The article was written by Mr Balderstone when he was a freelance journalist. It was published in September 1986 although it was written some time before that. At no time does he advocate any activity that would cause harm to a person. Simon Balderstone is owed an apology by Senator Puplick.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave, Mr President, to move a motion to take note of the answer by the Minister for the Environment and the Arts (Senator Richardson).

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer.
The article to which Senator Richardson has referred entitled `Eco-Defence' says in part:

Time, however, is of the essence if the environment is to be protected and saved. Everywhere, people are resorting to direct action in an attempt to achieve their aims. Lobbying often fails, and more drastic measures have to be taken.

I accept that the Minister has rightly said that this article was written at a time when Mr Balderstone was not a member of his staff. However, the article is quite clear. It analyses in a particular fashion a series of techniques, including what is called monkeywrenching, `ecotage' and the process of tree spiking-which is not only described in detail in this article but also in fact described by way of the presentation of a very explicit--

TALK.START.PARA: —Did he write that section?

—I will come to that in a moment. It includes a very explicit guide to how one goes about the process of tree spiking-the sort of technique to be used. This includes mention of the fact that a silent and cordless drill should be used so as not to draw attention to the people spiking trees, that metal detectors are of such a nature that it would be better to use ceramic rods and not steel rods in the spiking of trees and that it is very important that the process be concluded by using a dab of clear silicone in order to conceal the whole thing and that a small chip of bark be pressed on to conceal the hole. A number of other techniques are described in such considerable detail that this article can only be seen to be a manual, a how-to-do-it guide, as far as this activity is concerned. The text, which is not in quotations and which does not discuss any of the articles published in overseas journals which Mr Balderstone seeks to analyse, makes it perfectly clear that the article gives support and encouragement to the adoption of these techniques. The article says:

SPEECH.PARA: And to change those things-
that is, in relation to certain practices-
positive action obviously has to be taken. The differences of opinion within the conservation movement stem not from differences in principles, but in modus operandi.
Generally, however, direct action, properly organised and timed, seems to have overwhelming support within the ecological movement.

The article certainly makes qualifications as to the practice known as monkeywrenching. Nevertheless, the article is quite clear in the way it analyses and presents in a positive and formal fashion a do-it-yourself technique for sabotage in an ecological sense, in a fashion which is bound in the long run to be dangerous to the lives of ordinary people going about their normal business, in forestry or other operations. I in no way resile from the comments which I made either in the question I asked or subsequent to Senator Richardson's statement. I seek leave to table the article which is the subject of the debate which has just taken place.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the artcile.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an extraordinary attack by Senator Puplick. I find it more than disturbing that a member of my staff, or any journalist, should be attacked in such a way. The great preponderance of this article contains quotes from senior people in the conservation movement around the country. Those quotes attack members of the conservation movement who take direct action beyond blockades and demonstrations-into monkeywrenching and tree spiking. The great preponderance of this article is against that and this is made clear time and again. The reality is that Simon Balderstone fulfilled his function as a journalist. He did not editorialise; he reported. At no stage did he indicate, in any part, an attack on the person. He never has and never would. That is what Senator Puplick failed to acknowledge.

SPEECH.PARA: Debate (on motion by Senator Chaney) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) having regard:
(i) to the desire of all people to live in peace and freedom and to enjoy basic human rights, including the right to self-determination,

(ii) to Australia's membership of the United Nations and regard for the principles of its Charter, the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, the United Nations Declaration on the Granting of Independence to Colonial Countries and Peoples adopted by its General Assembly on 14 December 1960 by Resolution 1514 (XV), and the Final Act of the Helsinki Agreement, and
(iii) to the fact that, whilst the Australian people have acquired these rights and freedoms other peoples are deprived of them; and
(b) taking note:
(i) of the Resolution of the European Parliament on the Situation in the Baltic States (Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania) adopted on 13 January 1983,

(ii) of the fact that the 3 Baltic States were independent sovereign republics and members of the League of Nations during the years 1918 to 1940, when they were occupied by the Soviet Union in consequence of an agreement between the then German Government under Hitler and the Soviet Government under Stalin (the so-called Molotov-Ribbentrop Pact),

(iii) of the fact that the occupation of these states by the Soviet Union still continues, but that in accordance with other democratic governments the Australian Government has not recognised de jure their incorporation into the Soviet Union,
(iv) that the peoples of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania are being denied many basic human rights but that they have not given up their struggle for self-determination and freedom, and
(v) that an intensive process of Russification is taking place in these occupied countries aimed at elimination of the indigenous languages and culture;
resolves-

(a) that Australia, as a member of the United Nations, should fulfil its obligations to promote and encourage respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, and should support the European Parliament's Resolution in respect of the Baltic States,

(b) that in order to do so the Australian Government should, on its own initiative, and by seeking the support of like-minded governments, bring the question of human rights and self-determination for the Baltic States before all appropriate forums of the United Nations, and especially before the United Nations Human Rights Commission, and
(c) that the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade should be directed to take all necessary steps in order to implement this Resolution.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FINANCE AND GOVERNMENT OPERATIONS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement about the Government's response to the report of the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations on Australian Broadcasting Corporation employment contracts and their confidentiality, to incorporate the statement in Hansard, and to move a motion relating to the statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

For the information of honourable senators I present the Government's response to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations on `ABC Employment Contracts and their Confidentiality'.
BACKGROUND

During hearings held by Estimates Committee C, on 15 April 1985, on the Additional Estimates of expenditure for the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC), several questions were asked of ABC officers concerning payments to Ms Geraldine Doogue, under her employment contract with the ABC, in relation to The National television news program.

The information sought was regarded by the ABC as commercially confidential and ABC officers declined to provide it. An offer was made, however, for the data requested to be provided to the Minister for Communications for his information.

Arising out of the Senate's consideration of the report of Senate Estimates Committee C on 16 May 1985, the Senate decided that the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government operations should investigate and report on:
Whether the claim by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation that certain information should not be made available to Estimates Committee C, on the ground of commercial confidentiality, is justified.

In conducting its investigation, the Committee decided that it should examine and determine whether such contracts were justifiable, and whether claims regarding their confidential status could be justified.
CONCLUSIONS OF THE COMMITTEE
The Committee reached conclusions in four areas:
The use of contract employment;
The confidentiality of such contracts;
The particular nature of Ms Doogue's contract; and
The accountability of the ABC to the Parliament and its Committees.
These conclusions were:
In Respect of Contract Employment

In general the Committee did not disapprove of the use of contracts of employment by a statutory authority when it would facilitate the activities of the authority. The Committee believed, however, that such contracts should be used only for limited employment or for the engagement of persons to perform particular tasks and only after all other options have been considered. They should not be used for normal full-time employment.

The Committee believed that contracts for service were not a desirable form of arranging employment for a Commonwealth authority. Such contracts could distort the normal employment relationship and may allow a person whose services are obtained under the contract to gain tax or other financial advantages not available to other employees.
The ABC should introduce clear guidelines on the use of contract employment which address these points.

The Government believes that statutory authorities such as the ABC should have the flexibility in their staffing arrangements to employ personnel on a contract basis. In many cases statutory authorities are operating in a competitive environment and are subject to market trends and pressures, and constantly changing challenges. It is essential to their ability to compete successfully with other organisations in these situations that they have the facility to engage staff for specific projects or time periods, with specialist skills, particular qualities, or expertise which may not be available other than on a contractual basis.

Having set out this framework, I consider that the Committee's conclusions are not incompatible with this approach and would provide a basis for guiding authorities such as the ABC in this area of their activities.

In respect of the introduction of guidelines the ABC has advised that it is currently reviewing its policy and practices with a view to developing guidelines which address the areas of concern to the Committee.
Confidentiality of Contracts
The broad conclusions in this area were:

The Committee considered that an authority could not presume that the Parliament or its committees would not insist on disclosure of details of such contracts. As a matter of accountability it is desirable that details of contracts not be confidential.

If information concerning contracts is claimed to be commercially confidential, proper regard should be had for genuine personal and commercial interests, such as privacy or competitiveness, that may be affected by publication.

Estimates Committees were established for the specific purpose of examining the expenditure programs of Commonwealth Departments and statutory authorities. Authorities must, therefore, be prepared to account to Estimates Committees for all aspects of their financial management and administration, even when the information sought may be regarded as private or commercially confidential.

The Government accepts the broad thrust of the Committee's comments on the issue of confidentiality. However, it is noted that the Committee's report seems implicitly to accept that in some circumstances the ABC could be justified in seeking to presume the confidentiality of contract details. In this respect, the Government would expect that Parliament would be mindful of the need to respect the confidentiality of any information which may be personal, of value to the contractor's competitors, or detrimental to the activities of the particular authority.

The Government is conscious of the fact that authorities such as the ABC, which are in close competition with the private sector for certain personnel, may need to keep certain information relating to contracts of employment confidential. Knowledge that such information concerning the personal privacy of the individuals concerned could be made public at a Parliamentary Committee hearing may discourage those persons with the necessary skills from accepting appointment.

In these circumstances, the Government believes that Parliament should assess the difficulties associated with making the information public and ensure that any such adverse effect is balanced against the public interest in the Parliament obtaining the information.
Ms Doogue's Contract

The Committee considered that it was irresponsible of the ABC to enter into a contract with Ms Doogue which provided for the payment for services so far in advance of the services being provided. The Committee understood the ABC's desire to obtain Ms Doogue's services but considered that a stronger negotiating stand should have been taken by the ABC to resist the imposition of an ``up front'' payment claim. It also considered that there should be no doubt on the part of the ABC that Parliament or its Committees was entitled to have full disclosure of the provisions of the contracts. The Government notes the Committee's conclusion, and the ABC advises that it accepts the Committee's views on advance payment provisions and it will restrict such provisions to cases where there is demonstrable advantages and adequate protection for the ABC in the case of non-performance.
Accountability of the ABC to the Parliament and its Committees

The Committee considered that the ABC must expect and respond to the same degree of scrutiny as any Commonwealth statutory authority in reporting its operations to Parliament. Subject to my earlier comments about when Parliament seeks information which is commercially sensitive or involves personal privacy issues, the Government fully accepts and agrees with the Committee's conclusion.

Why does it not seek to promote within the Parliament a means by which those matters can be further examined? . . . the ABC . . . will restrict such provisions to cases where there is demonstrable advantages and adequate protection for the ABC in the case of non-performance.

This really comes to the point of the inquiry and opens up the basic question to which an answer was sought by Estimates Committee C. It initially asked this question some two years ago. It is amazing that it has taken the Government two years to give us the answer and tell us in a Yes Minister fashion that, yes, that is a problem, but it does not do anything further about it and it does not seek to demonstrate further how the ABC might overcome these problems. I would like to know to whom they are to be demonstrated, whether it is to the Senate or to some other body. One was extremely surprised to find out at this late stage that no adequate protection is being written into these contract documents, apparently for the ABC, in those events.

I guess that this comes to the central point of the response and the initial inquiry set up by Estimates Committee C; that is, that there are severe and serious shortcomings in the contracting arrangements between employees who are outstanding personalities, such as Ms Geraldine Doogue, and the ABC itself. It certainly represents an issue that the Government and particularly the Senate ought to be examining. The Government, having recognised this, has failed to do something about it; it is merely drawing attention to the point.
