They simply boil down to lip service to whatever it is that the Government believes ought to be proper governmental control in these areas. The statement is inadequate. It is certainly very late. It has taken the Government 12 months to labour mightily to bring forward this mouse and, as I have said, it adds nothing to the overall debate in this area.

We have before us some 26 treaties or conventions covering a very large range of matters. They include a number of extradition treaties, a number of fisheries treaties, an agreement on nuclear science and technology, and the Budapest Treaty on the International Recognition of the Deposit of Micro-organisms for the Purposes of Patent Procedure, which is very important, especially to the world's leading genetic engineers. They include the ratification by Australia of the Convention for the Conservation of Antarctic Seals, which has long been called for and vigorously supported by the Opposition. TALK.START.PARA: —Is there a hole in it?

—I will come to that in a moment. The ozone layer has been a matter of debate in recent months since some of the sensational reports which appeared in the popular Press, as well as in journals such as Nature, about the emergence of a hole in the ozone layer over the Antarctic. One of the consequences of this is the exposure of the surface of the earth to a far greater penetration by ultraviolet light. It has been estimated that for every one per cent reduction in the concentration of ozone in the atmosphere, our protective shield, there will be a 2 per cent increase in the rate of non-melanoma skin cancers in countries such as Australia, which already has the highest rate of skin cancer of any country in the world.

SPEECH.PARA: Ever since Rowland and Molina first discussed this phenomenon in 1974, the effect of chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs), especially those known as CFC11 and CFC12, has been highly suspect as a primary cause of the ozone depletion. Australia has been an active participant in the work of the United Nations environment program conferences on this issue. We support fully both the 1985 Vienna Convention for the Protection of the Ozone Layer, which is one of the treaties on this list, and the associated Montreal Protocol of 1987, which I hope the Government will speedily adopt. The Australian Environment Council, together with the National Health and Medical Research Council, produced an excellent report on this subject as far back as 1983 entitled Environmental, Health and Economic Implications of the Use of Chlorofluorocarbons as Aerosol Propellants and Possible Substitutes.

The Opposition fully supports the efforts of the Government to gain rapid adoption of the recommendations of the Montreal Protocol to secure a 50 per cent reduction in the use of CFCs by 1998-99. Action to date on this subject has been most encouraging in Australia, where voluntary compliance with the code has already reduced the levels of CFC releases by 35 per cent since the peak year of 1974. But a great deal remains to be done. It is very disappointing to see that at the last meeting of Australian environment Ministers, a proposal advanced by my colleague the Minister for the Environment in the Tasmanian Liberal Government, Mr Peter Hodgman, for urgent action on this matter was not taken up by the other Ministers. The majority of Labor Federal and State Ministers were not prepared to agree to Liberal Minister Hodgman's call for more urgent action to be taken on this matter.

This Convention is very important. I believe it is also important that it operate as far as is possible through voluntary compliance within the industry. A notable contribution to this has already been made by the McDonalds Corporation, which in the United States of America has abandoned the use of the foam packaging for its hamburgers and other items, the decay of that foam packaging being an important contributor towards the release of CFCs into the atmosphere. I believe that its Australian subsidiary will follow suit shortly. Nevertheless, it is important for the Government to give an indication of its support to the private sector for the way in which it has handled this matter. At the same time it should assume the proper responsibility it has for atmospheric protection in Australia. I am glad to see that this Convention is one of those on the list. As I say, the Opposition has pressed for our adherence to the Budapest Treaty on Micro-organisms for Patent Purposes and the convention for the Conservation of Antarctic Seals. It is important that these international instruments, where they are relevant and where they do not trespass upon the proper and legitimate rights of states, can be entered into. We certainly commend the action taken by Government departments and advisers who have had a great deal of involvement in these areas and we are glad to see that these treaties are part of the list which is now before the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: That the following matter be referred to the Standing Committee on Procedure-
The practice of Senators of referring written questions to Departments prior to the hearings of Estimates Committees.

I would like to outline the reasons that the Committee has for bringing this matter to the attention of the Standing Committee on Procedure. It has been a long-standing practice of committee or non-committee members to give notice to departments of possible lines of questioning and expect that the departments will have the officers who deal with the matters at the committee hearing to answer the questions put by senators. This practice in recent years has been expanded to the point that some senators have been placing questions on notice to all departments and expecting that the answers will be provided in committee hearings.

While not opposing the concept of having questions on notice to the departments, the Committee is concerned that the practice will develop into a situation where departments will be faced with an enormous task of answering questions given to them by the Estimates committee, although the questions were never actually asked in the Estimates hearing. One purpose of the Estimates committees has been to ask departmental officers questions concerning their programs in a committee atmosphere where there is face to face contact between witnesses and senators. The Committee believes that this situation should not be diluted by the growing practice of senators placing questions on notice.

The Committee further recognises that all senators cannot attend every committee meeting, but suggests that senators should take one of two lines of approach: either pass on their questions so that colleagues on the committee might ask the necessary questions, or use the other forms that the Standing Orders provide to obtain information from departments. The Committee also believes that the process of placing questions on notice can be confusing, especially where a department answers the question at the beginning of the hearing, and when an honourable senator asks a similar or related question the officials refer to the tabled document and state that it has already been answered. This process leads to a diminution of the functions of honourable senators on the committee to ask and seek answers from departmental officials.

I also make some comments in relation to replies to questions on notice. The Committee also wishes to express concern at the delay in receiving replies to questions taken on notice during the hearings by the Department of Community Services and Health. These were received by the Committee one week after the time allowed by the Committee and despite numerous calls by the staff of the Committee. It was only after intervention by the Chairman that a satisfactory resolution to the problem was achieved. The Committee acknowledges that it may be difficult for departments to answer some questions in a short period, but believes that the two weeks that the Department of Community Services and Health originally had was more than adequate to answer the majority of the questions that were asked. The Committee anticipates that by the Supplementary Estimates in 1988 the Department will be able to comply with the deadlines imposed by the Estimates committees timetable.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

The speeches read as follows-
AUSTRALIAN HORTICULTURAL CORPORATION BILL 1987

The purpose of the Bill is to provide for the establishment of the Australian Horticultural Corporation (AHC). The Bill forms one essential element of the package of measures being introduced primarily to enhance the capacity of the horticultural industries to expand exports. The other measures in the package are the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation Bill, the Horticultural Policy Council Bill, the Horticultural Levy Bill, the Horticultural Levy Collection Bill, the Horticultural Export Charge Bill, the Horticultural Export Charge Collection Bill and the Australian Horticultural Corporation (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill.

The package of Bills implements the institutional initiatives for the horticultural sector which form part of the Government's Economic and Rural Policy Statement of April 1986 and for which the Government has committed a total of $9 million over five years to assist in their establishment and early operation. The sector's output in 1985-86 was valued at some $2 billion, with exports amounting to around $400 million in that year. While the horticultural sector has achieved significant increases in exports in recent years, opportunities exist for further substantial increases. For the sector's full export potential to be realised, however, there needs to be a more co-ordinated and sustained activity both in horticultural products marketing and in research.

The Bills relating to the two Corporations provide for the establishment of complementary institutions which will be required, as their main task, to assist the horticultural industries to develop their export marketing and research efforts. The four Bills dealing with product levies and export charges provide for funds to be raised for participating industries to help finance the ongoing activities of the two Corporations. The Horticultural Policy Council Bill fits into the package by providing the means for developing more consistent and comprehensive policies at the national level for the horticultural industries. The Council will be funded wholly by the Commonwealth for 5 years. Funding and the Council's continuance will be reviewed in its fifth year of operation.

The Australian Horticultural Corporation (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill provides for such things as the transfer to the AHC of staff, assets and liabilities from the Australian Apple and Pear Corporation on its abolition.

Many views were conveyed to the Government by industry organisations and other groups throughout Australia during the extensive consultation process that was undertaken on the initiatives. These views were carefully considered and many of the suggestions which were put forward are now reflected in the Bills before the House. The Government believes that, in their present form, the Bills address constructively the needs of the industries and that the horticultural sector will benefit significantly from these new institutions.

Participation in the AHC by horticultural industries is voluntary. In the case of industries currently covered by statutory marketing arrangements, namely the canned fruits, dried fruits and apple and pear industries, the situation is as follows.

For canned fruits, the Government has decided that the statutory marketing powers of the Australian Canned Fruits Corporation are to be extended by one year only, to December 1988, and that the Corporation be wound up in 1989. Whether or not any of its other functions would be passed over to the AHC is a matter for consideration by the industry. The question of merging the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation with the AHC is being deferred until 1988. In the meantime, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy is currently exploring with the industry the question of a separate Corporation in line with the Government's policy on Primary Industry Statutory Marketing Authorities.

The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy advised the Australian Apple and Pear Growers' Association in May 1987 that he considered it would be in the best interests of the industry if it were encompassed in the AHC from the outset. He has had further consultations with that organisation's executive since then and, as a result, modifications to the details of the proposals were made to accommodate the Industry's concerns. At its Annual Conference in July 1987 the Association agreed to participation in the AHC.

The inclusion of apple and pear activities under the AHC makes the Australian Apple and Pear Corporation redundant. The Bill thus provides for the repeal of the principal and amending Apple and Pear Corporation Acts and, as I mentioned earlier, there is an associated Bill which deals with transitional and other provisions arising from the abolition of this Corporation.
I turn now to the specific provisions of the Bill.
Objects, Functions and Powers

The objects, functions and powers of the AHC are set out in Part II, Division 1 of the Bill and additional powers are described in Part V. The principal object of the AHC is to assist Australian horticultural industries to achieve their full potential in overseas markets. To achieve this it will encourage, facilitate and co-ordinate export activities, and provide a link from exporting and marketing back to growers to encourage production in line with market needs. It will complement, not replace, the marketing efforts of private exporters.

An important subsidiary object of the AHC is to contribute to the development of horticultural production and marketing within Australia. In particular, it will be able to undertake domestic promotional activities on behalf of Horticultural Industries and, in this respect, will continue to handle the extensive domestic promotion relating to apples and pears.

Not all horticultural industries will require the same services from the AHC and, for that reason, the Bill provides flexibility for the AHC in meeting varying industry needs; it also empowers the Corporation to carry out work for individuals and groups on a fee-for-service basis on the one hand, and on the other, it will have the power to appoint agents to perform any tasks on its behalf.

In addition to the range of powers that will enable the Corporation to undertake general activities for and on behalf of the industries, the Bill provides it with export trading powers. These powers are, however, subject to the written approval of the Minister and the Government is firmly of the view that they would be applied only in circumstances where there is general support for the relevant industry. To facilitate such export trading, the Corporation may buy and sell horticultural products and it may enter into contracts concerning transport and insurance.

In Part V of the Bill the AHC will also be empowered, if appropriate, to control exports and provide for licensing arrangements. The exercise of such powers is to be fully consistent with the Corporation's primary object of assisting the horticultural industries to achieve their full potential in export markets. The Government will only agree to the making of regulations and ministerial orders for this purpose if it is satisfied that this is the case and that the controls are in the best interests of the industry.
Organisational Structure

The Government's policy for Primary Industry Statutory Marketing Authorities provides that it is not appropriate for Boards of such authorities to have as members persons representing various sectors of industry but rather that the members should have the skills appropriate to their corporate responsibilities. In conformity with that policy, the Bill provides that membership of the AHC is based on qualifications and experience in various specified fields of endeavour.

Part II, Division 2 of the Bill provides that the membership will comprise an independent Chairperson, one government member, the Managing Director and six other members. The six other members are to be selected on the basis of their expertise in one or more of a number of fields such as horticultural growing, horticultural exporting, business management, finance and marketing. Members, other than the Managing Director, will be appointed by the Minister on a part-time basis; except for the government member, the appointments will be for periods of up to three years but members will be eligible for re-appointment. Under this provision, membership terms can be staggered to ensure that the Corporation always has some members with experience of its activities and knowledge of current issues. The Managing Director will be appointed by the Board but with the terms and conditions of employment being approved by the Minister.

The diversity of products and industries in the horticultural sector means the Board will need product-specific advice. Part II, Division 8 of the Bill therefore empowers the Corporation to establish such specialist committees as it considers necessary.

The number of product group committees and the range of products a particular committee might cover will be decided by the Corporation after consultation with the industries participating in the AHC. Given its size and importance, the apple and pear industry can confidently anticipate that there would be a separate committee for its products; and so, too, can the citrus industry, which has given its firm commitment to participate in the AHC.

The members of a product group committee will be appointed by the Corporation and comprise a Chairperson, who is to be a member of the Corporation Board, and from three to five other members with product-specific expertise in areas which are, in general terms, the same as those laid down for Corporation members.

As it is the Board of the Corporation that is accountable for actions performed on its behalf, product group committees will not be autonomous. However, the Corporation will be empowered to delegate its powers to the committees and I would expect, for example, that the bulk of any activity undertaken on domestic promotion would be so delegated. This will free the Board to focus on the broader, general, export policy issues.
Selection Procedures

Part III of the Bill provides for the establishment of the Australian Horticultural Corporation Selection Committee. The function of the Committee will be to identify and nominate persons with expertise in one or more specified fields for appointment by the Minister of Corporation members. The Selection Committee will comprise a Chairperson selected by the Minister, six members appointed from nominations put forward by relevant horticultural producer organisations and one member nominated by horticultural exporting interests.

In the longer term, when levy arrangements have been put in place, national organisations representing those industries which provide the levy proceeds for funding the Corporation will be the ones to be prescribed as eligible to provide producer nominations. However, as the apple and pear industry is the only industry for which levies will be collected for the AHC from its outset, and as the citrus industry is, so far, the only other industry which has given a firm commitment to participate and contribute by way of levies, the Government has decided that their respective national organisations will be invited to furnish the bulk of nominees for the first round of appointments to the AHC Selection Committee. Thus, the Australian Apple and Pear Growers' Association will be invited to furnish nominees for three positions and the Australian Citrus Growers' Federation for one position. The Australian Horticultural Growers' Council will also be invited to provide two nominees and, in recognition of the Corporation's export focus, one nominee is to be put forward by a horticultural exporter organisation. All these organisations will be prescribed for this purpose.

It is intended that the Australian Horticultural Growers' Council, before furnishing its nominations, will be required to consult with industry organisations and to have particular regard to the views of those industries wishing to participate in the Corporation at an early stage.

Part IV of the Bill provides for the establishment and operation of product Group Selection Committees. These are to consist of the Chairperson of the Corporation Selection Committee, two Corporation members and from three to six nominated members. The number of nominated members in each case will be determined by the Corporation in consultation with the relevant industry organisations. The Bill provides for the Corporation to appoint the members (other than the Chairperson) of a product group selection committee. The nominated members are to be appointed from nominees furnished by the relevant industry organisations.

The arrangements mean that those industries which provide levy or export charge proceeds for funding the Corporation will play a major part in determining who will be on the AHC Selection Committee and on product group committees.
Cost and Accounting Matters
The Bill also puts in place provisions which deal with the manner in which financial transactions and costs are to be treated.

To facilitate financial accountability and protect the interests of participating industries, funds provided by each industry will be held by the Corporation in separate accounts. In this regard, the assets and liabilities of the Australian Apple and Pear Corporation will be transferred immediately to a separate account on commencement of the AHC's operation.

In consultation with different participating industries, the AHC will need to put in place mechanisms to ensure that the funds derived from one industry will not be used to support activities for other industries but this will not preclude agreed joint-industry funding for particular projects, should this be required. All participating industries will need to contribute to meeting the basic overheads of the AHC. The sharing of these costs will be determined by the Board of the Corporation on an equitable basis, with the composition of the costs being identified.

An important consideration that has been of particular interest to the horticultural industries is that of cost. As I have already mentioned, the corporation will be a commercially oriented organisation. Its structure will reflect industry requirements. For example, separate product group committees will only be established, where justified, in consultation with the relevant industry or industries. Similarly, the Corporation will be able to respond in terms of staffing and other resources as needs dictate. Over the longer term, the Corporation will be funded fully by industry and the consultation and accountability requirements of the Bill will ensure that proper pressures are extended for its cost efficient and effective performance.

The Commonwealth has allocated to the Corporation $5.85m over 5 years to assist it to get programs of activities under way quickly. Pending the implementation of levy arrangements for those industries wishing to participate, some $300,000 a year of this may be used to defray basic overheads, thus presenting significant savings for participating industries in the early years whilst leaving a considerable pool of funds for commercial activities.
Planning and Accountability

Provisions in Part II, Division 3 of the Bill ensure that the Corporation will carry out its functions in a business-like manner and spell out the basis for its relationship with the Minister. These require the Corporation to prepare a corporate plan with a five year horizon, to be reviewed and extended annually. The corporate plan is to define the principal objectives of the Corporation, assess the industry outlook and outline the strategies it will pursue. Before preparing or revising the corporate plan the Corporation will be required to consult with eligible bodies.

The Corporation will also be required to develop for each successive period an annual operational plan which sets out, among other things, the details of the strategies to be pursued by the Corporation in the coming year.

Both the corporate and annual operating plans are to be submitted to the Minister for approval. In this way, the accountability arrangements with the Minister will focus on the strategies and longer term performance of the Corporation and free it from the need for constant reference to the Minister for approval of individual activities proposed.

Apart from its corporate and operational planning provisions, the Bill contains a number of accountability requirements which are designed to further ensure that the AHC will carry out its operations in a businesslike manner. These requirements are covered in Part III, Division 4 of the Bill.

Not only will the Corporation be required to present an annual report covering its operations including its audited financial statements for each financial year to the Minister for tabling in the Parliament, but also to each eligible industry body. As well, the Corporation will be required to arrange with some individual, eligible industry bodies for the Chairperson to attend either their next annual conference or a meeting of their executives. For other eligible industry bodies, the Corporation will be required to convene a meeting to which their representatives would be invited to attend. At such meetings the Chairperson will be required to provide an address and to be questioned on the activities of the Corporation as covered by the Annual Report and the Corporation's intended activities for the coming year.

The horticultural sector has considerable potential to develop further, particularly in terms of exporting. This potential will be more readily realised if the sector is assisted by an appropriate organisational infrastructure. This Corporation is an important part of that infrastructure.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
HORTICULTURAL RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT CORPORATION BILL 1987

The purpose of the Bill is to provide for the establishment of a Horticultural Research and Development Corporation as part of the package of measures outlined in my second reading speech for the Australian Horticultural Corporation Bill 1987.

It has been recognised that the horticultural sector has under-invested in research and development (R&D) with continuing national programs having been few and far between. The Horticultural Research and Development Corporation (HRDC), provided for in this Bill, is designed to overcome these problems by funding more, and by better co-ordinating, horticultural R&D.
I turn now to the specific provisions of the Bill.
Objects, Functions and Powers

The objects, functions and powers of the HRDC are set out in Part II, Division 1 of the Bill. The Corporation's primary object is to improve production by, and market performance of, horticultural industries. This is to be achieved in three main ways. Firstly, by identifying areas of horticultural R&D which are relevant to the needs of these industries. Secondly, by improving the efficiency and effectiveness of horticultural R&D. And, thirdly, by encouraging the more effective use of the resources and skills available in the community, especially in the scientific community, for horticultural R&D.

The Corporation is also charged with developing awareness in the Australian horticultural industries as to the positive contribution that R&D can make to improving their efficiency and competitiveness. Industry diversity has meant that, due to the limited scope of their operations, smaller individual industries have had difficulties in identifying their potential for research. The Corporation will, in time, become a source of information for these industries with respect to the advantages that might exist for them.

The functions of the Corporation detailed by the Bill include evaluation of R&D needs, formulation of annual and longer term R&D plans and, of course, funding the carrying out by others, or, if appropriate, by itself carrying out, relevant R&D activities.

Subject to certain restrictions, the Corporation is to be empowered to do all things that are necessary to perform its functions. This includes fee-for-service charging, employing staff and accepting contributions. Importantly, as a body corporate, it will be able to make applications for, and deal with patents, participate in joint ventures and enter into agreements for the carrying out of R&D projects by other persons.
Membership and Selection

Part II, Division 2 of the Bill provides the composition of the Board of the Corporation. The nine member Board will consist of an independent Chairperson, one government member, the Executive Director and six other members. The six other members are to be selected on the basis of expertise in one or more fields such as growing or processing horticultural products, horticultural R&D or other R&D, administration or marketing. These members are to be nominated by a Selection Committee as provided for in Part III of the Bill.

Members, other than the Corporation-appointed Executive Director, will be appointed by the Minister on a part-time basis; except for the government member, appointments will be for periods of up to three years, but members will be eligible for re-appointment. Under this provision, membership terms can be staggered to ensure that the Corporation always has some members with experience of its activities and knowledge of current issues.

Part III of the Bill provides for the establishment of the Corporation Selection Committee. The function of that Committee will be to identify and nominate persons for appointment by the Minister of Corporation members based on one or more fields of expertise defined by the Bill.

The Committee will consist of seven members. Four members, including the Chairperson will be drawn from the existing Rural Industries Research Councils Selection Committee. The other three members will be nominated by eligible industry bodies for appointment by the Minister.

For the first round of appointments, the Government has decided that as the apple and pear industry is the only industry for which levies will be collected for the HRDC from its outset, and as the citrus industry is, so far, the only industry which has given a firm commitment to participate and contribute by way of levies, their respective national organisations will be invited to furnish one nominee each. The Australian Horticultural Growers' Council will be invited to provide the other nominee. It is intended that the Council will be required to consult with industry organisations before furnishing its nominee and to have particular regard to the views of those industries wishing to participate at an early stage.
As other industries decide to participate in the arrangements they will become eligible industries and will have a say in the nomination process.
Finance
Part II, Division 7 of the Bill deals with financial accounting and auditing aspects of the Corporation's activities. A number of these matters warrant brief mention.

The Corporation is to receive funds from industries through levy and export charge collections. As occurs with other Rural Industries Research Councils, the levies and charges collected for the Corporation will attract a matching dollar for dollar contribution from the Commonwealth of up to 0.5 per cent of the particular industry's gross value of production.

However, as the dispersed nature or other factors in some industries within the horticultural sector can result in their not being able to develop adequate levy arrangements, the Government is prepared to vary these matching arrangements. This variation provides for the matching, by Government, of eligible voluntary contributions made in respect of products not subject to levy but, as before, within the ceiling of the 0.5 per cent of the gross value of production of the particular industry. Such matching will be subject to appropriate guidelines to be issued by way of ministerial orders in due course.

It is also important to note that, in order to assist the Corporation to get programs under way quickly, the Government has allocated $1.25 million for use by the Corporation over the first five years of its operation. This funding is not dependent on corresponding industry contributions being made during that period but, as such contributions are made, normal Commonwealth matching will be drawn from this allocation.

Provision has also been made for contribution by different industries to be held in separate accounts. This will result in the identification of each industry's expenditure on R&D activities. However, such an accounting practice will not preclude cross-industry funding of projects, where this is considered appropriate by the Corporation and the industries involved.
Planning and Accountability

Provisions in Part III, Division 3 ensure that the Corporation maintains a high level of control and direction in the discharge of its functions. It will be required to develop a corporate R&D plan with a 5 year horizon and an annual R&D program. Both the plan and the program are to be reviewed and revised annually, following consultation with relevant Australian horticultural industries.

While the corporate plan will set out the longer term strategies and policies that the Corporation intends to adopt in order to achieve its objectives, the annual programs will provide yearly operational schedules for the Corporation by specifying and describing the projects to be carried out, or that may be considered for funding, in the coming year. The annual programs will also provide cost estimates of each project as well as the total anticipated expenditure of the Corporation for the year.

Apart from its corporate and operational planning provisions, the Bill contains a number of accountability requirements which are designed to further ensure that the Corporation will carry out its operations in a business-like manner. These requirements are covered in Part III, Division 4 of the Bill.
The Bill's annual report and accountability to industry provisions are the same as those outlined in my second reading speech for the Australian Horticultural Corporation Bill.

The horticultural industries, which have considerable scope to develop their full potential, will be assisted in realising this by a well organised infrastructure for horticultural R&D. The activities of this Corporation will make significant complementary contributions to those of the other two bodies being established.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
HORTICULTURAL POLICY COUNCIL BILL 1987

The purpose of this Bill is to provide for the establishment of a Horticultural Policy Council as part of the package of measures outlined in my Second Reading Speech for the Australian Horticultural Corporation Bill 1987.

The Government perceives that there is a need to bring together representatives of the widely dispersed, fragmented and diverse horticultural sector into a single body with capacity to present to Government a total sectoral perspective on policy issues. That body, the Council, will be able to thoroughly research and examine issues and areas of concern to the sector.
I turn now to the specific provisions of the Bill.
Objects, Functions and Powers

The objects, functions and powers are set out in Part II of the Bill. The object of the Council is to facilitate development of policy through co-ordinated participation of the horticultural sector in the policy formulation process. The Bill provides the Council with powers necessary to perform its functions, which in the main are:
to examine, on its own initiative, issues affecting the horticultural sector and report to the Minister;
to examine matters relevant to horticulture referred to it by the Minister; and
to develop recommendations, guidelines and plans for measures designed to safeguard or further the interests of horticulture
Organisational Structure

Part III of the Bill provides the composition of the Council. Its membership of 15 will consist of an independent Chairperson, five members representing horticultural growers and producers, two members representing processors, one member representing persons engaged in horticultural marketing, two members representing employees, two members representing the Australian Agricultural Council and the Chairpersons of the Australian Horticultural Corporation and the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation respectively. All members will be appointed by the Minister, but members, other than the Council's Chairperson and the Chairpersons of the two Corporations, will be nominated for appointment by relevant bodies, which will be prescribed by regulation.

Also, by regulation, the Bill enables the number and composition of the Council's membership to be varied. This provision has been included so that changing circumstances in the organisational structure of the horticultural sector may be reflected in the representation on the Council as and when the need arises. I should also mention that it will be the Government's policy for variation to be made only after consultation with the Council. I believe it to be essential to keep the Council to a manageable size and this will be borne in mind in any consideration to vary the Council's membership.
Part IV of the Bill provides the Council with the power and scope to establish and abolish executive or other committees and working groups.

With regard to committees, it is intended that they be established to consider specific issues or areas of concern. The composition of such committees may be made up entirely of Council members or partly of members and other persons.

A working group established by the Council may consist entirely of persons other than Council members, or may be composed of Council members and other persons. Membership of a working group would, in general, be based on expertise rather than representation and it would be expected that the issues being examined by a working group would have a high degree of technical content.

The consultancy provisions of Part V of the Bill complement the provisions for committees and working groups of the Council. They enable the Council to engage experts who may work on their own or be part of a committee or working group. It will be up to the Council to determine the terms and conditions under which consultants may be engaged.
Administrative Arrangements
Part V of the Bill also makes provision for the Council to be staffed by a permanent secretariat. Staff of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy will fulfil this function.
The Government is providing $1.9 million to cover the Council's costs over 5 years. Continuation and subsequent funding of the Council will be reviewed in the fifth year of its operation.

The Bill makes annual report provisions consistent with those applied to other such Commonwealth statutory bodies. To this end, the Bill specifies that the Council is to prepare and submit an annual report each year to the Minister for tabling in the Parliament.

The Government considers that the Horticultural Policy Council will provide an important link between industry and the Government in the development of national policies relevant to the horticultural sector.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
HORTICULTURAL LEVY BILL 1987

The purposes of this Bill and three related Bills-namely, the Horticultural Levy Collection Bill 1987, the Horticultural Export Charge Bill 1987 and the Horticultural Export Charge Collection Bill 1987-are to provide for the imposition and collection of levies on horticultural products produced and sold in Australia and for charges on exports of horticultural products.

They provide the means of financing, in the longer term, the activities of the Australian Horticultural Corporation and, apart from Commonwealth matching moneys, the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation.

As the Australian Horticultural Corporation's role will include the servicing of the apple and pear growing industry, the current levies on its products will be imposed and collected under the new Levy Bills; and the existing apple and pear levy legislation will be repealed. The operative rates of levy for apples and pears will be set by regulation, while the rates for other horticultural products will be included in regulations as respective horticultural industries decide to participate in the activities of either or both Corporations and agree on levy arrangements to help finance marketing and research activities.

Levy will be payable by the producer of a horticultural product which is covered by the appropriate regulations while the export charge is to be payable by the owner of the product at the time of export. Provision has been made in the Levy and Export Charge Bills for determination of maximum rates of levy and charge. The maximum rates do, of course, vary from product to product.

In order to limit administrative costs or for policy reasons, certain exemptions from levy will be permitted under regulations; for example, these may be in situations where sales by individual growers are relatively small or where small volumes of horticultural products are retailed direct by growers at the orchard gate or, in relation to products used directly by the grower for juicing or processing purposes, if the relevant annual quantities do not exceed a maximum level as set down in regulations.

There are already levies on apples and pears and the continuing application of these levies is expected to provide annual funds to the Australian Horticultural Corporation and the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation combined of around $1.3 m. Total receipts of horticultural levies to fund the two Corporations will rise as the number of industry sectors participating in the marketing and research activities increases.

The Commonwealth will match expenditure of the industry moneys-based on levies, export charges and eligible voluntary contributions, identified for the Research and Development Corporation-dollar for dollar, up to a limit of 0.5 per cent of the average annual gross value of production of groups of products, the groupings to be specified by regulation. The extent of the Commonwealth contribution to research will thus depend on the number of industries which agree to participate and the rates at which the individual industries are prepared to fund Corporation research activities.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
HORTICULTURAL LEVY COLLECTION BILL 1987
The Bill is complementary to the Horticultural Levy Bill, which I have just introduced. Its purpose is to make provision for the efficient and effective collection of the levies imposed by that Bill.

Essentially, liability for the levies will rest with the growers or other producers of the relevant horticultural products. However, in order to reduce greatly the number of collection points and thus the costs of administering the collection of the levies, the responsibility for their payment to the Commonwealth will, for the most part, be placed with wholesalers, selling agents and processors. The Collection Bill provides for these persons to be given the authority in law to recover the levy payment from their supplying growers.
The Bill also provides for dates on which levies become due for payment to be set by regulation.

Collection of existing levies on apples and pears will continue, with the rates set by regulation under the Horticultural Levy Act. Total amounts of levies to be collected will rise over the next few years as the number of participating industries increases.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
HORTICULTURAL EXPORT CHARGE BILL 1987

This Bill is a companion to the Horticultural Levy Bill, 1987 dealt with earlier. Whereas the purpose of that Bill is to impose levies on the production of prescribed horticultural products, this one authorises charges to be imposed on the exports of prescribed horticultural products. The funds raised by both Bills are to provide the means of financing, in the longer term, the activities of the Australian Horticultural Corporation and, apart from Commonwealth matching money, the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation.

The general principles of the Charge Bill mirror those of the Horticultural Levy Bill. The main difference is that the export charge is imposed on the owner at the time of export rather than on the producer.

There are already export charges on apples and pears and these will be continued under the new legislation with the rates set by regulation; the existing apple and pear charge legislation will be repealed. The rates of charge for other horticultural products will be included in regulations as respective horticultural industries decide to participate in the activities of either or both Corporations and agree on the charge arrangements to help finance marketing and research activities.
Provision has been made for determination of maximum rates of charge. The maximum rates do, of course, vary from product to product.

Continuation of the current charges on apples and pears is expected to yield an annual income of around $300,000. Total receipts from charges to fund the Australian Horticultural Corporation and the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation will rise as the number of industries participating in this way in the marketing and research activities increases.

The Commonwealth will match expenditure of the industry moneys-based on levies, export charges and eligible voluntary contributions, identified for the Research and Development Corporation-dollar for dollar, up to a limit of 0.5% of the average annual gross value of production of groups of products, the groupings to be specified by regulation. The extend of the Commonwealth contribution to research will thus depend on the number of industries which agree to participate and the rates at which the individual industries are prepared to fund Corporation research activities.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
HORTICULTURAL EXPORT CHARGE COLLECTION BILL 1987

The Bill is complementary to the Horticultural Export Charge Bill, which I have just introduced. Its purpose is to make provision for the efficient and effective collection of the charges imposed by that Bill.

Essentially, liability for the charges will rest with the owner of the relevant horticultural products when exported. However, in order to facilitate collection when an exporting agent exports on behalf of another person who may reside overseas, the responsibility for payment of the charge to the Commonwealth will be placed with the agent. This Collection Bill provides for the agent to be given the authority in law to recover the charge payment from moneys received on behalf of the owner.
The Bill also provides for dates on which charges become due for payment to be set by regulation.

Collection of existing charges on apples and pears will continue, with the rates set by regulation under the Horticultural Export Charge Act. Total amounts of charges to be collected will rise over the next few years as the number of participating industries increases.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
AUSTRALIAN HORTICULTURAL CORPORATION (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1987

The purpose of this Bill is to make provisions for arrangements to bring the apple and pear industry within the ambit of the new Australian Horticultural Corporation as outlined in my Second Reading Speech in relation to that body.

While the Australian Horticultural Corporation Bill provides for the repeal of the principal and amending Australian Apple and Pear Corporation Acts, this Bill deals with provisions for such things as transfer of assets and liabilities from the Australian Apple and Pear Corporation, when abolished, to the new Corporation. The Bill also deals with consequential amendments to those Apple and Pear Acts which will continue in existence under the new arrangements.
I turn now to the specific provisions of the Bill.

The provisions for the administrative and organisational arrangements, which are necessary on abolition of the Australian Apple and Pear Corporation, are set out in Part II of the Bill. These cover the transfer of staff, assets and liabilities from the abolished to the new Corporation. In particular, it provides for the staff of the abolished Corporation to be transferred to the new Corporation on terms and conditions which applied immediately prior to the change over. Another provision of this Part requires the new Corporation to prepare the report and financial statements covering the period of operation of the abolished Corporation, from the time of its last report to the time of its abolition.

Part III of the Bill provides amendments to the Apple and Pear Export Underwriting Act 1981 by substituting the name of the abolished Corporation with that of the new Corporation in the relevant provisions.

Parts IV and V of the Bill provide amendments to the current Apple and Pear Export Charge and Levy Acts so as to limit their application up to the day immediately prior to the new Horticultural Levy and Export Charge Acts coming into effect. This prevents product from being subject to double levies or charges.
Finally, Part VI of the Bill provides for the repeal of the Apple and Pear Stabilisation Acts and associated amendment Acts, the operation of which has been completed.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.

DEBATE.TITLE: FAMILY LAW AMENDMENT BILL 1987 (No. 2)FAMILY COURT OF AUSTRALIA (ADDITIONAL JURISDICTION AND EXERCISE OF POWERS) BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bills received from the House of Representatives.
That the Bills may proceed without formalities, may be considered together and be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
FAMILY LAW AMENDMENT BILL 1987

For 11 years the Commonwealth and the States have been negotiating for a reference of powers from the States in respect of family law matters. Last year four States, New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia and Tasmania, enacted legislation referring to the Commonwealth powers over the maintenance, custody and guardianship of, and access to, all children and for the payment of expenses in relation to children and child bearing. The references of power do not extend to children who are the subject of orders under State welfare laws.

The amendments being introduced in this Bill give effect to those references of powers. This means that in those States, and the Australian Capital Territory, Northern Territory and Norfolk Island, where the Family Law Act 1975 also has application, all children will be subject to the same law and the procedures under the Family Law Act, including the provisions for counselling and conciliation, will be available in disputes concerning ex-nuptial children.

Queensland and Western Australia will be outside this uniform scheme. The provisions in this Bill applying the Act to ex-nuptial children will not extend to Queensland or Western Australia. In Western Australia, the State family court has jurisdiction to deal with all of the children in a family unit. It applies, as appropriate, the Family Law Act and the State law. In Queensland, however, it will still be necessary to bring proceedings in the State courts in respect of children who are not children of a marriage and in the Family Court in respect of children who are children of a marriage. The Bill seeks to avoid jurisdictional problems in some of these cases by giving the Family Court of Australia jurisdiction in matters concerning ex-nuptial children where the parties to the proceedings are residents of different States. In doing so, the Bill relies on the constitutional power in section 75 (iv) of the Constitution. In exercising jurisdiction in such a case, the court would apply the relevant law of the non-referring State to those cases not covered by the Family Law Act as amended.

The Commonwealth is still hopeful that Queensland and Western Australia will refer similar powers to the Commonwealth. Alternatively, and the Bill provides for this, those States may adopt the provisions of this Bill in respect of their ex-nuptial children to ensure that such children are not disadvantaged compared with children in the referring States and the Territories.

In the present Act the provisions relating to children are scattered throughout a number of parts of the Act. The opportunity has been taken to restructure the Act to bring most of the provisions relating to children together in the one part, new part VII. That new part will operate in general terms in the referring States, the Australian Capital Territory, the Northern Territory and Norfolk Island, but with no alteration to the substantive law in the non-referring states.
Amendments to the Law

The amendments in the Bill will change the present law on guardianship, custody and access in two ways. First, in the referring States and the Territories the provisions of the Family Law Act will apply to ex-nuptial children in the same way as those provisions now apply to children of a marriage. In the four referring States and the Territories there will be a uniform law for the guardianship and custody of all children. At present the parents of an ex-nuptial child have, under State and Territory law, varying status as guardians and custodians and these may differ from the guardianship and custody rights of parties to a marriage in respect of children of the marriage. This can create complex legal problems and parents of ex-nuptial children may be uncertain of their rights and responsibilities, particularly if one or both parents move interstate. The Bill provides that both parents of a child should, until a court orders to the contrary or the parents file a child welfare agreement in the court, be a guardian and share custody. Secondly, the Bill provides for the registration of enforceable agreements between the parents in respect of the custody, guardianship or welfare of, or access to, a child. The new procedure will simply involve the parents in filing the agreement at the court registry thus removing the need for expensive court hearings.

The Bill introduces Federal laws in the area of child bearing expenses. The States and Territories have long provided, not uniformly, for such expenses. It also provides for presumptions of parentage and paternity for the purpose of determination of these issues under the Family Law Act, thereby replacing for those purposes the operation of the common law presumptions and the non-uniform statutory presumptions that apply under State and Territory status of children laws.

The Bill makes substantial changes to the Family Law Act with respect to the maintenance of children. The Government's proposals in respect of maintenance were spelt out in a ministerial statement to the Parliament by the Minister for Social Security on 24 March 1987. The Government will be introducing separate legislation to establish the Child Support Agency in accordance with that statement.

This Bill effects a number of changes to the Family Law Act that were foreshadowed in that statement. In particular, the Bill seeks to ensure that children will receive a proper level of financial support from the income, earning capacity, property and financial resources of both their parents and that both parents share equitably in the support of their children. The Bill provides that the duty of parents to maintain a child takes priority over all commitments of the parent other than commitments enabling the parent to support himself or herself or any other person or child that the parent has a duty to maintain.

In developing its proposals for child maintenance, the Government has been concerned at the very high level of social security payments being made to divorced parties who have not made adequate provision for spousal maintenance in the course of conclusion of their financial arrangements. Section 75 (2) (f) has facilitated the drain on the revenue by allowing courts to take into account in both spousal and child maintenance proceedings the eligibility of either party to a marriage to a pension, benefit or allowance.
This Bill provides that in any future proceedings for spousal or child maintenance the court must disregard the eligibility for an income tested pension of an applicant for maintenance.

The Bill will still leave room for parties to reach their own agreements on child maintenance and spousal maintenance. Those agreements may be enforced so long as the effect of the agreements is not to cast a burden on the revenue by maintenance being so designed as to qualify the party concerned for an income tested pension or benefit.

The Bill also inserts new provisions to enable the income testing, for social security purposes, of maintenance received other than by way of periodic sum. These provisions require the court, in ordering the payment of a lump sum or the transfer of property in satisfaction of maintenance, to specify the proportion of the payment or the value of the portion of the property which is attributable to the provision for maintenance of the party to the marriage. A similar requirement exists in relation to maintenance agreements.

In his statement, the Minister for Social Security said that the Government would consider changes to access laws and the enforcement of access orders after it received the reports to be made by the Family Law Council on access and the Law Reform Commission on contempt of court. Those reports have now been tabled in the Parliament and the Government will be assessing the public reaction to the reports. Further amendments may be made to the Family Law Act in the light of that consideration and of the Government's consideration of the separate report on matrimonial property by the Law Reform Commission.
Financial Impact Statement

Implementation of the references of powers will result in the transfer of work from Senate welfare departments and State courts to the counselling, conciliation and judicial services of the Family Court of Australia. The effect will be to transfer most jurisdiction in custody and guardianship cases affecting ex-nuptial children in the referring States from the State courts to the Family Court. There is expected to be some transfer of maintenance cases affecting ex-nuptial children from State magistrates courts to the Family Court. It is difficult to predict the extent of the transferred work, but potentially this could increase the cost of the operation of the Family Court in a full year by some $3.5m. To the extent to which matters now coming before State courts would come before the Family Court there would be a corresponding decrease in the work load of the State courts.

The amendments to be made by the Bill that relate to the child support scheme may result in increased litigation in the Family Court in maintenance matters. The extent to which this may occur is, however, impossible to predict, given the number of factors that are likely to influence decisions to litigate maintenance applications.
I commend the Bill to the Senate. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
FAMILY COURT OF AUSTRALIA (ADDITIONAL JURISDICTION AND EXERCISE OF POWERS) BILL 1987

The Family Court of Australia (Additional Jurisdiction and Exercise of Powers) Bill 1987 marks a major development in the administration of family law in Australia. The Government recognises that the specialist jurisdiction of the Family Court has created problems for judges and that the volume of routine and minor contested matters has produced delays. In this Bill the Government addresses these problems by extending the jurisdiction of the Family Court of Australia and introducing proposals to provide for speedier resolution of proceedings in routine and minor contested matters.
The proposals embodied in the Bill have been developed having regard to-

the views expressed by the Constitutional Commission Advisory Committee on the Australian Judicial System that the jurisdiction of the Family Court be extended so as to broaden the work of the Family Court judges and help enhance the standing of the Court;
that Committee's further view that a large number of applications which, being essentially of a routine kind and uncontested, do not warrant the attention of a superior court;

the need to reduce delays in defended proceedings in the Family Court by devolving some of the less complex contested and other matters now handled by judges to court officers and by providing additional jurisdiction for State courts of summary jurisdiction.

For some time now the Government has been concerned about the difficulty of recruiting judges to the Family Court. The narrowness of the jurisdiction exercised by judges of the Family Court has reduced its attractiveness to a wide range of practitioners. By broadening the jurisdiction of Family Court judges, appointments to the Family Court will be more attractive. It will also give existing judges some relief from the burdens of the highly emotive family law jurisdiction.

The Bill will extend the Family Court jurisdiction to proceedings in bankruptcy, income tax appeals, consumer protection provisions of the Trade Practices Act and proceedings under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act. It does not permit proceedings in these matters to be filed directly in the Family Court. Instead, it provides for proceedings which have been filed in the Federal Court of Australia to be transferred to the Family Court. This may be done at the request of the parties or by the Federal Court on its own initiative. There is to be consultation between the chief judges of the two courts in respect of the transfer of proceedings. These consultations will ensure that appropriate Family Court judges are available to deal with transferred matters and that these matters will not be delayed as a consequence of transfer.

The transfer of matters will not affect the basis upon which proceedings are conducted. An identical provision in the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977, the Bankruptcy Act 1966, the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 and the Trade Practices Act 1974 ensures that the practices and procedures applicable in proceedings in the Federal Court will apply in transferred proceedings in the Family Court.

Registrars of the Family Court currently exercise jurisdiction under delegation from the judges in respect of many procedural matters and consent orders. They may not be delegated powers to deal with undefended divorces and to approve maintenance agreements under section 87 of the Act.

The Bill provides for the creation of offices of judicial registrars to exercise jurisdiction under delegation from the judges. These offices will be similar to the office of master attached to State Supreme Courts. The Bill also removes the present limitations on the powers of the judges to delegate functions to registrars.

The office of master is a concept well established in State superior courts. Masters undertake much minor and undefended work, relieving the judges of these more routine matters. The State experience is that the appointment of masters enables the numbers of the judges of such courts to be minimised. It is expected that the appointment of judicial registrars in the Family Court, together with the possibility of more matters being delegated to registrars, will leave the judges free to concentrate on the major matters and to accept additional jurisdiction.

State courts of summary jurisdiction at present exercise limited family law jurisdiction. Apart from maintenance and minor property matters, however, that jurisdiction can only be exercised with the consent of the parties. Courts of summary jurisdiction are not presently able to deal with divorce applications. After discussing this matter with State Attorneys-General the Attorney-General proposes that the jurisdiction of courts of summary jurisdiction in family law matters be extended.

The Bill gives courts of summary jurisdiction jurisdiction in respect of undefended applications for dissolution where the parties, for their own convenience, request that the application be transferred from the Family Court to a specified court of summary jurisdiction. Further, the monetary limit on the jurisdiction of these courts in property matters (unless the parties consent) has been substantially increased so that it will equal the monetary limit in the jurisdiction of those courts under State law in actions for the recovery of debts. It is expected that in country areas the extended jurisdiction for courts of summary jurisdiction will provide a less expensive and more timely resolution of family proceedings for the parties and their legal representatives.
Financial Impact Statement

The proposals for the transfer of proceedings from the Federal Court to the Family Court are substantially revenue neutral. Some additional expenditure will be involved in payments to the States in respect of additional jurisdiction conferred on courts of summary jurisdiction, which will be partly set off by the reduced work load of the registries of the Family Court. The additional cost will depend upon the number of matters brought in courts of summary jurisdiction and this cannot be predicted. Additional expenditure may be in the order of $250,000 in a full year.
I commend the Bill to the Senate. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Senator Tambling) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: MANAGEMENT AND INVESTMENT COMPANIES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill will amend both the Management and Investment Companies Act 1983 and the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 by permitting a management and investment company (MIC) to raise non-tax concessional capital in conjunction with tax concessional capital as well as enabling a MIC to exit the program without triggering the tax clawback arrangements by surrendering its licence. The proposed amendments follow the Government's consideration of the Bureau of Industry Economics' (BIE) review of the MIC program.

The MIC program commenced in early 1984 with the objectives of encouraging the development of a viable private sector venture capital market and to provide management support and equity capital to young export oriented businesses using innovative technology and having the potential for rapid growth.
This followed the report Developing High Technology Enterprises for Australia, prepared by a committee of the Australian Academy of Technological Sciences, chaired by Sir Frank Espie.

The Espie report found that the lack of risk capital and a widespread lack of management and commercial skills within new high technology enterprises were obstacles to the development of those enterprises.
Since the inception of the MIC program there has been a rapid increase in the availability of venture capital and continued strong growth is expected.

The BIE in its review estimated that at 30 June 1983 only some $2m of venture capital had been available; by 31 March 1987 this had increased to approximately $310m with a further projected increase to about $570m for 31 March 1988.

This rapid expansion in the availability of venture capital is indeed significant, and represents not only the activities of the MICs but also reflects growth in the availability of venture capital outside the MIC program.

To 30 September 1987 the MICs have invested and committed almost $140m in 129 businesses across a range of industries, including computer hardware and software, medical equipment and products, scientific and technical services and industrial products and machinery.
This is a clear indication that the program has gone a good deal of the way towards demonstrating the viability of a venture capital market.

However, despite the increased availability of venture capital, the government remains unconvinced as to the durability of the venture capital market if the MIC program were to be terminated at this time.

The danger being that premature termination of the program would not only place the MICs and their investee businesses at risk but could also lead to a lack of confidence in the venture capital market as a whole.
The Government has therefore, decided to continue the MIC program until at least 30 June 1989.
In reaching this decision the government has taken a number of factors into consideration which include the following:
Firstly, many of the new non-MICs are still a good deal smaller than the MICs and with only a limited amount of capital available.

Secondly, the MICs, unlike the non-MICs, focus their investments primarily at the more risky start-up and early growth stages of business development, with emphasis upon technology-based and export oriented industries.
Thirdly, MICs appear to devote more time towards providing management support than the non-MICs.

It was also felt that while financial deregulation had resulted in greater flexibility and competition within the financial system, this had not yet, to any great extent, flowed over into the high risk venture capital market, but had mainly benefited the more traditional areas of financial activity.
The Government believes that the key to the long term viability of the venture capital market lies with its ability to attract funds from the major financial institutions.

The institutions have begun to show an increased interest in venture capital but it is still very tentative. Indications are that institutional investors are reluctant to provide ongoing investment in venture capital as they regard the market as still being immature.

The financial institutions are looking for an established track record in portfolio management of venture capital investments. The MICs with their spread of investments across the venture capital spectrum are well placed to show that such a track record can be achieved.

An integral part of the MIC program is the 100 per cent tax concession which is provided in order to encourage investment in the MICs. The government has therefore decided to refer the program to the review of business taxation announced by the Treasurer in his recent Budget Speech.

The future of the program beyond 30 June 1989 will be determined in the context of the review's findings, with due regard being paid to the program's objective of encouraging the development of a viable private sector venture capital market and assurance as to the long term viability of that market.
The Government has decided that the upper limit of $20m per annum as the cost to revenue of the program will be retained for the life of the program.
On the basis of a marginal tax rate of around 50c in the dollar, the $20m of revenue forgone will result in about $40m of tax concessional capital being available to the MICs per annum.
In addition to the continuation of the MIC program the Government has recognised the need for a suitable mechanism by which MICs could exit the program.
This is required so that individual MICs are allowed to voluntarily exit the program in an orderly and non prejudicial fashion.
The raising of non-tax concession capital provides such a mechanism.

At the moment MICs can raise only tax concessional capital. By allowing MICs to raise non-tax concessional capital in conjunction with tax concessional capital they will become less reliant upon the tax concession in order to attract funds, assisting in an orderly exit from the program.

Apart from providing a suitable exiting mechanism, the raising of non-tax concessional capital will also increase the amount of venture capital available to these young innovative businesses without any additional cost to revenue.

In order for the exiting mechanism to function, MICs must be able to voluntarily surrender licences without triggering the tax clawback provisions. To do otherwise would be prejudicial to interests of both the individual investors in the MICs and the businesses in which MICs have invested.

The clawback provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act operate to withdraw the 100 per cent tax concession for shares in a MIC which are disposed of within four years of the MIC becoming licensed or the shares being paid up, whichever is the later event.
The clawback provisions are designed to encourage patient investment in the MICs while at the same time preventing abuses of the tax concession by investors.

This Bill proposes to amend both the MIC Act and the Income Tax Assessment Act to enable a MIC to voluntarily surrender its licence without triggering the clawback provisions provided investors do not dispose of their shares in that MIC within the statutory four-year period.
The Bill also proposes a number of minor amendments to the MIC Act.
These amendments are necessary to clarify certain provisions, to remove a number of unnecessary restrictions and to resolve other administrative difficulties.
