DEBATE.TITLE: APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL 1987-88[COGNATE BILLS:APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 1) 1987-88APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 2) 1987-88]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 21 October, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the Senate is debating the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill cognately with Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1987-88 and Appropriation Bill (No. 2) 1987-88. The Budget for 1987-88 presented by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) bore the hallmarks of a skilled, albeit shortsighted, political craftsman. Its centrepiece, which was an allegedly balanced Budget outcome, captured so much media attention that the more important questions about its underlying economic strategy were virtually ignored by media commentators. Essentially, it was a Budget directed towards the financial markets. The intention was to talk up the exchange rate and to talk down interest rates. Mr Deputy President, I am advised that at this stage it would be appropriate for me to foreshadow that, in respect of Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1987-88, I shall move the following amendment:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add:
``, but the Senate is of the opinion that:
(1) this Bill is part of a continuing pattern of failure by the Hawke Government to face up to the need for adequate and timely adjustment of the economy;
(2) this failure by the Hawke Government has heightened Australia's vulnerability to changes in world economic conditions at this time of crisis on world financial markets;

(3) because the Government has squandered time and resources while persistently running Australia into massive debt, our national economic options are now so narrowly limited as to largely deprive us of independent options; and

(4) the Government no longer has the scope to protect jobs, to stop the prospective rise in unemployment, to stem the continuing rise in numbers of Australians living in poverty or to protect the position of families more generally;

and therefore calls on the Government to revise its fiscal, labour market, taxation and other micro-economic policies with a view to providing a more appropriate economic framework to meet our current economic and social dangers''.

Less than a week after the delivery of the Budget its reception was transformed by Senator Walsh's extraordinary attack on it and, by implication, on the Treasurer. The Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) implied at that time, on the weekend following the delivery of the Budget, amongst other things, that the Government lacked the `political courage' to bite into around 200 social welfare and other programs that, again in his words, `are not justified on social, equity or economic efficiency grounds'. The Minister for Finance was thereby criticising both the rhetoric and the substance of the Hawke-Keating Budget. In doing so he was seeking to distance himself from it and from them.

Just how far wide of the mark that budgetary strategy was has since been frighteningly illustrated. On 20 October, four weeks ago tomorrow, Australian stock markets, in company with stock markets all around the world, crashed. Since that time international foreign exchange markets and, of course, our own foreign exchange market along with them, have brought about a major downgrading of the central reserve and transactions currency of the world, the United States dollar, and, of course, an even sharper decline in the value of our own dollar. With that initial crash and with the events which have followed it we have seen the Budget economic strategy rendered irrelevant. Although, of course, as the Government does not cease to remind us, it is still too early to assess the full and detailed consequences of that share market collapse and that foreign exchange market collapse, it is already clear that the optimistic Treasury economic forecasts which supported the budgetary strategy have been simply blown away.

In his public responses to these events, Senator Walsh-I must say among whose more acceptable traits is a streak of economic rationalism almost unique among his ministerial colleagues-has again carefully and deliberately moved to distance himself from the Treasurer's attempts to salvage the Government's discredited policies. The irrelevancy of that strategy as laid down in the Budget in the face of a collapsing share market and a collapsing foreign exchange market, with all the attendant economic uncertainty which those events imply for the future, is already self-evident. The important question now is how the budgetary strategy and, indeed, the Government's economic strategy more generally, should be recast in order to tackle Australia's economic problems which until now the Treasurer has sought to gloss over in what, I think, can only be called his softly, softly approach to the Lodge.

Part of the answer as to how that recasting of policies is to be attained is given in the Budget Papers themselves. I refer to page 7 of Budget Paper No. 1, that is, Statement No. 2. The Treasury purports to be the author of this particular Statement of the Budget, although I think these days the Treasurer and his private office staff go over it with rather a finer tooth comb than they once did. The Treasury states:
The current account deficit, although significantly reduced, remains unsustainably high.
That was written towards the end of August or early September, approximately six weeks before the events to which I have just been referring. The Treasury continues:

Our large overseas debt is continuing to grow, although at a slower rate. Appropriate macroeconomic policies remain central to the adjustment process, and there is a need to complement these with an enhanced effort on a range of microeconomic policies. This is desirable to speed the adjustment process and, more generally, to improve the flexibility and adaptability of the Australian economy . . .

Of course, so it is. That concise summary of the problems and constraints facing Australia's economic policy-makers is, in itself, unchallengeable. It states the problem and it points unmistakeably to the necessary corrective fiscal policy in this case, but also it hints at microeconomic policy, adjustments that are required. That was a statement drawn from the commencement of Statement No. 2. Let us now turn to page 52 of that Statement where the Treasury again says, and here I think the blue pencil of the Treasurer's office is rather more in evidence:

The continued implementation of policies which consistently put runs on the board-particularly in terms of downward trends in inflation and in the current account deficit-without driving the economy through the floor, can be expected to produce an acceptable rate of adjustment.

We should perhaps bear in mind those words, `particularly in terms of downward trends in inflation and in the current account deficit' of the balance of payments. As one senior economic journalist has put it, those words of the Treasury or, I think more accurately, the Treasurer's office, are doubletalk for `She'll be right, mate'. We have here a totally internally inconsistent analysis but one which effectively muddied the waters at the time it was first brought down. An economically robust analysis of the current situation and its inherent dangers obscured the fact that politically difficult but economically necessary responses had been sidestepped in the Budget itself. That is why Senator Walsh on two occasions now has taken the opportunity to part company publicly with the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer. His own general policy prescriptions are in conflict with those of his Government and his colleagues in that Government. They are unacceptable to the Treasurer and the Prime Minister because they flow consistently from the economic problems that he identifies.

I will quote from a statement by Senator Walsh on 7 August this year, just five weeks before the Budget was brought down but, of course, during the middle of Cabinet discussions as to the nature of that Budget. In a speech which began with much the same view as the Treasury about the nature and severity of Australia's economic problems Senator Walsh pointed out that Australia had only three economic policy choices. Firstly, there was what he called the `draconian' choice, which was to stabilise the foreign debt by imposing on ourselves a catastrophic depression of infinite duration and frightening social consequences. Secondly, there was what he called the `irresponsible' choice, which was to ignore the problem until, as he put it, the International Monetary Fund imposed a solution on us. Thirdly, there was what he called the `sensible' choice, which was to stabilise and, in time, reverse our foreign debt position as a proportion of gross domestic product by a combination of consumption restraint, economic restructuring and productivity growth. From his immediate post-Budget comments and subsequent responses in the Parliament to the stock market and foreign exchange market collapses, the Minister for Finance clearly thinks that the 1987-88 Budget strategy represents the irresponsible choice. I would have to say that in that assessment at least it is impossible not to agree with him.

The economic strategy of this Government has had two main themes. The first has focused on the private tradeable goods and services sector, which, according to the strategy, is expected to respond to a recent improvement in our international competitiveness, mainly achieved by a massive fall in the value of our currency vis-a-vis those of other countries, by displacing; imports and increasing exports of manufactured items and, in some cases-for example, tourism-services. The second prong of the adjustment process has pointed to constraining the growth of domestic demand. To that end, private and public consumption expenditure was to be reduced-so ran the theory. Certainly there was some success in reducing the growth of private consumption, but there was very little success-in fact, almost no success-in reducing the growth of public sector consumption, government consumption. That reduction in public and private consumption objective was directed to increasing domestic savings, and therefore, in turn, reducing imports and the current account deficit in the balance of payments.

But the contentious question in this strategy is: How much can or should the pace of adjustment be forced? The answer emerges simply from examining the extent of the problem. The current account deficit in the balance of payments rose strongly-as the Government never ceases to point out-during the early 1980s. What the Government always fails to point out in that context is that it rose at that time because of a very strong burst of investment in the resource industries. Following the 1981-82 wage explosion, the recession of 1982-83 which resulted from that reduced import demand and business investment to an extraordinarily low level. Against that background, the current account deficit eased somewhat in 1982-83 to around 4 per cent of gross domestic product. But by 1985-86 that deficit had again increased-it increased further-to around 6 per cent of our gross domestic product, under the influence of swollen fiscal deficits under this Government and, above all, a wages policy totally out of line with our national productivity performance.

It is true that in the latter part of that period these problems were also exacerbated by a significant decline in our international terms of trade-the capacity of our exports to provide the foreign exchange with which to buy imports. In the current Budget we have a forecast that the balance of payments deficit is to fall in the current financial year to what would still be an historically high level of 4 per cent of gross domestic product, a forecast which, I should add, in the light of recent events is already out of date. What we have now got-although we have not yet seen it reflected in the balance of payments figures and we will not see that for a month or two-are the effects of a further fall in the exchange rate impacting upon our balance of payments. A new J-curve is now commencing or is in prospect. In that respect it will be 1985-86 all over again.

Let us consider the situation against which all this is happening. At 30 June last, which is the latest date for which we have figures, the gross external debts of all Australians-that is, government, corporations and individuals-totalled $109,000m. Just four years earlier, which was just after this Government came to office, that figure was only $35 billion. If we take the net figures-that is, after deducting from those gross figures any debts which were owed to Australians, including the Reserve Bank of Australia, by foreigners-Australia's net debts at 30 June last totalled some $83 billion, whereas four years earlier they were only $21 billion. In that very short space of time our net debts have quadrupled.

What that boils down to is that, even at the time of the Budget, Australia was confronted with an unsustainable external account situation. Today that situation has become even more unsustainable than it was, because we now have the realities of our international uncompetitiveness, the likelihood of a resumed fall in the prices of our major export commodities-or a good many of them-and this dramatic increase in our overseas debt, and hence the debt servicing burden, which will be increased by the sharp fall in the value of the Australian dollar which has recently occurred again. These events are now forcing an effect on the Australian economy and, although they are not yet publicly acknowledged to be doing so, on the attention of our Government.

Adjustments in economic policies and, as part of that, in community expectations and attitudes-a point on which the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) often harps, quite rightly, in my view-are urgently required if the slide which has already occurred in living standards is to be halted and, over the longer term, reversed; it certainly cannot be over the shorter term. The Budget Papers canvassed the risks which are associated with forcing the pace of this adjustment but they also recognised, although the Budget did not take any account of it, that the longer we prolong this process of adjustment and refuse to face up to it, the more our debt burden will increase and the greater will be the call on future income from exports to service that debt.

As I have said, since the Budget was brought down we have seen a major deterioration not only in the state of our economy but in the prospective state of the international economy. It is now distinctly likely-not to use any stronger term-that, in the light of those momentous events commencing almost four weeks ago, Australia particularly will be vulnerable to have overseas lenders pull from under us the hot money rug on which our Government's economic policies have been reclining for so long now to maintain not merely the value of our currency but our standard of living. We should not underestimate the capacity of the financial markets to do that, because the extent to which our financial markets, economy, balance of payments and capital account have been propped up by hot money in the past couple of years in particular, by these standards at least, can be regarded as almost limitless. It is very great.

As an illustration of the kind of dilemma which these events have produced for our Government, let us consider that it has been rightly pointed out that in the wake of the share market crash it is the responsibility of the monetary authorities, the central bank, to maintain liquidity in the financial markets to avoid any sharp bankruptcies or crashes of that kind which could have adverse consequences. I agree with that, as we all do. But the problem that the Australian authorities have is that that cannot be a never-ending road. We no longer have the options open to us to prolong that action for very long because if we do so that action will undermine confidence in our currency.

We also cannot afford to have our currency once again go into the kind of free-fall situation that we saw in February and April of 1985, again in November 1985 and, unfortunately, too often during the course of the last couple of years under this Government's policies. The Reserve Bank of Australia is faced with the problem of conducting a delicate operation. It is walking a tightrope-on the one hand it is seeking to maintain adequate liquidity in the financial market while, on the other, it is being extraordinarily concerned about the consequences for the foreign exchange market of doing so.

Furthermore, the events that have already occurred in the last 2 1/2 weeks, as a result of which our currency has already depreciated by something like 8 per cent against the trade weighted index of a basket of currencies and by a bit less than that against the US dollar-that fall has already occurred, let alone any further possible falls that may occur-will themselves regenerate inflationary pressures. Therefore, whereas the Budget Papers talk about an inflation forecast of 6 per cent by the end of this financial year most private forecasters are putting that figure at around 7 1/2 per cent at least, without considering the possibility of further developments between now and then. Events of that kind have already almost certainly overturned the inflationary assumptions in the Budget Papers which were based on, among other things, the so-called wages accord between the Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions.

The point that I want to try to drive home to the Senate, which is set out in the amendment that I wish to move to the Appropriation Bill (No. 1), is that because this Government has squandered time-the past 4 1/2 years, but particularly the past three years-and resources in the sense of living off borrowed money, while persistently running Australia into massive debt, and because of the Government's failure to face up to its responsibility, our national economic options today are so narrowly limited that we can no longer regard ourselves as possibly having an independent economic policy. For example, just consider what the situation would be like if today our international debt were not $109 billion but the $35 billion figure that the Government inherited. Just consider what the situation would be like if today, instead of having a balance of payments deficit which was forecast in the Budget at 4 per cent of gross domestic product and which undoubtedly will be higher than that now unless the recession cuts back imports, we had a balance of payments deficit running at only 1 1/2 or 2 per cent because of good economic management over the past 4 1/2 years.

Under those circumstances, the Government would have some options and would, perhaps, be able to contemplate maintaining a softer monetary policy and keeping interest rates lower than they would otherwise have to be, with the knowledge that this would allow our balance of payments deficit to be rather higher than would otherwise be the case, in the hope that those policies would be able to sustain activity in the Australian economy, shore up employment, reduce the otherwise likely increase in unemployment and generally help to soften the blow from abroad that is in prospect. Because the Government has squandered its opportunities to put us into that position over this time, we do not have those options. We cannot cut taxes and allow the Budget deficit to expand-the kind of thing that might, under other circumstances, have been sensible to suggest. We do not have that option any longer because of the fact that, for 4 1/2 years, this Government has continued to allow us to run further and further into debt and has maintained a balance of payments deficit that is inordinately high.

The real tragedy of Australia's economic situation today is not merely that we are in this position of heavy indebtedness; it is the fact that we do not have to be. This Government continues to proclaim that it has been a successful government that has maintained employment and even managed to reduce unemployment slightly and that the standard of living, until the last year or so at least, has risen slightly. But what the Government has never told us is that there has been a price for that, and the price has been to drive us into debt and to maintain a balance of payments deficit at a level which today ties the hands of the Government in facing up to the now enormous problems confronting us both domestically and abroad.

Therefore, the Opposition calls on the Government to revise its policies-not merely its fiscal policy but its labour market policy, its taxation policy and its other microeconomic policies, such as the ones about which the Leader of the Government in the Senate was refusing to talk in response to Senator Chaney's question today-in order to provide, even at this late stage, a better and more appropriate economic framework in which to meet and deal with our current economic and social dangers. It is the tragedy of this Government and of Australia under this Government that it has frittered away 4 1/2 years of office, particularly the last three years of office, without putting to rights the fundamentals of our public finance and of our balance of payments, and without attempting to brake the growth of our international debt. Because of all those failures, the Government is now helpless in the face of economic events bearing down on us and Australia will be tossed around in the wake of those events.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon we are debating jointly three Bills-Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1987-88, Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1987-88 and Appropriation Bill (No. 2) 1987-88. Effectively, they are the Government's Budget Bills which provide for the 1987 Commonwealth Budget and, as a Government member, I support the legislation. A major feature of the 1987 Budget, which was brought down in September, was expenditure restraint. This Government faced up to the task of restraining the growth in government spending and has cut expenditure on the Forward Estimates quite significantly. The outcome of that activity has been to reduce the Budget deficit for the current financial year to a balanced position, that is, a zero deficit. That compares with the actual outcome in the last financial year of $2,700m and compares even more favourably with the prospective deficit inherited from the Liberal Treasurer of $9,600m for 1983-84. That is a major reduction in the Budget deficit compared with four financial years ago, and that prospective $9,600m deficit inherited from the Liberal Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite the reduction in the deficit to a zero position this year, the Government has been able to proceed further with its rounds of tax cuts and tax reforms which it started in 1985 and, from 1 July of this financial year, the marginal income tax rates have been cut significantly. The rate, which was formerly 46c in the dollar and later reduced to 43c in the dollar, is now a mere 40c in the dollar. The top rate of income tax which we inherited from Mr Howard when he was Treasurer of 60c in the dollar, which we subsequently cut to 55c, from 1 July this year was reduced to 49c in the dollar. The result is that no Australian taxpayer will pay more than half of his or her extra income in income tax, because the top marginal tax rate is now 49c in the dollar.

Economic indicators point to improvements in the Australian economy in recent times and suggest that the Government's budgetary strategy is on target. I instance the indicators which are reported in the Treasury Round-up, the economic bulletin for the month of October published by the Federal Treasury. That summarises a number of the major economic indicators in Australia at present. It is very interesting to note that in the three months to August this year there was a 4.1 per cent growth in new motor vehicle registrations. It is a welcome growth situation in Australia's very important new motor vehicle production industry. There are also signs of an upturn in the home building industry. In the three months to August this year there was a 3.4 per cent increase in new dwelling approvals, suggesting that the recent downturn in housing activity in Australia has bottomed out and that growth is now starting to occur in the new home building industry. One program which must be linked to that, one of the Government's policy initiatives which has been successful in boosting home building activity in Australia, is the first home owners scheme which was introduced by the Hawke Government in 1983 and which provides grants for householders to purchase their first homes. In the three months to August there was growth in retail sales of some 3.4 per cent, a very welcome rate of growth indeed and a sign of continuing confidence by consumers in Australia.

I would like to mention particularly growth in employment which has occurred in recent months. For example, in the September quarter this year, the total number of Australians at work was 2.6 per cent higher than in the September quarter of 1986. That increase in employment has been one of the contributors to the extra 800,000 jobs in Australia since this Government came to power. I am very pleased to say that in just over 4 1/2 years of the Hawke Government 800,000 more Australians are at work. I was rather interested in comments made in the preceding speech by Senator Stone who, of course, was a former head of the Treasury. He said that this Government over 4 1/2 years has frittered away its opportunities in Australia. I must say, and I am sure Senator Tate who is in the chamber at the moment would agree with me, that when we look at the fact that some 800,000 extra jobs have been created under this Government-the great majority are permanent jobs in the private sector; they are not band-aid jobs in make work schemes-it is very hard to sustain the argument which Senator Stone embarked upon that opportunities have been frittered away. Clearly, over 800,000 more Australians are at work and no doubt they regard that as a very tangible improvement in the Australian economic scene.

In the June quarter the unemployment rate fell as employment rose. In the June quarter the average rate of unemployment was 8 per cent compared with 8.2 per cent previously. In regard to new jobs available in the community, one of the more important items is a document prepared by the ANZ Bank which shows that in the month of September this year the number of new job advertisements in metropolitan newspapers rose by 5.9 per cent, making the figure 11.9 per cent higher than just 12 months ago. So the number of new jobs advertised has increased by more than 11 per cent over a 12-month period and, more importantly, the number of new jobs being advertised is now at its highest level since April 1986. I suggest that Senator Stone would have great difficulty in making his claim that opportunities have been frittered away by this Government. He needs to look at not only the numbers of extra people at work but also those who are about to go into work as a result of very rapid increases in the number of new jobs being advertised in Australia.

The Australian Bureau of Statistics publishes a series of job vacancies. That series also shows an uptrend. The number of job vacancies recorded in August 1987, which are the latest figures available, is 56,200 or some 7,600 higher than in August 1986. I think the Government can take some heart from those figures. It is yet another confirmation that the Hawke Government, members of the Australian Labor Party, are much better economic managers than the Liberal Party of Australia under Mr Howard in the period to 1982-83. We need only to look at Mr Howard's recent record to be able to substantiate that particular claim. I pointed out on a number of occasions in this place that Mr Howard's record as Treasurer was disastrous. In five Budgets he had a disastrous record; he presided over the destruction of hundreds of thousands of jobs, a double digit unemployment rate and double digit cost of living rises. That was his record as Treasurer.
I would like to examine in some detail Mr Howard's recent record as Opposition Leader in the Australian Parliament. It is interesting to go back to Mr Howard's speech on the 1986 Budget. He said:
Unemployment is likely to rise well above the current 8.3 per cent.

That was what Mr Howard said just over 12 months ago, but the facts are quite different. The reality is totally at odds with the claim made by Mr Howard because unemployment did not rise in the financial year 1986-87. The actual figure for the year was 8.3 per cent, the same as the figure quoted by Mr Howard as being the current figure at that time, so there was absolutely no rise in unemployment in that particular year. Mr Howard went on to say:
. . . recession is likely to continue for longer than anticipated by the Government . . .

But when one looks at the gross domestic product figures that we have available to us now for 1986-87, we see that actual gross domestic product rose in both halves of the financial year; it did not rise at some isolated point of time in that year, it rose in both halves of the 1986-87 financial year. Again we can see that with economic growth occurring in the community there was no such thing as an economic recession as predicted by Mr Howard during 1986-87. He then went on to talk about the Budget deficit. Mr Howard, the Leader of the Opposition and a former Treasurer of Australia last year, said:
. . . the Budget deficit will blow out above the estimated $3.5 billion.

He attacked the estimated deficit, the estimate made by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) that the Commonwealth Budget of Australia would be $3,500m last financial year. All honourable senators have those figures available to them. They show that the actual deficit for 1986-87 was $2,700m. It did not blow out from the $3,500m as estimated by the Treasurer, it came in better than that-it came in at a figure of $2,700m. Yet that particular claim again was made by the man who wants to be Prime Minister of this nation, the man who was Treasurer of Australia for five years and the man who left this country with double digit unemployment and double digit inflation. Mr Howard, in his speech last year, went on to say that the Budget:
will limit any substantive fall in interest rates during the year ahead.

He claimed that there would be limited falls in interest rates. I ask honourable senators to look at some of the commercial rates in the market place; for example, the rate of interest paid by the banks on their 90-day bank bills which is one of the most common ways in which banks borrow money for lending to the rest of the community. The rate of interest on those bank bills was over 17 per cent last January; the rate yesterday was below 13 per cent. So there was a very significant reduction in that important interest rate in the community.

I would like to turn also to Mr Howard's predictions last year, made in his speech on the Budget, concerning net exports. That particular piece of economic jargon refers to the excess of Australia's exports over its imports. The Budget forecast for the 1986-87 financial year was for a 1 3/4 percentage point contribution to gross domestic product from net exports. Mr Howard, in response to that prediction in the Budget, said that this would result more from driving the economy into recession and reducing imports than from the so-called J-curve working. But when one looks at the figures one sees that they totally contradict the claims made by Mr Howard. They totally disprove his statement. While there was a 4.8 per cent reduction in imports in 1986-87, there was far stronger growth in exports. Exports did not stagnate, as he suggested would happen; they grew by 7.5 percentage points. So, wrong again on net exports, Mr Howard.

Senator Short, a member of this place who, by the way, is a former Treasury officer-I think that is correct-made some predictions about the Budget in this place on 28 August last year. I found them fascinating reading when I went through them recently. I love checking up on the statements made by members of the Liberal Party because I know that I can always catch them out. They are always interested in the short term gain. They do not take a long term view of politics and they trip themselves up fairly quickly. For example, on 28 August last year Senator Short said that it was highly unlikely that Australia would lift its net export performance by anything like 1 3/4 percentage points. So a member of this place, I think at the time a shadow Minister in the Opposition and a former Treasury officer, said that Mr Keating's prediction about the contribution of net exports to economic growth would not reach the 1 3/4 percentage point level. But the record shows that the actual figure was 2.3 per cent, which far exceeded the prediction made by the Government. There is yet another case of an Opposition senator looking for the chance of short term gain, and getting caught out again. It is just a matter of checking the records and watching what Opposition senators say.

I was interested in the prediction that Senator Stone made today. Mr Acting Deputy President, I can assure you that I will be checking the record very assiduously in the months to come to ensure that people such as Senator Stone are brought to account for the predictions they make about economic matters. Using about six instances this afternoon I have been able to show that Mr Howard made very rash predictions which did not come true and I have shown up a rather foolish prediction by Senator Short, made just 15 months ago, which has been clearly disproved by the record, by the Budget outcome. Those predictions made by honourable senators in the debate today and which will be made during this week will be examined very carefully by Government members.

I would like now to refer also to the fact that in this Budget the Government is bringing down its $500m family package, as announced during the election campaign. That family package will introduce real increases in the standard of living of more than one million children. The package will be introduced from this Christmas and will include a new family allowance supplement of $22 a week for families with one child, earning $300 a week or less. That income limit increases by $12 for each subsequent child, so the income limit for a two-child family is $312 a week. Families earning below that figure qualify for the full $22 a week for each dependent child. The most important thing to bear in mind about the package is that it applies to working families. It applies not just to families whose head depends on social welfare payments but also to families whose head is in the work force but who is earning a low income. Of course that family package was a major election policy statement of this Hawke Government.

It is noteworthy that the Government fought the election campaign on the themes of leadership and stability, its record in economic management-the fact that it had taken the tough decisions to get Australia back on the right economic track-and the lack of credibility of the Opposition in the Federal Parliament. It is very interesting that, as a result of the July elections, Labor not only is in government in four Australian States but also has been elected, for the first time in history, in three successive Federal elections. One of the results of the last election was that the Hawke Government increased its majority in the House of Representatives from 16 to 24 seats-a net gain of four seats, giving us our largest ever majority in the House of Representatives. We achieved election victories in the seat of Denison in Tasmania-which I know Senator Tate is very interested in-in the Northern Territory and, most particularly, in four more seats in Queensland. We won the seats of Forde, Petrie, Hinkler and Fisher. A very big swing to Labor in Queensland resulted in those substantial gains for the Government. I regret that we lost two very hard-working members in Mr Maher, the former member for Lowe in New South Wales, and Mrs Mayer, the former member for Chisholm. Those were the only two losses by this Government in the election. It is very important to note that the Labor Party now holds--

TALK.START.PARA: —You lost Senator West. Maybe she wasn't a valued colleague.

—I will talk about the Senate in a moment. It is important to note-I know that Liberal members do not like to hear about this-that, as a result of the realignment in Australian politics, Labor now holds the majority of House of Representatives seats in every mainland State of Australia. Only a matter of 10 years ago my State of South Australia was the only State that had a majority of Labor seats in the House of Representatives. I know that Liberal members do not like to hear these unpalatable facts but I repeat that Labor now holds the majority of House of Representatives seats in every mainland State of Australia. That is as a result of swings to Labor, particularly in Queensland, achieved despite the very difficult economic climate and economic circumstances in Australia. The Government had a swing against it at a national level, on a two-party preferred vote, of only one per cent-quite a small swing in view of the circumstances.

SPEECH.PARA: The results give absolutely no comfort at all to the Opposition because, on the figures, it will be harder for the coalition parties to win the next election than it would have been for them to win the 1987 Federal election. It will require a swing of 3.3 per cent to win Labor's thirteenth most marginal seat-which, on my calculations, is the seat of Calare in New South Wales-and remove the Government's majority. Our campaign was very effective in the marginal seats. There is no doubt that, despite a recent assessment of the Liberal Party about the election results, we targeted the marginal seats very effectively indeed and we focused our campaign on the key seats. By contrast, the Opposition will be very vulnerable at the next election. Again on my calculations, a uniform swing of 2 per cent to the Government would net seven Opposition seats and that would give us a majority of 38 seats in the House of Representatives. A swing of 2 per cent to Labor would give us the seats of Chisholm, Casey, Flinders and Deakin in Victoria, Moreton and Dawson-two more seats-in Queensland and Lowe in New South Wales.

The Hawke Government's strongest performance at the election was in Queensland. As I have pointed out, we won four seats. We now have a majority of the Federal divisions in Queensland, holding 13 of the 24 Federal seats in that State. What a change that is from the period 10 years ago when Labor held only one Federal seat in Queensland. I well recall the time not so long ago when the only Federal seat held by Labor in Queensland was that of Oxley held by Mr Hayden. We now hold 13 seats, a majority of the seats in Queensland. All I say to the coalition parties is, `Eat your hearts out. Labor is now the majority party in that State'. The reason for that is that there was a swing to Labor, to the Government, of 1.4 per cent in Queensland on a two-party preferred vote basis.

Queensland is the State that is supposed to be the jewel in the crown of the National Party of Australia. I see there are some National Party senators in the chamber today. Queensland was supposedly the jewel in the crown of that Party. But the result of the election shows that four seats went to Labor. On the calculations of others in the Labor Party, another 1,000 votes to Labor would have given us three more seats. The seats of Kennedy, Dawson and Moreton would have fallen to Labor with another 1,000 votes spread over those seats.

It is particularly interesting to note that in the Federal division of Wide Bay-you, Mr Deputy President, will be aware that this incorporates the State seat of Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen-the swing to Labor was 2.6 per cent. In fact, one of the biggest swings to Labor in Australia occurred in the Federal division in which the town of Kingaroy is sited. There is no doubt in my mind that the result in Queensland in the Federal election was a stinging rebuff to the ill-conceived `Joh for PM' campaign because the biggest swings to Labor in the Federal election occurred consistently in the State of Queensland. One can say that the wheels fell off the `Joh for PM' band-wagon before it had even left the Queensland border. The reality was a stinging rebuff to the National Party in Queensland, a landslide to Labor and a major electoral realignment in that State.

I turn to the rural results in the election campaign because it is quite clear from the figures available that the swing against Labor in rural and provincial Australia was less than in the capital cities. That is a very significant result because, prior to the 1987 election, of our nine most marginal seats five were based on provincial cities or included substantial rural areas. But the reality is that in the election we held every one of those seats. Not one of those five seats, based on provincial cities or having substantial rural areas, was lost by Labor. That followed a period of years in which honourable senators from the Liberal and National parties talked in this place about how the Labor Party had no support in country areas and that its taxation reforms and other policies would alienate voters in rural areas.

The fact is that we did extraordinarily well outside of the capital cities in the 1987 election. Not only did we hold the seats that were at risk, the marginal seats, but also we picked up two provincial seats. We gained the seat of Hinkler in Queensland, based on the cities of Bundaberg and Gladstone, and we gained the Northern Territory. So there were further gains to Labor in rural areas of Australia at the 1987 election. The so-called rural revolt, about which we in the Government were subjected to tirades day after day and week after week in this place, completely fizzled out. The Opposition did not convince the townspeople. The so-called rural revolt did not carry the townspeople along with it. One of the reasons for that is that those Australians who live in country areas are becoming more and more aware as every month goes by that Labor governments are not as bad for them as the picture that has been painted by conservative politicians in the past. Those who live in country areas are becoming more and more familiar with life under a Labor government. They have found that the picture is not as bad as that painted by conservative politicians.

It is interesting to note, from my calculations, that 10 years ago the Labor Party held just three Federal divisions outside of the capital cities of Australia. Following the 1987 election one can estimate that we now hold some 21 out of 45 non-metropolitan electorates. So there has been a quantum growth in Labor's representation in rural areas of Australia. That has been one of the major factors in the increase in Labor's majority in the House of Representatives. Of course, one of the big flops of the campaign was the role of the New Right, which has totally dropped out of the news, as honourable senators will be aware, in recent times. Who has heard anything of Katharine West and the other maddies out there? They have dropped out of the news completely.

Another aspect of the campaign involved the total flop of the National Farmers Federation (NFF) campaign. The NFF targeted 22 seats in the election campaign; 11 of those were held by the Government and 11 were held by the coalition parties. Labor held every one of its 11. Labor held every one of its seats targeted by the National Farmers Federation and also won three from the Liberals and Nationals. That was the effect of the National Farmers Federation's campaign. We received a positive swing to us in all but one of the Labor seats targeted by the National Farmers Federation. So in 10 of the 11 seats held by Labor and targeted by Mr McLachlan and his cronies, we got a swing to us, not against us, at the election campaign. It is interesting that the biggest swing to Labor in South Australia occurred in the seat of Barker where Mr Ian McLachlan has his largest property. In fact it was in the southern part of the Barker electorate, where Mr McLachlan's property is situated, that the biggest swing to Labor in South Australia in the election occurred. At the 1987 election Labor rewrote the history books by winning three elections in a row. I believe we will win the next election. I believe we will win four terms and, as a result of that, we will totally rewrite the history books of Australia.

—I pick up Senator Stone's interjection. But, if the election result is a matter of history, so too are the economic verities to which Senator Stone has referred in his speech. SPEECH.PARA: The opportunity given by this debate allows senators to range widely-in fact to range over much government activity and not least to have a look at matters of context, the context within which we operate in Australia. Senator Stone has referred particularly to the economic context. We can look at the economic context, the political context and questions of context which are so vital today in Australia. They are as vital as the options we choose or the priorities we make. Unless we get the context right, many of our efforts will be in vain. The context in which we operate nationally should give Australia great cause for concern.

I go back to what my colleague Senator Stone said. He described a national debt in excess of $100,000m and pointed out that if one nets that down the debt is $83,000m. He pointed out that when the Labor Party took office-the glorious Government of which Senator Maguire spoke-the netted down foreign debt was $21,000m. That is as much a verity as any of the election figures which were presented to us. We heard nothing of that. We know that the foreign debt is rising by more than $1,000m every month. We know that the balance of payments deficit has been running as high as 6 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP). We know that the Government thinks that it will come down to 4 per cent of GDP. But the Government inherited a level far lower than that-a level, I believe, of less than 2 per cent of GDP. The Government now thinks that it is doing well by aiming for a much higher figure than that. Our currency is diminishing rapidly in its value against the harder currencies. Against the Japanese yen it was in the low 90s and it probably remains there.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has fallen by about 10 per cent.

—Senator Stone says that it has fallen by about 10 per cent. Business confidence is low. More than that, we know that measured poverty in Australia is increasing. We know that home prices have put buying homes out of the reach of many Australians. The parents of young adults ask, `How can they hope to do as we did and purchase and own homes?'. The rental market has contracted and has disappeared. Rental accommodation is impossible to find. Homelessness in Australia has increased rapidly under this Government. Business failures have increased and are at a high level. Government support for the needy has diminished and government support for the wealthy has increased. Families in Australia, whose functions are so important and vital-whatever form they have-are finding it harder to fulfil those functions. So of course we are concerned and worried. We look at the context and we do not like what we see.

SPEECH.PARA: I am reminded that the Budget which we are considering was in two parts. There was a preliminary Budget statement in May this year. People have forgotten some of the things that were in the preliminary statement, but they are part of the Budget presentation which we are considering now. We remember that the Government sought to balance its books by reducing or withdrawing benefits to the needy, by imposing harsher conditions for those in need to gain access to benefits, by creating longer waiting periods and so on. Has anyone forgotten that the Government sought to balance its books by making conditions for widows harder, by telling widows whose children had grown older and who had done nothing more than elect to be full time homemakers, that they had to go out and compete again in the work force, a work force in which today there are 600,000 people registered as unemployed? What kind of priority was that? The only sin those people had committed was trying to be homemakers and to look after the children who had been left in their care.

The Government saw fit to impose harsher conditions on the unemployed, families, school leavers, single sickness beneficiaries and all the young unemployed. It managed to take $77m in a full year from them. The Government sought to make those with complicated illnesses less able to pay their way. It sought to make those choosing to take beds in private hospitals pay more. It sought to make it more difficult for students, and it sought to make it more difficult for those seeking to get child care. The Government sought to make it difficult for all of those people to make their way.

The Government at no stage gave us a full accounting of who the losers would be from this mini-Budget exercise, what the extent of their loss would be and what the social costs of the measures which it introduced would be. The social costs are many, not least in the area in which I am expert. During the Estimates hearings we had occasion to test the Government on its proposals to take away some of the rebates for payments to consulting physicians. I am a consulting physician. As I am no longer in practice, I have no pecuniary interest in what the Government has chosen to do. But the Chief Medical Officer of the Commonwealth told us in the Estimates that in relation to 20 medical conditions which I put to him, the Government's proposals simply would not work, that the conditions for which it was proposed to limit access to consulting physicians were the very conditions for which prolonged contact with those physicians was absolutely necessary.

In the initial Budget statement the Government sought to achieve its major cost savings by hitting the weakest and the most vulnerable in our society. We should make clear a priority which the Liberal Party of Australia and, I am sure, the National Party of Australia have always emphasised, and that is that we will respond to need when we provide our welfare. It is impossible to understand the social priorities of some of the measures which were introduced by the Government in May, especially when they were to be offset by tax cuts for all, including the wealthiest in the community.

I wish to use this opportunity to say something else in the area of context, to talk a little about the trade context in which Australia is trying to operate. Our capacity to trade will determine our capacity to prosper. Senator Maguire said that there had been a 7 1/2 per cent increase in trade. He did not bother to tell us whether he was talking about dollars or volume, but whatever he was talking about, I accept his figure in good faith. But other countries have had to trade under adverse circumstances. For example, Sweden and Switzerland have had to make their way in a hostile world. If Australia is to prosper, we must examine the context in which we are operating. We have to set the context and we have to get it right.

It is appropriate now to examine the trade context, especially as it relates to Australia's relations with the three major trading groups in the world in which we operate. Those three major groups are critically important to Australia. I ask: How does what they are doing affect us now, how much have they done to damage us, and what are they threatening to do in the imminent future? The three main blocs are the European Community-a community of well over 300 million people-Japan, which is the great giant to our north, and the United States. Those three groups together account for 60 per cent of all the world trade in manufactured products, so they dominate most of the markets that interest us. The three groups are quite dissimilar and they present quite different problems for Australia today. The United States is the country most open to imports. It is the country that has been most serious about ending protection. Because it has been most open to imports, it has sucked in imports. That is one of the reasons that large United States deficits have become inevitable. The United States is heading into a presidential election year, and we have to ask what mood that will create for the United States approach to trade, especially as the Uruguay Round is upon us.

In its dealings with the European Community, the United States has been operating at a great trade disadvantage. The European Community has a trade surplus with the United States of something like 25,000 million European currency units (ECUs), which is about $A30 billion, annually. At the same time, the US capacity to penetrate the European market has dropped and its exports to the European Community have dropped, over about four or five years, by about 75 per cent. So the United States is becoming more aggressive. It is looking at the situation and it does not like what it sees. It sees unequal treatment being given to it in its relations with Europe. It is approaching an election year in which protectionist pressures are rising and it is approaching the Uruguay Round where it wants to get some progress on moving further towards free trade.

I put to the Senate that part of the context in which we operate is that there is the possibility of a trade war between Europe and the United States if things do not go well. Such a trade war, should it occur, would be to no one's benefit and especially not to the benefit of a country such as Australia, trading as it does with both Europe and the United States. The European Community is chronically in deficit in its relations with Japan. It had a deficit of $US8,000m in 1982 which has now risen to over $US22 billion a year. The European Community now understands that this cannot go on. So in terms of that bilateral relationship, things are not good.

The European Community is the largest exporter of dairy products in the world. It is the largest exporter of beef and the second largest exporter of wheat. It is the third largest exporter of sugar after Cuba and the Soviet Union. Of course, it is also the largest agricultural importer in the world but mainly in coffee and tropical products. The European Community is in a mess and that is important for Australia in its trading capacity, prospects and future. Europe is suffering from what has been called `Euro-sclerosis', an incapacity to modify what it does in the face of some realities which I will set out. Japan, by contrast, after probably being worst affected of all the players by the oil shock, came out of the oil crisis toughened and more competitive and we are seeing the result today.

Because of what the European Community has done, because of its production policies, its subsidisation policies and its export subsidies, the world prices of products that affect Australia have dropped by about 16 per cent. The European Community has in stock over one million tonnes of butter. It costs the European Community a dollar a day per tonne to store this butter. That store is three or four times the entire world market per year. How are we supposed to operate as a nation interested in dairy products in that kind of context? The European Community has a stock of beef of over 650,000 tonnes and in the killing season it is adding to that stock by 10,000 tonnes to 20,000 tonnes each week. The European Community finds itself in this position because of its production and export subsidies for agriculture. In 1986 export subsidies for agriculture were about 10 billion European currency units, about $A13,000m. We in Australia, looking at this Budget and asking what kind of context we are working in as we try to trade our way out of trouble, find we have very great difficulties.

It is true that in 1986 the European Community was our second biggest trading partner but this was because we sell more than $1 billion of coal a year to the European Community. We sell $900m of wool and $750m worth of metals and ores a year to the European Community. But our problems with the Community relate particularly to agriculture. It is Australian agriculture that has suffered and it is all Australian trade that might suffer if the European Community cannot get its house in order. In the European Community agriculture is big business-it has become big agri-business now-but it is socially important because of the many small communities which are agricultural. It is because of these that Europe-in particular, Germany within the European Community-seems to lack a capacity and will to move.

It seems that the common agricultural policy (CAP) is the problem that is making so much difficulty for us in Australia. After all, because of the common agricultural policy, European domestic subsidies stimulate overproduction so that Europe produces uneconomically more than it needs and the price related supports then distort community markets so that it is more difficult for Australia with its very efficient farming, its very efficient production, even to penetrate those markets. The export subsidies then allow the European Community to dump on world markets and to take away from us or interfere with the non-European markets to which we have traditionally sold. Interestingly, in talking about context, the common agricultural policy is now costing the European Community enormous amounts of money. In fact, in this current year, or the year just past, the CAP cost the European Community more money than the total income which the Community received from all the member states.

Mr Deputy President, you will know that the Community gets its income from a part of the value added tax collections of each of the member states. The common agricultural policy subsidy payments this year came to 29 billion ECUs when the total income of the Community was 24 billion ECUs. I say to honourable senators that the European Community this year is technically bankrupt because it is paying out on an agricultural policy, the effect of which is to beggar the rest of the world, more money than it receives in total. Honourable senators may not have realised that the Europeans have got where they are partly because they have developed a decision making process which we do not use in this country. They have proceeded at a painfully slow speed by a method of consensual decision making. Unless we can master the consequences of their consensual decision making method, we will not be able to correct the situation in which we find ourselves.

What does it all mean for Australia? Australia has already been forced to make more dramatic changes than has the European Community. Since the mid-1970s we have reduced our butter production by more than 60 per cent. We have reduced our skim milk production by 35 per cent. Our beef herd has been reduced by 27 per cent and in the last three years alone we have reduced our wheat acreage by 15 per cent and our barley acreage by more than one-quarter. Employment in this country has suffered. Farming communities have disappeared. Small farming towns have discovered that they are no longer viable and our fragile rural communities have been destroyed. It is all very well for the Europeans to tell us that they cannot change because they have fragile communities; we from this Senate should tell them that we do as well and that Australia is suffering.

Mr Deputy President, in the year ahead Japan will have to try to start opening up its markets to many more imports. It will have to take a lot more imports as part of its share of solving some of the world problems. The European Community has to be helped to modify and move the common agricultural policy to something more sensible. It has to move from production subsidies to income support, which seems to be the favoured mechanism being put to us by Europeans. That would be very helpful. The United States must be assisted in the election year to resist the more outrageous protectionist pressures. The United States has to be assisted-as far as Australia can do so-towards a successful prosecution of its role in the Uruguay Round. We see an interesting situation where the United States legislative branch is becoming heavily protectionist as elections approach while the United States Executive tends to be much more interested in what the Uruguay Round might produce. Australia during this time must be able to take advantages, such as they are, of our more competitive export position, brought about by our weakened currency. I think that new protectionism is the danger we face, and we must do all we can to overcome it.

At the moment there seem to be three giant trade elephants in the world fighting each other. Australia is like the grass beneath their feet. If I can paraphrase an old East African saying from the Kikuyu tribe, when the elephants fight, it is the grass that gets trampled. There are three elephants fighting and we, as the grass underneath, are feeling the pain of what they are doing. We need from this Government a set of clear trade priorities. I want to understand what it sees as Australia's place, as we find and secure niches in markets around the world, as other small to medium size countries have done in adverse times. For example, Sweden, early in this century, had exactly the same kind of problem.

I want to know what the Government is doing, what policy approaches it is taking, to try to hold what we have now against the pressures in the United States, Europe and Japan, to send us even further backwards, to restrict our markets even more, to trump up cases against our exporters. I want to know what this Government will do to secure and to extend our penetration of more markets in the large region in which we live and operate. The last annual report that I saw of the then Department of Trade was concerned more about activities, structures and processes than it was about strategies or outcomes. Perhaps that was just as I read it, but it did not give me a lot of heart. I think the test in the end is what we can achieve by way of exports, markets and products.

I conclude where I began: the question is one of context, the theme of our context. As Senator Stone said in his presentation, had the balance of payments deficit in Australia been held even to, say, 2 per cent, instead of the 4 per cent which the Government thinks it will achieve, think of the context that might then have applied. Had the overseas debt been held even close to the $35 billion mark, the $21 billion net that the Government inherited in 1983, think of the context in which we would have then been operating. Neither of those things are the reality today. The overseas debt has blown out to a net figure of over $80 billion. The balance of payments deficit has blown out, and we only have good intentions to say that it will come in at a lower figure. The context for this country is quite different. The Government is not now in a position to be able to direct policies which can best help Australia. The Government stands condemned for that, above all else. The Government has fired the bullets available to it so far and has done so with insufficient result. It has used up its options, and it leaves us with too few options today. Australia is now quite unnecessarily at the mercy of world events that are not of our making-events from which we are suffering.

My presentation of the trade situation around the world sought merely to indicate another way in which Australia is suffering and another way in which we are more in jeopardy than we need have been. It is my belief that unless we can do something to control some of the outcomes of these negotiations between our great and powerful trading partners during the next year our position will become even more difficult and less certain. The tragedy for Australia is that so much of it was avoidable and it was not avoided.

There is one area that deserves special mention, and it is one that the Australian Labor Party and, indeed, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and his Ministers, particularly the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe), can take a tremendous amount of pleasure from. TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Lewis very much. I will continue with my remarks in regard to the stock exchange. I have had something to say on this before. It is my view-I do not say that it is a view shared by the majority of Australians or, indeed, by the majority within my own Party, nevertheless I believe it is a view that is worth putting on the public record-that the speculation by and greed of a small part of the international and domestic business clique have put in peril the stability of the economic system of the entire financial world. That is evidenced by the massive increases in paper value we have seen in the previous 12-month period on the stock exchange, not only in this country but also in all the major capitalist trading nations of the world. Speculators have proved by their actions that they have no interest in the real productive activity of the economy. They are after a quick profit. If a quick profit can be extracted, the speculator believes that such a profit should be extracted irrespective of the cost to the individual, perhaps the worker on the shop floor, or the community in general. As long as the profit is there, the speculator believes that that profit should be his or hers. There has been a demand, which has been echoed in the past few days, that there should be no legal constraints put in the way of speculators' activities. We will see this demand by the pseudo-intellectual friends of the speculators, the New Right, rise again and again in the coming months. We have had something to say in the past about that movement. Perhaps it is not the force it was pre-election, but nonetheless it is still around.

SPEECH.PARA: Members of the New Right suffered because of the crash in world stock markets. Perhaps it has shaken their gung ho confidence. They, above all others, had believed that the market-place was the only place from which society could be governed. Their confidence has been shaken as has their belief that the benefits of an unfettered market-place were obvious and self-evident. With the massive losses in prospect, the security of some form of regulation of financial institutions has suddenly become more attractive to some of the speculators. It makes one wonder what some of them are about. It would be like those of us who had a gamble, albeit small, recently on the Melbourne Cup-some lost and some won-seeking an indemnity from government to cover our losses. There are some interesting examples around Australia of requests to balance the Budget following the stock market crash.

The Budget, in turn, put some new pressures on the New Right. The Budget, as I said, was responsible and informed. As Senator Maguire said earlier, it has proved to be a blow to the New Right. One does not hear a great deal from the New Right now. Its demands for Budget cuts, which would impose further burdens on disadvantaged groups, have been exposed for what they are: the demands of a greedy few for more of the national cake. Similarly, the July Federal election proved in many ways to be a disappointment to the New Right. Internal divisions and circumstances beyond the control of New Right groups led to the demise of the `Joh for Canberra' campaign. The much-vaunted targeting of marginal seats by the zealous leadership of the National Farmers Federation proved almost totally ineffective. It was exactly in those marginal seats that the Labor Government proved its durability and resilience.

Many people can claim responsibility for the demise of the New Right-or at least putting it into the background where it properly belongs. Efforts by the Government, the trade union movement and the Australian Labor Party to expose the New Right activities in the run-up to the Federal election paid dividends in terms of public awareness and the subsequent rejection of New Right philosophies at the election. The likely New Right response at the moment will be to re-examine and perhaps apply sophisticated overseas models of propaganda, influence and control on the Australian population.

The aftermath of the Federal election has also proved traumatic for the neo-conservatives. The standard-bearer in the north, the Premier of Queensland, Joh Bjelke-Petersen, is now a spent political force, ineffectual and even an embarrassment to those people who put him there. Behind that tottering throne where he sits for the moment we see that the jostling for power is beginning. It has probably been there for some time but it is now more in the open than it has been. The long tentacles of corruption reach even closer to the inner sanctums of the major political party in that area, making it increasingly difficult for that party to maintain its facade of fundamentalist moral purity. In this context I am not talking about condoms but moral purity as distinct from sexual purity. These things are demonstrable set-backs for the New Right.
It is important to note that there are inherent contradictions in New Right thought. As Erica McWilliam points out in her article `The Challenge of the New Right':

Its appeal is for both a stable social world, an established community with shared values and moral restraint and, paradoxically, a world which is wide open to possibilities, a world of individuals unfettered by government action.
Consistency and coherence are abandoned philosophically in favour of seizing on matters of free floating anxiety thrown up by forces unleashed by the development of capitalism itself.

It would be an error for us to regard the New Right as a clearly-defined political entity. Even more dangerous would be the idea that the recent electoral, internal and market force set-backs are an indication that the New Right has become a spent force. The realistic situation is that while the philosophies espoused by the New Right are deplorable, it must be recognised by all that some of the key individuals in the New Right have considerable organisational ability, even a misused intelligence. One likely short term strategy which the New Right might adopt is to concentrate on what has proven successful in the past-union bashing. On this scenario, attempts to rekindle anti-union fervour by running on pseudo-issues such as powerful unions, union bosses and union anarchy, are to be expected. Some of the puppet columnists have started this already. I notice that Senator Lewis reads newspapers. Perhaps he will point out the names of the columnists who are putting these ideas forward. I will not waste time in my contribution by doing this.

If the Budget strategy is to succeed, the Government, the trade union movement and the community must be on guard against these renewed attacks. If the New Right succeeds in destabilising the industrial relations system, this will provide the neo-conservatives with the will and the impetus to exert their evil influences on an even larger audience-the total political system of this wonderful nation.

One other area of concern-it is not necessarily a Budget matter, although it is certainly Budget-related-and which is on the agenda at the moment is privatisation. That is interpreted as the sale, in whole or in part, of publicly-owned assets. Assets which have been put on the list for discussion include the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, Qantas Airways Ltd, Australian Airlines, Telecom Australia and a host of others. The debate on whether these assets should be sold is ongoing and healthy. It will culminate in June next year in Hobart when the Labor Party National Conference is held in that fair city.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a fair city.

—It is indeed. I have been there once. It was very cold but, nonetheless, it is a very fair city. I wish that Senator Tate could do something about the weather. I am glad that his efforts, among those of other senators, have enabled us to be given minimum temperatures for that fair city. Each of the assets which I mentioned before is a revenue raiser for government. The Commonwealth Bank, for example, contributed $100m last year. Qantas contributed $15m and Telecom contributed $661m. When this debate is concluded next year, if it is concluded once and for all, I believe that the Labor Party will decide, for a wide number of reasons, not to sell these assets. Many of these reasons are being canvassed at the moment in the community.

SPEECH.PARA: There is one government asset that I would like to see added to the list. Perhaps it sounds a little strange that a reputed left winger of the Labor Party would be advocating the sale of a government asset but I have had things to say in previous debates in this place about the Australian National Gallery. I note that page 195 of Budget Paper No. 1 states that the allocation this year to the Australian National Gallery is $15.7m. I have only a few minutes of my time left, but a few more things to say. My attention was drawn this morning to a leader in today's West Australian newspaper, headlined: `Jobs paradox is still with us'. This was a fairly responsible leader, or editorial comment, which said that an examination of the problems that Australia is experiencing at the moment shows a paradox of a shortage of skilled labour at a time of high unemployment. If we retrace our steps three or four years back, we find ourselves in a period when apprentices, particularly in the metal industry, were being put off by employers because there was not enough work for them, and because some employers had joined a campaign to cut youth wages. Now we find that, Australia-wide, we are having to recruit skilled persons from overseas to fill our needs because for some developments in some areas we do not have the necessary skilled people to do particular jobs and to continue the economic development of Australia.

This matter has not been put in the cupboard by the Government and forgotten about. We are acutely aware that there are problems in this area. Not all of the problems are of our own making and we are certainly not going to get into a union bash. Mr Dawkins, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, presented his Budget Paper No. 9, Skills Formation in Australia, during Budget day in the House of Representatives. I commend the paper to each and every person involved, in Parliament and out in society, in this very important matter, whether as a parent, an employer, a trade unionist or a worker. There is a whole restructuring of training, retraining, and education related training going on within the Department of Employment, Education and Training.

However, I express some concerns about one area, although I blame myself for not informing myself about it earlier.
