I asked the official what Job Club is and I was informed that it is a three-week course to train young people on how to apply for a job. I expressed some concern about why it should take three weeks to train a person to apply for a job, and I was given some verbal information with the promise of some written to come. I await that, but at this stage I need convincing that one has to spend three weeks to train people in the art of applying for a job.

There has been some mention about the state of the Senate and people who are no longer with us and I had intended to pay tribute to some of my former colleagues, particularly those Western Australians Ruth Coleman and Gordon McIntosh. I had intended to welcome Senator Michael Beahan, who I believe will make an enormous contribution to the chamber on behalf of his State. Unfortunately, I have let time get away from me. I would have liked to say something about former Senator Georges and put on record just how he came to leave this Parliament, because some distortions have been made today and at other times about why George is no longer with us in body, although he is still with us in spirit on many of the issues for which he has fought so valiantly over the years. I commend the Budget to the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —If one is not worried, then one simply does not understand the problem. Senator McKiernan is not worried and he showed today that he simply has no understanding of the problem. But he is in good company-neither has the Treasurer (Mr Keating). The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) has expressed some concerns. The Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) has expressed enormous concerns. The Treasurer is still somewhere out there in cloud-cuckoo-land with Senator McKiernan.

SPEECH.PARA: That his Budget is no longer appropriate is the simple reality. We warned of that when it was introduced. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) said that it was a risky Budget that left no scope for any protection and gave no benefit of any cover in the event of everything not turning out exactly right. Things are not turning out exactly right. They have turned out very wrong indeed. The risk to which the Government exposed the nation in that Budget is now being revealed. That risk or danger is understood by everyone except, apparently, the Treasurer.

The reality is that if the present situation persists, this Budget will be about $1 billion wrong-unless, of course, the Government fiddles it by slamming in some more of the Reserve Bank profits that will emerge, in Australian dollar terms, from the continued collapse of the Australian dollar. But the Budget will not work either, and that is not just the Opposition saying so but the expert commentators such as Syntec Economic Services Pty Ltd, or even Senator Walsh, who have recognised that this Budget, which may have been marginally appropriate-as Senator McKiernan pointed out, some journalists welcomed it-given the continuation of the Indian summer in our economy that we had when it was introduced, is massively inappropriate now. Given the dramatic change in the outlook for the world, and for Australia, it is simply inappropriate and it will not work.

We hope that there will not be a world recession and my concerns are expressed in that context. I do not expect there to be a world recession. Sensible comment overseas seems to be pointing to a significant slowdown in world economic growth-a slowdown that we cannot afford and that will have a massive impact on the Australian economy. The fact that there probably will not be a recession overseas does not mean that there will not be an enormous negative impact on Australia. One does not have to be a Jeremiah or a knocker, or all those other names that the Labor Party comes out with whenever anybody introduces a note of reality into the debate, to see that. One does not have to put up with that kind of nonsense from the Labor Party because, interestingly enough, some of the Labor Party people themselves recognise the truth of all the warnings that we have been giving.

For Senator McKiernan's benefit, perhaps I should remind him of what Mr Bill Hayden said this morning on ABC radio, to expand on his comments, made the previous night, that Australia is living in the most difficult and threatening economic climate since World War II, and in which he warned of a new dark age of stagnation and protectionism in the world. When questioned about that this morning, he said:

The longer the present undesirable international economic situation continues and continues to worsen with large trade imbalances, positively on the side of Japan and Germany and negatively on the side of the United States, the more worried one must become at the prospect becoming almost a certainty.
He continued:

The collapse in world stock exchanges, the collapse in the American dollar, the way that has affected us-striking us down with it and the general loss of confidence in economic activity as a result of that. Investors are disturbed at what has happened and will suspend in many cases important investment programs.

That is here in Australia; that is the result of what is happening overseas. Let me now read the crucial bit to the non-worriers such as Senator McKiernan who say, `What, me worry?'. It sounds like the words from an American comic strip. Mr Hayden said:
That means there could be a slowdown in economic activity. That is why it is urgent that action be taken . . .
It is urgent that action be taken. It is urgent that action be taken by the Treasurer of this country to change what is now an extraordinarily inappropriate Budget. Mr Hayden went on:
We are living in easily the most difficult and threatening international economic climate that we have lived in in any stage since WW II.
The interviewer said:
. . . an economic dark ages, is that not being over dramatic?
Mr Hayden responded:
It is an appropriate figure of speech.

Although Mr Hayden warned us of the need for action, only 11 days ago Mr Keating told the Economic Planning Advisory Council (EPAC), `We see no role for any precipitate action'. `Precipitate' in that context means doing anything. Mr Keating went on to make one of the most extraordinary remarks that I believe any Treasurer of this nation has ever made. He said:
This view is reinforced by the fact that the outlays and receipts estimates for this year remain firmly on track.

He did not say the deficit outcome; he said both parts of it, that `the outlays and receipts estimates for this year remain firmly on track'. That is impossible. I believe that this is a deliberate attempt to mislead the Australian people because I do not believe that Mr Keating could possibly be so unaware of reality as to believe it himself.

Let us have a look at the evidence of how much these revenue and expenditure figures can possibly be on track by looking at the Budget forecasts. Let us start off with the Budget forecast about the trade weighted index (TWI). The Budget forecasts, all of our revenue and expenditure estimates, are based on the fact that the Government expected the trade weighted index-that is, Australia's relationship with the world currencies-to be at the 56 level, not around the 51 level that now seems to be with us despite hiccups after today's balance of payments figure which is still a disastrous $1.2 billion but which was surprisingly and extraordinarily welcomed by some elements of the market which obviously will be reviewing their attitudes later, I would imagine downwards. But at this stage we have a situation where there has been almost a 10 per cent fall in the trade weighted index of our currency.

Let us look at what the Government said last December would happen if there were even a 5 per cent depreciation of the currency against the trade weighted index. I refer honourable senators to the December 1986 report on the Forward Estimates of Budget outlays. That document forecast that a 5 per cent depreciation in the trade weighted index would bring a total response, as it was called; in other words, a rise in the Government deficit of about $400m. We have now had about a 10 per cent depreciation and the indications are that the Australian dollar could-it may not, but it could-deteriorate further. What would be the consequences of a 10 per cent depreciation of the Australian dollar against the TWI? The reality is that the deficit would be almost $800m, $0.8 billion. When I said that it looked like this Budget was going to be wrong by about $1 billion, 80 per cent of that being wrong emerges from one parameter change, one simple incident-the fact that our relationship with the currencies of our trading partners has deteriorated so significantly. It needs only another couple of hundred million dollars of being wrong to get over the billion dollar error that this Government now faces. I believe that that is inevitable unless, as I said, the Government fiddles it with some Reserve Bank of Australia profits. But that does not get Mr Keating off the hook because Mr Keating has said that both outlays and receipts estimates for this year remain firmly on track. That is absolute bunkum.

Let us have a look at some of the other parameter changes that have taken place. Mr Keating was looking to the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development gross national product (GNP)-that is, the GNP of our major trading partners-going up by almost 4 per cent. The reality is that the latest estimates are all predicting a fall in world economic activity. According to his forecasts, world-wide inflation was supposed to go up a bit; clearly it will fall as a result of what has happened over the last two months on world markets. He said in the Budget that interest rates would be up a bit and that the Budget was based on that expectation. The fact is that they will be down a bit; in fact, in some areas down a lot. Then he said that the Budget is based on the assumption of monetary policy remaining appropriately firm throughout 1987-88. But, of course, the reality is that because of the fall in the markets there will be increasing pressure on the Government to make monetary policy a lot looser and to tighten fiscal policy. So these factors will have a clear and significant impact on what will happen in the Budget.

It was estimated in the Budget that there would be something like a 5 per cent increase in business investment. There is just no chance of that. Who knows what it will be? Certainly all the evidence we have seen is that business investment is not being sustained at the sort of rate the Government would expect. The forecast for non-farm gross domestic product is 3 per cent. The comments that I have heard from most of the leading experts in this area have been that at best we could perhaps look to 2 per cent this year. All those things have an enormous impact on what the Budget deficit will be. They will certainly have an impact on both the outlays and receipts sides of the Budget.

According to the forecasts, average weekly earnings will go up 6 1/2 per cent. But it now appears that the second tier is taking longer to come in than expected. As I understand it, only about a quarter of those seeking that second tier will have their claim resolved by the end of this year. If average earnings do not increase at the rate forecast in the Budget, neither will income tax collections. Clearly that will affect the revenue side of the Budget again.

The consumer price index, along with the deflator, is forecast at 7 per cent. The forecast I have been seeing lately put it at around 8 per cent. That means there will be an increase in government costs. As with average earnings, this rise will take place without an appropriate or comparable rise in government revenues. We have a current account deficit which is forecast to be $11 1/2 billion. There is no chance whatsoever of that being achieved, particularly after the recent problems that will impinge on our capacity to export commodities. Certainly, the more cheerful comments around the place are that it might blow out to $12 1/2 billion-that is, about $1 billion or $1 1/4 billion more than the Budget forecasts. It seems to me that here we have the reality of a situation that Mr Paul Keating is not prepared to face.

Let us see what is going on behind things such as today's balance of payments figure. No matter how temporary the good news might appear to be on exports, or even apparent good news on imports on a seasonally adjusted basis, the reality is that we face serious problems in a downturn in the world economy in trying to sell commodities on which we are still massively dependent. We certainly face import problems if-and it is a very big `if' at this stage-there is any renewal of investment in Australia. The items of equipment we would need to support that investment would have to come largely from overseas and that would knock our import levels.

But the most sinister item is the total income debits-the flowing of money out of Australia in order to service our continually booming levels of international debt. This Government has not instituted effective policies to halt the worsening of our huge debt levels because of our continued massive balance of payments and current account deficits which today were shown to be $1.2 billion for the latest month-an unsustainable level. The Government cannot possibly pretend that its policies are having a serious and significant impact when underlying all this is the one major, serious and worsening problem of our debt bill.

In the last three months our income debits have increased by 20 per cent over the same period for the previous year. As our dollar deteriorates-and it just has-that bill will keep going up because our borrowings in the currencies from overseas will increase in size relative to the Australian dollar and the cost of paying that interest bill will continue to increase. I believe that a 20 per cent rise in the cost of servicing our indebtedness is the hidden disaster that the Treasurer did not talk about in his Press release about today's less worse than expected balance of payments figures.

Let us look at what independent commentators, not members of the Opposition, are saying about the inappropriate nature of this Budget. Many of those commentators are people who initially welcomed the Government's Budget. They believed it to be responsible economically and skilful politically, and this was referred to by Senator McKiernan. It was certainly skilful politically because it pulled the wool over their eyes and it was aimed at pulling the wool over the eyes of the Australian people. In fact, that wool is still being pulled with great enthusiasm by Mr Keating. As I have said, he addressed EPAC only 11 days ago and he said that the Budget parameters would not change.

Let us have a look at the things he said in that speech because, quite frankly, some of the content of that speech suggests that his conclusion had nothing to do with the points he was making in his speech. In referring to the collapse in the share market and so on he said:
This decline in private sector wealth, as well as the uncertainty about the economic outlook, can be expected to result in a slowing in the growth of private consumption expenditure.

If that takes place it will mean that the Government will make less money out of sales tax collections, for example. The collapse in the share market has meant that non-pay as you earn (PAYE) tax collections will certainly be less than the Government had budgeted for. The forecast in the Budget Papers was for an 11 per cent increase in provisional tax. Of course, provisional tax is being paid only by non-PAYE taxpayers. I assume that the changed economic environment will make that forecast look very hairy indeed. Mr Keating went on:
There is also likely to be an impact on investment from the share price slump.

Okay; we have a few negatives here from Mr Keating. He said that apart from what happens to commodity prices-and there is universal acceptance that commodity prices will be badly affected by the world slump, not simply by a recession but also by any slowdown in world economic growth which is now regarded as inevitable by almost every commentator-some slowing in demand for Australia's exports can be expected in coming quarters, as world growth begins to moderate. Actually, he grasped at a straw then and said that that was not all too bad because the effect on imports into Australia will be a slowing in growth and that domestic demand will be working to offset a weaker outlook for exports. In other words, the Australian economy will get so bad that it does not matter that we will not be able to export much because we will not have any money to import anything anyway. The reality is that both those factors will affect the Federal budget and make the Budget that we are debating today increasingly irrelevant and increasingly inappropriate in terms of dealing with the real problems that we now have.

The Treasurer admitted that there will be a period of slightly more adverse monthly balance of payments results. He said that that would not be too bad because it will increase our competitiveness. While that happens it means that our costs go up and our inflation rate goes up because the cost of our imports will go up if our dollar continues to devalue. Mr Keating said:
. . . the . . . depreciation in trade weighted terms is appropriate . . .

That is the depreciation that I have already pointed out. It would increase the Budget deficit by $800m-a Budget that Mr Keating still goes around pretending that he has balanced. Of course, this is absolute nonsense. He confirmed what I said earlier about the expectation that average wages will grow a little more slowly in 1987-88 than was expected at Budget time. As I have said, that means that the revenue from tax collections will not be as great as the Government had hoped for. Yet Mr Keating still says that the Budget revenue and expenditure sides remain firmly on track. I wonder which direction we are going in. I wonder where the track is leading us. Is it leading us, once again, to a statement, such as the one Mr Keating made last year, about a banana republic? Having assured us that everything was on track he then slipped on that track on his banana.

I believe that the Government will be forced belatedly to take the sort of action that it should take. What is that action? A recent report by the National Australia Bank, in its monthly summary, entitled Australia's economic revival-is it real?, states not that we should do things, but that we must do things. It states:
In these circumstances we must:
- restrain domestic economic activity below the OECD average. Further cuts in government spending and an overall budget surplus may well be necessary to accommodate lower interest rates . . .

The Government, instead of doing that, is still looking to growth a little ahead of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development average. But we must restrain it, as the National Australia Bank quite rightly says. The second point the bank makes is:
continue to curb growth in overall wages . . .
That is self-evident if we are to try to compete. The bank states further that we must continue:
. . . the process of deregulation, removing restrictive trade barriers and achieving further efficiencies in the public sector;
I think that is a polite word for `privatise'. The bank then said that we need:
. . . a higher level of domestic savings to wind back the nation's level of overseas debt.

We can ask: What is the Government doing to bring these about? The answer is nothing. The Government has not changed its political economic stance. `Everything is on track', says Paul Keating. Senator McKiernan tells us not to worry.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —What we need is appropriate action to stop the rot. As I mentioned before dinner, Mr Keating is still pretending that everything is right. As the Sydney Morning Herald columnist Ross Gittins described it, he is doing his Pollyanna act, pretending that nothing is wrong. But there are things that must be done urgently. As Syntec, one of the most respected analysts of the Australian economic scene, pointed out in its recent issue:

SPEECH.PARA: If the Government wants to avoid an excessive fall in the $A and an excessive rise in interest rates, it will have to act on fiscal and wages policy.
Provided it does so, the fall in the $A can probably be confined to 10 to 15 per cent in Trade Weighted terms.

As I pointed out earlier, the sensitivity index in the Government's Forward Estimates publication indicates that that would have a worsening impact on the Budget deficit of between $0.8 billion and $1.2 billion. It will be limited to that only if the Government takes appropriate action now. What are the prospects of it doing so? Of course, Mr Keating still says that everything is on track and that there is no need to take any action.

The only people in this Parliament who have been pointing the way, dramatising what should be done, are those in the Opposition. We have been consistently giving the lead to the Government on what it should be doing. This Government has consistently dragged the chain in responding appropriately to the sorts of problems we face. In every major instance of economic policy in the last four years the Opposition has recommended what should be done and the Government has reluctantly, at last, come to the same conclusion, though it has only half done it, and done it badly. From this Government's first Budgets, which involved massive overspending, to the latest Budget, which met what appeared to be the needs of the time but which we have demonstrated leaves no room for manoeuvre and no scope in case of disaster, we have consistently pointed out how the Government could and should be doing a better job. Syntec states:

The Budget strategy of attempting to run moderately faster real growth than our major metropolitan economies and the associated gradual adjustment of our current account and external debt position is not viable.
I stress that the Government's Budget strategy is not viable. It may have barely got by in September, in the Indian summer, but it certainly is not viable now. Syntec goes on:

We are therefore faced with the formidable task of seeking to more rapidly close the gap between local and international wages and inflation . . . The pressure to do so is being increased by a falling Australian dollar, which will tend to push up prices.
Without further policy action-
that is, policy action the Opposition has been pressing for but which this Government has refused to supply-
inflation here is likely to stall at around 7 per cent while world inflation-already significantly lower than this-is likely to fall back.
In such a setting the Government cannot responsibly agree to carry on with existing wages policy as if nothing has happened.
Growth in incomes and demand here has to be slowed as part of the process of faster adjustment of our external imbalances.
It concludes on this note:
The Government strategy of trying to have Australia grow as fast or faster than the major economies is a recipe for disaster now.

That is an appropriate summation of this Budget that we are debating. It is a recipe for disaster now. it is based on a situation which no longer exists. We now have lower growth, higher inflation, a lower currency, a higher balance of payments deficit, a higher debt level and in fact a far worse outlook for our commodities. In the context of these major changes, the Government must change the steps it is taking.

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate on the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1987-88, Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1987-88 and Appropriation Bill (No. 2) 1987-88 is an appropriate time to comment on and indeed to censure the Government for its incredible financial mismanagement of the Australian economy. I could not believe it last week when the arrogant Mr Keating abused Mr Whitlam for mismanaging the economy for the three tragic years that Labor was running this country. It showed the hide of the man and his inability to know what is going on. The Whitlam fools were children compared with the Keating fools. What Keating has done in four years is of a magnitude beyond what Whitlam did in the 1970s.

SPEECH.PARA: Sadly, hundreds of thousands of ordinary defenceless Australians will pay for the mismanagement that this Government has inflicted upon the Australian community. TALK.START.PARA: —What has been the consequence of all this mismanagement? The first thing that has happened is that the bottom has fallen out of the value of the Australian dollar. When the Australian Labor Party came into power the Australian dollar was worth 206.99 yen. Today it is worth 92.40 yen.
—Disgraceful.

—As is suggested, it is a drop that is quite disgraceful. The currency has depreciated by more than a half. The Government always cites the value of the dollar against the United States dollar. The erosion in the value of the US dollar has been an intentional part of the United States Treasury's policy and so the diminution in the value of our dollar is less vis-a-vis that of the US dollar. Even so, the Australian dollar was worth $US0.869 in March 1983 and today it is worth $US0.6818. But the test by which we have to measure our economy is the value of our dollar as against the hard currencies, the yen and the Deutsche mark. In March 1983 our dollar bought 2.0941 Deutsche marks; today it will buy 1.1485 Deutsche marks. If we take the Swiss franc, another hard currency, in March 1983 our dollar bought 1.7991 Swiss francs and today it will buy 0.9389 Swiss francs. We can see that the judgment passed by the world on the economic policies of the Labor Party is utterly catastrophic. Against the hard currencies which are the benchmark by which our efforts have to be measured, one can see that the Australian dollar is now worth less than half of what it was when the Labor Party came into power. That is a real measure of the confidence that the hard-headed business minds around the world have in what this Government is doing to our economy.

SPEECH.PARA: The practicalities of that might be lost on the man in the street, but they are very real and very severe. It means that, since our currency is now worth under half of what it was when Labor came into office, we are paying twice as much in the interest payments on the huge borrowings that the Government has generated. It means that the debt repayment has to be paid with dollars which are worth half of what they were worth when Labor came into power.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is about $1 billion for every cent against the American dollar.

—That is quite right. On the other side, it means that everything in Australia is for sale at less than half price. My home and Senator Maguire's home could be sold to a Japanese, German or Swiss buyer for under half price. That is why they are coming in and buying up our homes--
—We stopped it.

—Did the honourable senator say that the Government stopped it? I am astonished at that. There are so many loopholes that one could drive a double-decker bus through them. What Mr Keating did was done with his usual skill and success! The restrictions which he brought in-one could well argue that there was no real case to bring them in, which I would accept, because the real problem is the low value of the currency-were absolutely toothless tigers. They have not stopped anyone from overseas buying houses, particularly the Japanese at present. That has a real impact on the Australian community. I have been to some house auctions recently and I have seen the effect of that in Brisbane's suburban areas. The operations of Japanese buyers in those areas has probably put at least 10 per cent on to the price of houses. It does not just affect houses. We have the same problem with businesses. Any business that is profitable is for sale to an overseas buyer at half price. That is a consequence of the Government's economic policies.

SPEECH.PARA: What has the Government done about this? I can tell you very simply, Mr Acting Deputy President, that it has done nothing. We have seen a great example of bovine inactivity from these great financial gurus. Mr Keating attacks Mr Whitlam and Senator Walsh attacks Mr Fraser. Mr Hawke comes home, after his last big junket, where he visited such crucial countries for the Australian economy as Ireland and Yugoslavia, and goes to bed sick with a headache for eight days straight. He could not stand the scene when he got back. That is some achievement, is it not, from a man of steel and principle! The Opposition will be moving an amendment which is in four parts and I have much pleasure in supporting it. The amendment reads in part:
(1) this Bill is part of a continuing pattern of failure by the Hawke Government to face up to the need for adequate and timely adjustment of the economy;
(2) this failure by the Hawke Government has heightened Australia's vulnerability to changes in world economic conditions at this time of crisis on world financial markets;

(3) because the Government has squandered time and resources while persistently running Australia into massive debt, our national economic options are now so narrowly limited as to largely deprive us of independent options; and

(4) the Government no longer has the scope to protect jobs, to stop the prospective rise in unemployment, to stem the continuing rise in numbers of Australians living in poverty or to protect the position of families more generally;

We have only to go back a few months to the meretricious claims of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) when he was on the hustings for the election, beating his breast and saying, `I will abolish poverty. There will be no child poverty in Australia by the end of the next term of Parliament'. If ever there was a King Canute-type statement it was poor Hawke's statement about eliminating poverty. There will be more poverty in Australia when he is bundled out of office at the end of this term than when he came in. Again, it is the ordinary Australians who will pay the price of that, not Mr Hawke or his friends.

Our problems come because we have a big spending, big taxing government. It spends too much on non-essentials. At a personal level one can see that in the way in which Mr Hawke and Mr Brown-Senator Puplick's friend!-go touring around the world at vast expense, as well as the blowout in expenditure on the new Parliament House. We are spending too much on non-essentials and not enough on essentials.

The department about which I wish to talk now is the Department of Defence. It is suffering more than any other department. It has not been as badly off, in terms of its capabilities, since 1945. We are not spending enough on defence. What we do spend is not being spent wisely. We are very rapidly reaching a situation in which, despite the billions of dollars we have spent on equipment, we will have no one there who knows how to use it and use it effectively, so it all becomes pointless.

We live in a region of changing circumstances. I have warned the Government on that for years, but it persists with its blinkered vision. It does not look at what is going on outside Australia. I do not think that it even reads newspapers. We now live in a region that is characterised by the highest degree of instability we have seen for many years. The latest example of that is Fiji.

Before I look at some of the details of the region, I want to look at the major influences. The major power in the region has been the United States. We are looking at an historical change point with respect to the United States. Last week we saw the resignation of the Secretary of the Department of Defense, Caspar Weinberger. Caspar Weinberger fought in the Pacific in 1942 as a United States marine. He had a major interest in the Pacific as opposed to the European theatre which influenced United States policy. At the same time, the United States Navy, which has always been Pacific oriented rather than Atlantic oriented, had as its Secretary Mr Lehman, who was a very powerful advocate for the development of the Navy. So in the recent past we have seen a very strong United States defence position with respect to the Pacific. Mr Lehman has gone and Mr Weinberger has resigned. Mr Weinberger's successor is Mr Carlucci. I believe that we will see a shift in emphasis of the United States from the Pacific to the European theatre, particularly as the disarmament talks get closer to finality and the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation powers get more concerned about their own security vis-a-vis the Iron Curtain forces. Coupled with this shift in emphasis we will have a rundown, a decline, to some degree of United States military capability in the area as the deficit is reduced in the United States domestic Budget.

Hand in hand with this we see an increasing Soviet presence. The Soviets have developed a very powerful base in Cam Ranh Bay, which is very close to the Philippines and the American resources at Subic and Clark Field. The Soviet presence has been expanding into our region in a slow, steady way for a matter of years. The fishing agreements are well known to honourable senators. I see in today's newspaper that the Soviets have declared an intention to join the Asian Development Bank. That will increase their presence and influence in the commercial activities of this region. So we have a potential rundown in the United States capability and a solid, steady growth of the Soviet presence.

Dealing with particular countries, we had the events in Fiji. Fiji, in the direction in which it is moving, looks as if it will diminish its involvement with Australia. It seems to be setting up new alliances and new trading agreements. It will almost certainly introduce new countries-countries that have not been active in the South Pacific-to this region. While Fiji is a small country, it is the largest population group in that part of the South Pacific. It has an importance as a consequence of that. The government and future of New Caledonia are no further down the track than they were some years ago. There is a degree of unpredictability about Vanuatu. Coupled with New Guinea, there is a position developing in international affairs where there is a recognisable Melanesian view on events and that is a view which, at the moment, Australia seems to have very little influence on in any way at all.

New Zealand still persists with the Lange Government and the economic debate in the last few weeks at the Labour Party conference there shows every indication that, if possible, the Lange Government has lurched even further to the left. In the Philippines, the Aquino regime seems to be set into an irreversible decline and we have to contemplate the prospect for the first time that there might be a secure Soviet presence in Cam Ranh Bay and no presence of the Americans in Subic and Clark Field. The social disorder in Malaysia keeps getting worse and, if there is a breakdown of social order in Malaysia, we can expect the Indonesian Government to take an interest in what is going on. In other words, we have all the signs of considerable trouble in the region in which we live. The point I make to the Government is that, just as we had a stock market collapse of great rapidity with no warning signs beforehand, we could have precisely the same situation in a military sense where we will have no warning time. Whilst it may not be a massive military event that we are involved in, it will come without any warning and we will have to use what we have at present, and what we have at present is not adequate in any way.

Australia must protect its national interests and in this region those national interests cover a variety of topics. Our first consideration is the protection of our own people. Australians are great travellers: there are a lot of them in Fiji and in Papua New Guinea. There are a lot of them scattered around the South Pacific region. In any sort of emergency with a government in any of those places our first obligation is to go in to secure those Australian nationals if their lives are at risk. We simply do not have the capability to do that. The second general requirement on us is to have the ability to project some force into the region. There is a very great difference between being seen to have the ability to project force into the region and actually using the force. If we are seen to have the capacity, that does not leave a vacuum and the force does not have to be used. But we simply have no capacity now to project force into the region.

Before I talk about some of our inadequacies in the few minutes remaining to me, I should say that the very first thing we have to know is what is going on in the region. The events of the last 12 months have demonstrated in the most dramatic way that we have very poor intelligence. I am sick and tired of going to meetings of the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade and having people appearing before the Committee boasting about how well they know what is going on. The Australian Government was not advised before the first Fijian coup. What was even worse, the second coup caught the Government totally unprepared. The Cabinet did not know and no one in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade knew, and that is inexcusable. We should have known what was going to happen. Until we get a decent intelligence service in the region all else is in vain.

The Australian defence forces are inadequately managed, inadequately structured, inadequately prepared, and inadequately nurtured-for want of a better word. The management is quite inadequate. Prior to 1974 we had a Minister for Defence, a Minister for the Army, a Minister for the Navy, a Minister for Air and a Minister for Supply. We had five Ministers coping with this area. We had an Army board, an Air board and a Navy board controlling the three Services. Clearly the segments had to be consolidated into an Australian Defence Force. The management needed to be improved. A Foreign Affairs officer by the name of Tange was appointed by the Whitlam Government to draft the blueprint for the new Department of Defence. What Mr Tange provided, albeit it in good faith, is really totally inadequate. We have now a single ministry of Defence. I have no quarrel with that or with the abolition of the boards. The Government set up a Chief of the Defence Force Staff, CDFS, who is now Chief of the Defence Force, CDF. It provided parity between the civilian Secretary to the Department and the Chief of the Defence Force. So far so good, but the system does not work. While the Defence Act provided for a rough parity between the civilian and the service components of the Department, in reality the practice is very, very different: all the plums go to the civilians. Whilst it is unquestionably a basic democratic principle in all democratic countries-which we support-that there is civilian control of the defence forces, that means control by the Parliament, by the Minister answerable to the Cabinet; it does not mean what we have in this country, which is control of the Defence Force by the bureaucracy.

The Chief of the Defence Force is the principal adviser on military matters to the Minister. We ask him to defend the country but we deny him control over the resources that he needs to do so. He does not have control over the force structure. He does not have control over equipment. He does not have the means of supporting either the forces or the equipment. They are essentially under civilian control. If ever there was a way of ensuring without a shadow of a doubt that we are going to have a disaster on our hands, it is by asking someone to do something then denying that person the resources and control over the resources which are critical in carrying out that task. Of course, that was the position that the British forces were in at the time of the Crimean war. We all know what happened in the Crimean war. I can tell the Senate with absolute certainty that in the post-Tange era we are very lucky that we have not had a defence emergency. Had we had to use the Australian defence forces we would have suffered the same fate as the British forces did in the Crimea because the system simply will not work.

We have over 90 committees in the Department of Defence. Nothing can get done until it is locked into the system for years and then nothing can be done if it is not approved by the civilian component because the Secretary alone is responsible for providing policy advice to the Minister. All the key committees in the Department of Defence-the Defence Committee, chaired by the Secretary; the Defence Force Development Committee, which is another very important committee, chaired by the Secretary; the consultative group, chaired by Deputy Secretary B; the Force Structure Committee, chaired by Deputy Secretary B; the Defence Source Definition Committee-are chaired by civilians. I do not need to go any further on that but we just cannot go on this way. Until that is changed and authority is vested in the uniformed services, with the Secretary and the civilian component providing advice and expertise where relevant, we will not get a decent Defence Force.

The second point I raised on inadequacies related to the force structure. We are labouring under the doctrine at the moment of low level threats with some poorly armed, harassing force coming ashore. I find that absolutely impossible to believe. Public opinion internationally is such that no nation would send 50 or 120 poorly armed troops to invade someone else's sovereignty unless it would achieve something. One hundred and fifty people would not be able to capture a country. The present Defence Force structure is not realistic but it is what the Australian Labor Party wants. Australian Labor Party members do not want a strong Defence Force which will be able to deter. They have this belief-and it is a touching belief-that if they are nice and polite and demonstrably seen to have no capability to harm anyone else, no one will harm them. I wish that were true, but unfortunately life is not like that. The old pacifist doctrines still run very strong beneath the surface in the Labor Party. Because of that we have the present force structure designed to cope with this low threat scenario.

As I said before, we do have essential interests in the region. We have to be able to project power into the geographical area around us. I would argue that the invasion scenario is the very lowest of our priorities. We need to project and to be able to get our nationals out of any country in the region if there are problems. Most importantly, we do not want any power vacuums in the region leaving an opportunity for someone else to come in. All we have at the moment is a very limited strike capability of the Air Force, a very limited submarine capability of the Navy, and almost nothing for the Army.

Some of the basic things we need to correct relate to intelligence. We need to know what is going on in a military sense. We need an airborne warning and control system capability, an air and surface surveillance capability, and command and control function. We need a transport capability, an air and a sea lift capability. One of the great tragedies, as I said some time ago, is that in 1985 we abandoned the amphibious squadron. The Chief of Naval Staff at the time, Admiral Hudson, found this to be the softest option to take. He was told to cut his expenditure and his manpower, so he disbanded the amphibious squadron.

If we are to operate in the region at all, we need to be able to bring in heavy equipment and troops by sea. This was demonstrated on a small scale at the Diamond Dollar exercise held last month on Cape York. The absence of any amphibious capability is absolutely crippling for us. The Government, instead of redressing this failure which it created years ago, has gone on with all of the nonsense regarding the new Anzac ship. Navy, during Estimates committee hearings, had no idea what it wants that ship to do, except that it wants it to cost $250m. I guess it does not want amphibious landing craft. They are not very good venues for cocktail parties and they certainly would not look very good on a calendar. But the fact is that they are what we need. We do not need a $250m surface ship for which the Navy does not have any idea what sorts of weapons fit it wants.

The third point I raised was inadequate preparation. Again, this gets back to the doctrine that we will have 10 years warning time. That is absolute nonsense. We must have forces that are ready to go. The only force that can go tonight, within an hour or two's warning, is the Air Force, and that could not be sustained for more than a day or two because we are not keeping any war stocks of munitions in the country. Even the simple things that the Army requires, such as boots, webbing and camouflage clothing, are in desperately short supply and what it has is poor and inadequate. The camouflage smocks were ready to go into service-again, after years of delay-in 1983, but four years later, under this Government, they are still not on issue. I mentioned war stocks of ammunition. We simply have no war stocks of munitions or missiles of any size at all. Our capability is measured in days, certainly not in years.

The final point is that we have an inadequately nurtured Defence Force. That can be seen by the resignation rates that are now running at record levels. I must comment on the sophistry of this Government. Just as a strike is an industrial dispute, we now find that a resignation from the armed services is a separation. For goodness sake, let us call a spade a spade. If we can recognise the problem, maybe we can be shamed into doing something about it. But to continue to refer to separations, as if this were some sort of hiving off that did not matter, is absolutely nonsensical and indefensible.

People are leaving the defence forces because they know that this Government does not respect what they do. Sure, pay is bad. Sure, they are working long hours, they are living in rotten housing, their children are suffering from an educational point of view and their pay and allowances have not kept pace with the rest of the economy. All of those things must be fixed. But the key point is that they know at the end of the day that the Australian Labor Party is the old pacifist party that it always was, that wanted to see the Defence Force disbanded or reduced to token status. That is the psychology behind the massive resignation rates. That is why there must be a change in what the Government is doing.

Just as the Government does not understand the economy and has driven the value of the dollar down to half the value that it was when it came to power, so it does not understand the defence needs of this country. It thinks that all it needs to do in both fields is to take a few surveys, get some golden tongued public relations people to tell a few mistruths about what is going on and everything will be all right. But at the end of the day the Government, just as it was caught out in regard to the economy, will also be caught out in the field of defence. It cannot keep running away from the truth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Devlin Sen A.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening the Senate is debating three Bills-the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1987-88, Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1987-88 and Appropriation Bill (No. 2) 1987-88. Debate on these Bills is, of necessity, wide-ranging and senators have the opportunity to explore and debate matters of particular importance to their States. The matter I raise tonight is indeed of importance to my State of Tasmania. I refer to job creation and job retention in forest-based industries in Tasmania. Job creation and retention is a task confronting governments around the world. Areas where employment potential is not being maximised must be explored and policies adjusted to make the most of any employment opportunities.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the most controversial issues at the moment in Tasmania is the question of what direction Tasmania's forest-based industries should take. I believe that this industry offers one of the most neglected areas for improved employment in Tasmania. I will address this point in my speech. Australian Bureau of Statistics figures reveal that for every 10,000 cubic metres of logs consumed each year by woodchip export companies, 13 jobs will be created-directly, indirectly and induced-whereas the same volume of timber would produce 84 jobs in the sawmilling industry and 109 jobs in the paper industry. Obviously, therefore, to maximise employment in the forest-based industries, it is essential that any material suitable for sawmilling be used for that purpose and, wherever possible, woodchips be used to produce paper in Tasmania rather than being exported overseas to be made into paper by foreigners.

While it is certainly true that integrated forest harvesting is certainly the best means of exploiting our forest resources, the integration should be such that sawmillers are seen to have the first rights to all millable material. Integration is preferable because it overcomes the practices that used to occur when sawmillers selectively logged forest areas. Now, with integrated logging, the areas are logged and regenerated. However, in this process it also appears that many millable logs are being lost.

Clearly, there is a need to provide incentives for operators, contractors and companies to maximise sawlog yield. In a logging operation two operatives are closely introduced-the faller who identifies the standing tree as a potential sawlog and the landing man who dresses and cross cuts the log. To treat a sawlog to transportable stage requires skill, care and time not demanded in the preparation of the pulp or chip logs. An incentive payment must be made to operators as a reward for their efforts. Likewise, the contractor must be suitably rewarded. This may be activated by either additional payment or a change of handling methods, resulting in reduced handling costs. For example, if contractors were permitted to grade and mark sawlogs, this would obviate the delay of waiting for a Forestry Commission officer to do so and thus avoid multiple log handling at landings.

An additional cost saving method would be the elimination of sawlog volume measurements. Sawlogs, like all other logs, should be measured by weight. As all log trucks today are fitted with integrated scales, this is a practical method of log measurement. Single handling at landings and log measurement by weight are cost saving devices which will lead to an increased contribution margin for contractors, thus providing incentive without adding to industry cost.

Chip companies have a disincentive to encourage production of sawlogs due to bad debt write-off to supplied sawmills. This also applies to contractors who supply direct to sawmills. A solution exists in eliminating badly run sawmills either by upgrading management and operating skills or by causing the closure of the mill. Australia is increasingly competing on the domestic market against overseas producers, especially in regard to North American softwood. Today's environment does not protect the inefficient and it is not in anybody's interest to allow and even encourage the large companies to prop up uneconomical sawmill operators. Where chip companies are adequately compensated for sawlogs produced in the pursuit of chip logs the incentive to do so will exist and, consequently, saw log recovery will rise.

Portions of chip logs frequently are of sawlog grade and are able to be recovered. It is of interest that the wood chip plant proposed to be established by Huon Forest Products contains a flitch mill for recovery of sawlog portions of chip grade logs. Clearly, this is an option open to all wood chip and pulp mills. Clearly this represents an added cost of production and cost offsets need to be sought, for example, in the form of royalty reduction. It is estimated that between 4 per cent and 10 per cent of all wood chipped at the Associated Pulp and Paper Mills (APPM) Long Reach plant would be suitable for sawmilling. Given that one million tonnes of wood is chipped each year at Long Reach this means that between 50,000 and 100,000 tonnes of millable wood is being chipped. These figures could be considered indicative, perhaps even conservative, in terms of the percentage of millable material that is chipped in Tasmania generally.

It is interesting to note only recently the Kauri Timber Co. Ltd, which does not have a woodchip export licence, announced that it would spend around $1.6m to facilitate utilising category 2 sawlogs. The company estimated it would be able to obtain between 20 per cent and 25 per cent of sawn boards from these logs. Similar installations are needed for woodchipping plants to recover millable material for use by the more labour-intensive sawmills at Wiltshire and Triabunna. APPM does have secondary sorting processes. However, more modernisation, particularly at Long Reach, is needed.

One of the main problems that needs remedying is that when trees are first cut down the logging contractors are not offered sufficient incentive to separate sawmilling material from chipping wood. Often to do so is a very time-consuming process which requires a sufficient excess profit to include such practices. In the absence of sufficient incentives many good millable logs are being cut in half for transporting thereby being ruined for any use other than chipping, even if the logs were later to go through a recovery mill. A number of points emerge from this. The first point is that while these practices continue resources that could be used in sawmills are being chipped. Thus jobs are being lost. The second point is that if appropriate incentives were offered contractors would spend longer recovering millable material with the result that new jobs would be created in the logging stage.

Another issue relating to forest-based industries that has major ramifications for employment creation is that of the types of forest management practices being adopted. Different types of practices are available. However, the one which seems to have the greatest merit is intensive forest management. Intensive management necessitates greater tendering of regenerated areas during their growth, often entailing several stages of thinning. The benefit of intensive management is that regenerated areas reach maturity more quickly thus producing timber of large size and increasing the yield of a given area. While the cost of intensive management is about triple the cost of less intensive management practices, the benefit merits the additional expense. As well as minimising the amount of Tasmania's forest that has to be used to sustain the industry, the other great advantage of intensive management is in regard to the jobs it would create.

As forecast earlier, there should perhaps be a fourth wood classification-the classification of fuel wood. Forests, particularly natural and regrowth forests, contain wood resource material which is both dead and alive, vertical and horizontal. Present wood use also requires a further classification which is wood rendered not usable due to carbon impurity. Present requirements for saw, chip and pulp logs demand carbon-free logs. It is a requirement of the Tasmanian forest practices code that the maximum harvestable resource left on the forest floor as residue does not exceed five tonnes per hectare. In my view this has led, firstly, to the harvesting of non-carbonised wood, for example, wood less than 20 centimetres in diameter which it is impracticable to bark before chipping at the chip mills. Small wood harvesting is expensive and the bark content adds to the impurity level of the export chip product. Secondly, there is a total forest residue far in excess of five tonnes per hectare, in some instances amounting to hundreds of tonnes per hectare where carbon impurity is high, because allowable residue is related to present marketable material.

At present the level of harvesting in Tasmania's forest residue is estimated at two million tonnes per annum. This resource cannot be ignored. Much of the resource is not suitable for present mill usage so consideration should be given to alternative uses such as fuel wood as an energy source for industry. Simple observation of domestic heating methods shows an economically driven move to wood heating. This has occurred in spite of inefficient solid fuel home heating systems. However, this system is now being redressed. High standards of emission control, especially in the United States of America, have led to highly efficient wood burning systems. Eucalypt, with a low ash content, particularly when burnt at a high temperature, is a highly efficient fuel.

Industry in Tasmania should be educated and encouraged to consider wood fuel as an energy substitute for electricity and, particularly, imported fossil fuel. Where necessary government should subsidise industry to change the system to solid fuel such as has occurred overseas, for example in Canada. There are many advantages to Tasmania in developing an industrial fuel market. Some such advantages are increased business opportunities, increased employment, reliable import replacement product, reduction in forest replanting costs, renewable resources and increased royalties. With proper co-ordination business opportunities could be created for harvesters and carters of solid wood fuel and for manufacturers of solid fuel burning systems. Obviously, employment opportunities would increase in tandem with such opportunities.

Tasmania imports its liquid fuel requirements at a price which appears not only uncontrollable but also scandalous. This applies both to petrol- eum products and natural gas. Liquid fuel costs about $300 per tonne, whereas solid wood fuel can be produced for about $30 per tonne. Given a fuel energy factor of about five, it would appear that solid wood fuel gathered from local forests would cost about half that of imported fuels. By cleaning up the forest floor a fuel wood industry could have the dual effect of reducing the cost of preparing harvested areas for replanting and adding to revenue royalty by using the same road facilities. Additional harvested wood will contribute to recovering the fixed costs of present production.

It is not suggested that the present residue of two million tonnes is indicative of the size of a solid fuel market. Domestic use stands at about half a million tonnes. An industrial market of about the same tonnage would make a significant contribution to the State's economy by increasing employment, recycling the energy dollar within the State and reducing the energy costs to industry and, ultimately, increasing competitiveness and possibly attracting new industry. Tasmania's forest-based industries are a classic example of the way in which job potential in Tasmania is not fully utilised. It is just the sort of area that we should be looking at improving.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last August the Treasurer (Mr Keating) brought down a Budget which, according to the Government and indeed a lot of people in the media, was a masterpiece because the Government, supposedly, had been able to cut its deficit to $27m. Ross Gittins of the Sydney Morning Herald was one of the few commentators who labelled the Budget as a Budget of wasted opportunities-a nothing Budget. He has been proved correct.
—Still in balance.

—Is Senator Maguire sure of that? Is it still in balance? I imagine that the honourable senator's interjection is very far from the truth. The Opposition was very critical in one specific area; that is, the Government's so-called cut which consisted of one-off asset sales. There were the $1 billion one-off asset sales and an additional $1,400m in taxes over and above the ceiling promised by Mr Hawke quite some time ago. In the Budget last August he overreached that promised ceiling by over $1,400m.

SPEECH.PARA: There were tremendous windfall profits from the Reserve Bank of Australia. Last year the figure was $2.6 billion. It is estimated this year to be $2.7 billion. This underlines the fact that the true Budget deficit is more like $2.5 billion, because I sincerely hope we do not expect the Reserve Bank to make similar windfall gains next year. Over the past 10 years the average profit of the Reserve Bank has been only about $600m. Unless things go really wrong once again with the Australian dollar and the Reserve Bank is forced to prop it up and so get these tremendous windfall profits, such a sum will not be realised again next year.

We all remember that volatile time when the Australian dollar dropped to an unprecedented low, other countries lost confidence in our economy and the situation was such that the Treasurer lost his cool and said that we were well on the way to being a banana republic. As I have said, the Opposition pointed out at Budget time that one-off sales such as asset sales, windfall Reserve Bank profits and rising taxes are not the way to go. Unless we have real cuts, the Government's expenditure next year will be the same and the Treasurer will be faced with the same problems he had this year. The true deficit will remain so long as it is paid for by one-off dollar profits. Year after year the Government will have to dream up bigger one-off dollar profits and bigger taxes. This was all said before the collapse in the market. How much more do the Opposition's warnings apply today? Following the market crash we know that growth will slow, the Government will not get its expected tax revenues and the Budget deficit will blow out purely because it was never anything but a false and phoney Budget deficit, one that relied entirely on one-off measures and additional taxes.

Today we have been told that the current account deficit is nearly $1.2 billion. Mr Hawke has said, `Well, that is not bad. It is better than expected and should be looked upon in that light'. This figure, of course, does not reflect the impact of the collapse-no doubt that will happen next year-so the figure is more serious than it appears even at the moment because Australia is continuing to borrow just to pay the interest on our foreign debt. If the Government does not heed the Opposition's warning and the warning from its own Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, it is being completely irresponsible. Let us look at what Senator Walsh has said, because he has been saying these things for some time. Last July, down in Hobart, he said:

I know some people believe that budget deficits don't matter. They do matter in the degree to which they lock in future expenditure. If we had a public debt interest payment, the same level of outlays as it was in 1982-
that, I might add, was the last Budget of the Fraser Government-

we would in this financial year have about $4 billion extra to either cut taxes, increase welfare spending or whatever else you wanted to do with it. But because we have run a sequence of high budget deficits, we are lumbered with a crippling public debt interest payment which restricts the ability of this Government and Governments for the foreseeable future, to deliver the programs they would like to deliver elsewhere.

That is how the Government's Finance Minister warned his own colleagues. The Government simply has to reduce its deficit. I am quite sure that Senator Walsh was not expecting one-off tax dollars to be used to reduce that deficit, nor was he expecting the one-off sales of Japanese property, the one-off sales totalling $1 billion that occurred in the May mini-Budget or a rise in taxes and he did not really anticipate the Reserve Bank's windfall profits, because he is reported to have said in his criticism of this year's Budget:
I'm worried that the Budget has been oversold and it will make the public and the Government complacent and think that we can slip back into our old slothful ways and we don't have to worry any more.
Why is not the Government listening to its Minister for Finance? Why is not the Government taking note of what Senator Walsh has been saying now for several years? He went on:
. . . if people were encouraged to spend rather than save, Australia would be sent further down the Argentinean road. If it goes much further, it could well be irretrievable.
Yet the Government ignores him. Senator Walsh is saying exactly the same things that the Opposition has been warning the Government about ever since it came to office. Senator Walsh said:

Certainly if there was another commodity price slide, the International Monetary Fund will be knocking on the door again. And I think we would all know what would happen to the welfare sector if we are pushed to that point. A country which has a high level of foreign debt and a continuing large current account deficit is a country which has few options.

Yet today, when the current account deficit comes out at nearly $1.2 billion, the Prime Minister says, `That is better than we expected. That is not bad. That is pretty good'. Why does he not listen? Why do not honourable senators opposite listen to their Minister for Finance?
Let us have a look at what has been the result of some of the economic rationalities of this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some 800,000 more jobs.

—We have just been told that the Government has created 800,000 more jobs. Ever since the Government has been in power it has merely kept up with the rate of increase in the population reaching the job age group. That is all, and every job that is taken up by the increase in population the Government says it has created. What absolute rubbish. Have a look at the long term unemployment rate and do not boast about it-it is absolutely appalling. I would not boast about the additional length of the long term unemployment if I were Senator Maguire.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us have a look at the bankruptcies that have occurred in the last few years. In 1984-85, there were 4,664. In 1985-86, the number went up to 5,539. In 1986-87 it went up to 7,495. Is that making lots more jobs? The Government is ruling over the highest number of bankruptcies in Australia's history and Government members are patting themselves on the back, and Mr Keating is telling us that the J-curve will soon take effect. We have the highest number of bankruptcies. What are the figures going to be next year, following on the market collapse, when there has been such an enormous jump between 1985-86 and 1986-87? I wonder what the figures for 1987-88 will be. So many small businesses have gone bankrupt.

As a result, there are many pressures on the family. Families are now considered as only needing support from the Government if they are low income earners. The middle income earners have been completely deserted by the Government. Let us have a look at an article in the Age on 19 October. The Age is certainly not a supporter of the Opposition-it supports the Government-and yet it says that the middle class family loses in the long run. The article says:
Average families on middle incomes are the big losers after a year of dramatic changes in taxes and benefits from all levels of government.

An analysis by `The Age' of all main changes in taxes, benefits and charges announced in two federal budgets and one state budget shows that many families would be worse off despite the much publicised tax cuts.

For example, a single-income family with two children, earning $22,000 a year at the start of this year would, after an increase in income in line with the consumer price index and despite federal tax cuts and the family package, lose at least $266 a year.
That is $266 a year for a family with two children, on $22,000 a year. Under this Government's so-called tax cuts, it is down the drain $5 a week. The article continues:

Similarly, a double-income family with two children, earning $42,500 a year, would be $409 a year poorer, while a couple earning $52,500 and which had two children would lose $750 a year, or $14.40 a week.
That is not bad in these so-called tax cuts about which we have heard so much from the Government! The article continues:
And state taxes and charges such as gas, electricity and council rates would bite further into family budgets, having risen on average by at least five per cent this year.

Those are the figures. That is what is happening to the middle income families under this Government. As I say, the Government has said that the only assistance that it will give is to the very low income families. As for the rest, considered middle income families on $22,000 a year, the Government will rip off them $266 a year.

The Government commissioned Bettina Cass to have a look at the situation of families, and she did a very detailed report for the Government on whether the family allowance should be given to everyone or whether it should be means tested. She came down very heavily on the side of saying that there would not be total equity, either horizontal or vertical, if it were means tested. Bettina Cass made it very clear that she believed that there was a need for families generally to pay less tax, rather than married couples or single people without the responsibility of children. What does this Government do? It decided that all the research that it had commissioned Bettina Cass to do was a lot of rot, and it decided to means test the family allowance. In his wisdom, at election time, to gain the popular vote, Mr Hawke made the statement that, `By 1990, no Australian child will be living in poverty'. What absolute rubbish that man talks. How can he possibly make a claim like that? I notice that, of late, he has changed those words quite considerably and now he is saying that no child will need to live in poverty by 1990.

The Government has brought in a family assistance package. I certainly do not say that families should not get some assistance, but the way that the Government has introduced that package has created a poverty trap. Let me give an example of a single income family with two children on $330 a week. If that family man is offered $90 a week overtime and he earns that additional money, what will he get out of that following the loss of the family assistance and tax, et cetera? He will get only $10 a week. He earns $90 but he gets only $10. What is he going to do? He will say that it is just not worth it, that he will not work that overtime or spend those additional hours earning $90 when all he gets out of it is an additional $10. He would rather put his hand out and get the family assistance package, which is much more secure and stable. Why does the Government not cut taxes instead and say that it will not tax that group, instead of taxing the workers and then handing the money back in the family assistance package so that people get used to handouts and are convinced in the long term that it is far better not to earn $90 overtime but to put out their hands for the additional welfare package? Is the Government aware that there are 700,000 additional Australians below the poverty line since March 1983? Yet we are told by a senator tonight that the Government is doing pretty well and is creating jobs. Since those opposite have been in government 700,000 additional Australians have fallen below the poverty line. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is telling us that by the year 1990 no child will be living in poverty.

The Government has completely deserted the families. The Government has chosen to look after, give support to and encourage only those families which it has put below the poverty line. It is high time that this Government recognised that unless we look after the families, give them assistance and support and take the burden of taxes off their backs, there will be a continual need to support more and more families.

Bettina Cass was 100 per cent correct when she said that all families have to shoulder additional costs if they have dependent children, and that governments must, just through sheer equity, allow those families to pay less tax, that there should be a redistribution in their favour, with family allowance to support them, and that there be some form of recognition by governments. But this Government has chosen to go the other way and not have any recognition of the needs of the families in the tax area. I believe that is the worst part of this Government's Budget and philosophy. The Government has completely deserted the middle income families, and in time those middle income families, through bankruptcies-I have just given the Senate the figures-will slowly but surely be reduced to the level of the low income families that the Government is now being forced to assist. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is considering together by leave the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill, the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) and the Appropriation Bill (No. 2). Senator Stone, on behalf of the Opposition, has foreshadowed that he will move an amendment to the motion for the second reading of Appropriation Bill (No. 1) in these terms:

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of motion, add:
``, but the Senate is of the opinion that:
(1) this Bill is part of a continuing pattern of failure by the Hawke Government to face up to the need for adequate and timely adjustment of the economy;
(2) this failure by the Hawke Government has heightened Australia's vulnerability to changes in world economic conditions at this time of crisis on world financial markets;

(3) because the Government has squandered time and resources while persistently running Australia into massive debt, our national economic options are now so narrowly limited as to largely deprive us of independent options; and

(4) the Government no longer has the scope to protect jobs, to stop the prospective rise in unemployment, to stem the continuing rise in numbers of Australians living in poverty or to protect the position of families more generally . . .

Nothing any Government speaker has said has in any way contradicted those flat statements, which, in my view, are patently true. Because of the gross mismanagement of this country for the last 4 1/2 years we are in really serious economic trouble and we are depending on others and good luck to get us out of it. It is late and we must start now to address some of the problems that should have been tackled years ago when the decline in our terms of trade first became obvious. One area we just must concentrate on is improving our productivity, because it is productivity growth, and productivity growth alone, which over the long haul determines the extent to which the community's standard of living can be improved. It is therefore a matter of the most serious concern that over the last two years we have seen a decline in the average level of national productivity. In 1985-86 our national productivity declined by 1.7 per cent. Last year there was a further decline of 2.8 per cent. At a time when we desperately need an improvement we have seen a decline in our national productivity over the last two years of the order of 4 1/2 per cent. This must be of great concern to all of us.

Of course, the Treasurer (Mr Keating), in his Budget Speech, anticipates an improvement in productivity of about one per cent this year. Well, we may get it. He promised the same thing last year and we did not get it, so I think we will believe the Treasurer's promises when we see the outcome. This decline in productivity must be of great concern to all concerned Australians. It is very alarming because despite the declining dollar and the increased opportunities our manufacturing sector in particular achieves from this, both for exports and for import replacements, we have not yet taken advantage of them. There has not been an improvement in investment in new plant and equipment in our manufacturing sector. In fact, the rate of investment in new plant and equipment, despite the enormously increased opportunities created by the declining dollar, is actually lower now than it was when the Hawke Government came to power. There has been a decline in real terms in investment in new plant and equipment, and our recovery cannot be said to have started until there is a sharp rise in investment in new plant and equipment and we take advantage of opportunities for exports and import replacements which are there for us to take if we have the will and the organisation.

It is not that we have no investment in plant and equipment. We have about $20,000 for each worker invested in manufacturing plant and equipment. This is quite high by world standard. We are not updating and expanding our plant and equipment as we should be. But even though we have modern plant and equipment we must use it efficiently; we must use it full time. The examples are legion of highly expensive capital equipment operated not throughout the year-closing down for four weeks over Christmas-things most other countries would never contemplate.

I will give honourable senators another example, which is notorious because there is a commission of inquiry into it. Grain terminals use highly expensive capital equipment which is fairly standard around the world. In grain terminal performance in four United States ports, the throughput per employee is 60,000, 80,000, 80,000 and 120,000; round about 100,000 average. With the same equipment in Sydney, the throughput per employee is 17,000 and in Newcastle 21,000. That really epitomises our productivity problem. Even where we have expensive equipment, we are not using it to its full capacity. If we do not do that, we will not be competitive. The world does not owe us a living; we must earn it. A great change of attitude is necessary if we are to do that.

It is not that Australians cannot work. I have before me a table of productivity in Australia compared with that in Britain, Germany, the United States of America and Japan. In the area of agriculture, we are incomparably the most efficient of those countries. Our productivity per head in agriculture is 2 1/2 times that of Britain, over three times that of Germany, 1 1/2 times that of the United States and 6 1/2 times that of Japan. Australians can and do work in certain sectors; they certainly do in the agricultural sector. In the mining sector the figures are 1.67 compared with Britain, 2.44 compared with Germany, 1.29 compared with the United States and 1.5 compared with Japan. So again, in the mining sector, we are the most efficient of all those countries. That is undoubtedly partly helped by the fact that our mineral deposits are usually easily accessible and we can use advanced equipment. Nevertheless, in my view, it is to the credit of the unions concerned, probably because they have been exposed for a long time to international competitiveness, that they are the most productive compared with those four other countries.

When we get into the manufacturing area we start to run into problems. We are actually more productive than Britain as the figures are 1.35 to one in our favour. We are less efficient than Germany with a figure of 0.9. The figure in respect of the United States is less than one-half and it is about the same for Japan. Other areas are broken down in the table which I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard.
