TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. There are a couple of other points that I would like to mention which I find interesting. For instance, in the building industry-much vilified I think-we actually do better than Britain, substantially worse than Germany and the United States but, interestingly, we are very much more productive than the Japanese. In the transport area we also do better than Britain in productivity terms, worse than Germany, very much worse than the United States and somewhat worse than Japan. I think in the case of transport, it is not that our shipping or our rail transport are inefficient, but that our transport figures are undoubtedly raised by our road transport system which is highly efficient by international standards.

SPEECH.PARA: Nevertheless, I think the lesson to be learnt from those figures is that Australians can and do work hard and efficiently in certain industries when they have the motivation and when they have the right attitudes. But in some areas-and the manufacturing industry is the most obvious one-they are not working nearly as productively as people in other comparable countries.

Australians can respond to a challenge. When I was in the Royal Australian Navy we used to operate ships which were identical to those of Britain and the United States. We had no difficulty, when operating with a sister ship from another navy, in outshining them in every conceivable respect. Competition and drive enthused people to do it. People are competitive. Look at our attitude to things such as the America's Cup. It was our cup when we won it; I do not know whose cup it was when we lost it. In the same way, people are involved and motivated when we talk to them about their football teams.

What we have not managed to do in areas which are heavily unionised, where people are working for wages, is to get them involved in the success of their company or their enterprise. They are doing it very much when they are working for themselves or for others on the land but they are not doing it in the manufacturing sector and that is the key problem we must address. We have to have a total change of attitude. Australians can and do do it. But they are not doing it in some key sectors. We have to go to the sources of our industrial relations problems and try to solve them. They will not be solved by confrontation and abuse. In my view, the whole problem is excessive confrontation. But somehow we have to get through the attitude that we are all in it together. The world does not owe us a living. If we are to get out of our current economic mess we must productively work together to cure the problems and we must all share fairly in success and all bear fairly the burdens of failure.

The other area where we have problems in terms of productivity is not only how hard and efficiently we work but also how long we work. The average Australian employee gets paid for 57 days a year when he is not at work. The average United States employee gets paid for about only 19 non-working days a year. Australians work only about 75 per cent of the average hours worked by people in most other industrial countries. It is interesting that, in a recent referendum, the Swiss rejected a proposal that their working week be reduced from 42 hours to 38 hours. I do not know whether such a referendum on a reduction in working hours would have been rejected here.

We also have great problems with featherbedding-people not doing jobs and just standing around. I will give just a couple of examples. One that struck me very forcibly was a study done in Sydney which showed that private bus companies had one maintenance man per nine buses and that the State transport system had one maintenance man per bus. There was no evidence that the State transport buses were cleaner or more reliable than the ones that had one maintenance man per nine buses. I will just run through a few other examples of the sorts of things we have to tackle and get rid of if we wish to become an economically efficient country. A large semi-governmental authority had all its new vehicles delivered without spare tyres. This was done to ensure that all punctures were repaired by a repairman who was sent with a driver from the base. On the New South Wales railways, hundreds of men were employed to check for bearing failures in hot boxes even though a switch to roller bearings had eliminated the possibility of the problem. On the waterfront, one worker is needed to stand at the edge and watch the loading of grain into container ships. Union rules insist on two workers watching the grain being poured. Only one is needed, but the union insists on two. Because there are two workers, the union insists that a supervisor must be present and, because there is a supervisor, there must be a foreman. Thus, four workers are employed to do one man's work. The world does not owe us a living. If we carry on like this we must expect a relative decline in our living standards.

Let me give one final example. In 1985 the Australian National Line's River Torrens came into Brisbane carrying cement clinker from Adelaide for the Sunstate Cement Co. The ship had been restructured at considerable expense so that she could be unloaded in perfect safety and very rapidly without the need to employ any shore labour at all. When she reached Brisbane the unions insisted that, for each of the three ships, one foreman, one waterside worker and one clerk be present and paid for, even though there was nothing for them to do. They also wanted a first aid officer standing by. The dispute was eventually referred to a commissioner of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission who ruled that there was no need for any of the shore party, so the dispute in Brisbane was over. But it started again in each port, Sydney, Hobart and Devonport, when the ship got there. As a nation we cannot afford this sort of behaviour. I repeat that the world does not owe us a living; we have to earn it.

Then there are the questions of restrictive work practices, some of which have been tackled in the recent second-tier wage negotiations. The sorts of things that we are up against are these: a recent survey of restrictive practices in the metal and engineering industries showed that 50 per cent of companies were affected by restrictions on the rostering of working hours; 46 per cent by inflexible manning practices; 46 per cent by limitations on the use of sub-contractors; 44 per cent by artificial controls on production levels-the old darg; 38 per cent by the prevention of incentive payments for individual performance; 37 per cent by one man, one job or machine; virtually all by demarcation restrictions; 35 per cent by restrictions on part time or casual employment; and 33.3 per cent by payment for work not done.

I think we can all see that we just cannot go on this way. If we wish to be competitive on the world scene-if we want to get over our economic problems we must be competitive on the world scene-we cannot go on with behaviour like that. One of the good things that came out of last year's wage negotiations was the so-called second tier, the pay linked to productivity improvements. But it will not be very effective. We appear to be going to pay a 4 per cent productivity increase and will get only about a one per cent improvement in productivity. Nevertheless, at least it is focusing some attention on the need to eliminate these arbitrary restrictions on the efficient working of our manufacturing plants.

The next point I wish to deal with is the question of quality control in manufacturing industry, although it does apply to other industries as well, such as the agricultural industry. There is little doubt that particularly in manufacturing industry our quality control is deplorable. A very large number of Australian consumers look at an Australian manufactured product and assume, with some justice, that it is likely to be inferior to a similar imported item. They will pay more for an imported item than for a comparable Australian item because they are sure or they think that the imported item is superior.

Japan used to have this problem. When I was a boy Japan had the reputation of making cheap and nasty things. Japan had the reputation for using cheap, shoddy materials. We even used the slang expression `Japanese made', meaning that it was poor and inferior. Through their efforts over the last 20 or 30 years, the Japanese have totally reversed that. `Manufactured in Japan' is now normally taken as a sign of high quality manufacturing skill. Attitudes can be changed. Japan had to change attitudes. We must do so.

We must stop `get rich' people destroying our exports. I am sure that would not happen in modern Japan. Let us look at some of the things that have happened. Honourable senators will remember that we built up a good trade with America for export beef. Someone thought that we would make some quick money by substituting kangaroo meat for the beef, without any regard for what that would do to Australia's exports standards and reputation. As another example, we built up, with considerable trouble, a reputation for Australian wines in Hong Kong. The people did not know the particular vineyards but they knew that Australian wines were quite good. When the reputation had been built up, someone thought what a wonderful opportunity there would be to dump some surplus cask wine. That soon destroyed the reputation, which it will take years to build up again, if we ever succeed.

On the subject of quality control, and I come back to the manufacturing industry, I can give a personal instance from very close to home. My son has just acquired his first car-or to be more accurate the first car that he has paid for himself. He chose an Australian car, under some pressure from me, I am bound to admit. He chose a Ford Meteor Ghia, the top line of that company's small cars, with nice optional extras such as cruise control, a computer controlled burglar alarm and air-conditioning. This car consisted largely of imported Japanese components but, of course, it was assembled and tested in Australia. In the first 7,000 kilometres the following defects occurred. On the first day a door handle came off. The cruise control did not work, and still does not work properly. Two door seals were defective, which produced loud wind noise. There was corrosion around the wheels. The front left disk brake locked while the car was going at high speed on the freeway. The car suffers from fuel starvation if one does a sharp turn at less than 25 kilometres per hour. Despite repeated attention, the radio still rattles, and one channel does not work. One channel of the cassette player does not work. The roof light fitting vibrates badly.

I think honourable senators can see that, if we are producing cars with that sort of quality control on the output, it is most unlikely that we will persuade anyone to buy a second one. Unfortunately, this affects the reputation right across the board of Australian manufactured products and Australian cars. If we are thinking of exporting cars, which we should be able to do-we used to have a substantial vehicle export industry in Australia-we can imagine what would happen if a car with those defects was sent to the United States. There would not be a second export order if we sent vehicles with those sorts of defects.

We must tackle seriously our quality control. It is not a matter of just having an inspection at the end of the production line, with a car being inspected thoroughly-in my son's case, the car obviously was not inspected thoroughly-and then accepted or rejected. We must have quality control throughout the whole manufacturing cycle. To use an expression, we do not have quality control inspected in; it must be built in. Again, this requires a whole change of attitude in the people assembling those cars.

The final point we must tackle in this area is the question of reliability of delivery. If we expect to be an exporting nation, we must be able to deliver when we promise. Last year 43 per cent of waterfront industrial disputes around the world occurred in Australia. We have only 10 per cent of the shipping movements and yet we have 43 per cent of the industrial disputes. I have a friend who has a small manufacturing business. He managed to get a contract to send some manufactured items to the Philippines. He sent off samples, which were satisfactory. He got the first production order, but it was stuck on the wharves in Melbourne for three months during a dispute. Of course, he had repeated calls from the Philippines asking where the order was. All he could say was that it had left the factory but was stuck on the wharves. Eventually, it was delivered. But he never got a repeat order. That sort of experience is all too common.

If we are to be an efficient exporter, we must be able to guarantee reliability of delivery. This Government has done nothing to improve performance on the waterfront. It is still deplorable. All too frequently we see what happens with our coal exports, which are probably now our most important exports. We do not have all the coal in the world. If we have contracts to deliver to Japan, Korea or China and we cannot deliver because of a strike, there will not be further orders. They will order from somewhere else-from South Africa or from Brazil. We have no monopoly on supply and they will not give us special treatment. We must perform.

This is the great challenge facing this country. We have enormous assets; we have an excellent climate; we have a stable political system; and we have enormous natural resources. But we are not making proper use of them. This is the challenge facing the country. This is the area in which we desperately need leadership from this Government and this is the area in which the Government is failing totally to give any sort of leadership to which this country is entitled.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1987-88, Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1987-88 and Appropriation Bill (No. 2) 1987-88, and in particular on the Budget. When talking about the Budget, I suppose that any Budget that reduces the deficit has its welcome side. However, I think we should be very much aware that this is no decisive blueprint for Australia's economic future, as the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) admitted on the weekend of 19 September when he stated that we were heading down the Argentinean road. While the Minister for Finance is very prone to abuse in this place everyone who moves, on occasions he does have the capacity to hit the nail on the head. With regard to this Budget, he has probably done that and been the only member of the Government who has been prepared to do so. The cuts that he urged a few weeks before the Budget have clearly not occurred when overall outlays are down in real terms by only 1.3 per cent for the Government's own programs compared with a 4.2 per cent real cut imposed on the States. Of course, new spending initiatives in this Budget will amount to $1.3 billion over a full year. It is highly significant that overall no more than 40 positions in the Commonwealth Public Service will disappear.

SPEECH.PARA: Since time immemorial, the Opposition has been begging and imploring the Government to cut spending and to cut the size of government. But that has not been done. All we have seen in this Budget is simply band-aids on the bucket that is rapidly leaking. This leakage has to be curtailed somehow. The Government is not prepared to bite that bullet. As I have said, Senator Walsh is probably the only person on the Government side who is prepared to be somewhat realistic. But, of course, he is beaten about the head by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating). Many of the initiatives that would have occurred in programs in the social security, health and education areas were described by Senator Walsh on 7 August as the `engine of growth in spending'. Once again, he described all this increased expenditure as inflationary. Yet, as Minister for Finance, he is not listened to.

It is not surprising that this Government has sought to minimise the deficit by what in the outside world will be called creative accounting. The deficit has been artificially reduced by the sale of assets amounting to $1 billion, which is hardly an exercise that can be repeated in years to come. I find that quite amazing considering the Prime Minister's rather outrageous attack on the Opposition during both the State election campaigns in South Australia and Western Australia and in the Federal election campaign as a result of its privatisation policy. Yet Government members are brawling and are clawing their own eyes out over privatisation. They have not yet accepted the fact that there is a need for real privatisation. The important distinction that needs to be made on this occasion is that the Opposition's privatisation policy is one of fiscal responsibility and practicality, whereas the Government's idea of privatisation is selling off the family jewels to pay for groceries. It is sad that we cannot expect continued repetition of the Reserve Bank of Australia's $2.7 billion currency trading profits. It is unrealistic to expect that. Until recently Reserve Bank profits averaged $600m a year, so how in the world can we hope to see the $2.7 billion profit again? The fundamental point made by Senator Walsh in August was this:
. . . the required fiscal policy statement must be made on the outlay side of the Budget.

Yet this $27m deficit-which, in reality, is a deficit of around $1,000m-has been achieved by increased revenue and taxation. Instead of making the hard expenditure decisions, this Government, at best, plays the old game of deferment so that the hard choices are postponed yet another year. A slight, if timely, decrease in real spending has to be offset against the weight of an accumulated $22 billion in deficits caused by higher real spending after 1983. Even 4 1/2 years down the track, we still hear from this Government that it inherited all its problems from the Fraser Government.

Mr Acting Deputy President, allow me to remind the Senate that since this Government took office we have seen five Budgets and three mini-Budgets, and we have had two talkfests called summits. The net result of all those things is that the economy is in an absolute mess. When Labor took office, it ran two massive Budget deficits. The Treasurer's first Budget deficit was almost double the deficit during the last year of the coalition Government. This Government has presided over a quadrupling of foreign debt. It has presided over the downgrading of our AAA credit rating for the first time in this country's history. History shows that no country has lost its AAA credit rating and got it back. That is what this Government has done for this country. If the Government can be proud of that achievement, good luck to it. Not too many people in the world are proud of it. The Government has put the economy in an extremely vulnerable position. It is not only the Opposition that has said that Australia is in a parlous state; so too has the Wall Street Journal. Of course a few weeks ago the Treasurer said that the Wall Street Journal was the most widely read newspaper in the United States of America, and in fact he was singing its praises. He may well be interested to know that the same Wall Street Journal said on 3 November, only a couple of days after he had praised it:
If there's a booby prize for stock markets in the current tumult, Australia is a strong contender to win.
It went on to say:
Commodity prices are one reason investors fear Australia.

The Government's economic strategy is clearly out of gear with the rest of the world-the real world. When will the Government sit up and take notice of the real world? It always begs the question: Who runs the country-the Government or the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU)? I think that most of us fully recognise that predominantly it is the ACTU that runs the country. The Government cannot blink without first consulting the ACTU and having secret little rendezvous with it in hotel rooms and so forth. It goes on and on. The Government cannot talk about wage increases or whatever without first consulting the ACTU. So who does run the Government?

This may not be a record spending Budget, except in nominal terms, but, let us face it, it is yet again a record taxing Budget. Nothing shows better the priorities of the Australian Labor Party (ALP) than when it tries to balance the books. Tax revenue has risen by 8.2 per cent compared with a 4.3 per cent rise in outlays. Taxation remains above 24 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP) compared with an average figure of 23 per cent under the former coalition Government. An extra $3 billion will be taken from Australians in tax this year and the average worker will be paying an extra $230 in taxation. Yet the Government talks about looking after the low income earners and says that they will be better off. That is a whole lot of rubbish. It should not be contemplated as any form of truth because it can be dispelled at the drop of a hat with accurate figures.

Yet again, receipts from excise duty on crude oil, liquefied petroleum gas and petroleum products are to rise between 3 and 6 per cent. The Budget Papers, in a graph on page 331, show how drastically crude oil production is estimated to fall after this year-from over 500,000 barrels a day to something like 150,000 a day in less than 10 years. In view of this Government's track record and its preferring to rely on taxes in place of spending cuts, we may well ask what may be in store for the taxpayer when this source of revenue quite literally dries up. We may be entitled to fear that Senator Walsh was foreshadowing the shape of things to come when he spoke of levying capital gains tax on the family home and regressing to that most vicious and degrading of taxes-death duties. That is the price we might pay for this Government's inability to cut back spending.

We have already had a debate about a wealth inquiry. I suppose the stock market crash has thrown a big bucket of iced water on that, however temporarily. This Government is committed to finding out who owns what and why and then distributing it back through the community. That is its whole motive-to destroy initiative. It has achieved its ultimate goal. A changed overall economic outlook since the Budget was presented gives greater force and urgency to the criticisms that the coalition is making of the inadequacy of this Government's spending cuts. The fact that the end of the five-year bull market on the stock exchange will severely cut the revenue from capital gains tax in 1988-89 is all the more reason why spending has to be addressed now rather than deferred to next year when at least that one aspect of taxation revenue will diminish. That is another great tragedy of this Government's capital gains tax. We have a capital gains tax on hand, but where is the capital losses tax? At the end of this year, many people will be confronted with provisional tax as a result of good capital gains. How are they to pay for it? They have now lost substantial income, but so what? There is no offsetting of the capital gains tax vis-a-vis a capital losses tax.

There can be no question that this tax, expected to yield between $50m and $100m this financial year, is based very largely on the stock market. Page 299 of the Budget Papers states that revenue estimates for 1987-88 are `based principally on substantial past increases in share- market prices'. How will the Government raise the extra money it will lose because of the stock market crash? It will not have any difficulty finding a way because it is the greatest taxing government Australia has ever seen. Again we are entitled to focus more sharply on Australia's overseas debt as a cumulative end product of government spending. The United States deficit and indebtedness are described as the cause of the loss of international financial confidence. Last week we saw the Prime Minister, with all the hide in the world, writing to the President of the United States, telling him what to do and how to get his act together. What cheek! If this country were in good shape he might have some reason to be a little brash but Australia is poorly placed to handle any world downturn. And here we have the Prime Minister telling President Reagan how to do it! We are poorly placed because of our high debt, our high current account deficit, our high inflation and exposure to commodity price movements. It is just outrageous that the Prime Minister can stand on a pedestal and say `I have all the answers' when he cannot even solve his own problems at home.

We have been calling on the Government to address the fundamentals which leave Australia exposed and in particular to rein back the growth of our external debt as rapidly as possible. The share and foreign exchange markets have registered their verdict on Australia's vulnerability in current economic circumstances. Our stock market has fallen by 44 per cent compared with much smaller falls in major overseas countries and our dollar has fallen by nearly 10 per cent against major world currencies. This perception of vulnerability is based on some very clear facts: our narrow commodity export base, our record foreign debt-our gross foreign debt is now at 42 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP), a doubling since June of 1983-and our record account deficits. The figure in 1986 was 5.6 per cent of GDP, which is the second largest figure in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) countries. Other factors are our high interest rates, our relatively high inflation rates and labour costs and low productivity growth. Inflation is forecast to rise by 7 per cent in Australia compared with a rise of about 3 per cent overseas and the labour productivity increase is expected to be about 0.5 per cent here compared with 2.7 per cent overseas. Yet with the benefit of all of that knowledge and all of that handy little needlework trick that the Prime Minister has done to this country, he has the audacity and the hide to write to the President of the United States telling him to get his act together.

It is therefore worth remembering that while Australia's overseas debt of $112 billion represents 42 per cent of GDP, the United States debt has been estimated to be as little as 7 per cent of GDP. The facts and the statistics that go on and on and on make it more and more of a mockery that the Prime Minister should be as bold and as brash as he was last week. The United States requires only 28 per cent of export earnings to service interest and capital payments; in Australia the figure is 40 per cent. There are disturbingly few nations within our region of the Western world where as large a proportion of export earnings is so consumed. It all points to the need for harder and more immediate spending discipline than the ALP has imposed on itself in this year's Budget. Just as this Budget has dodged the tough decisions on spending, so we find it is based on optimistic forecasts that leave us virtually flying on a wing and a prayer. Predictions of a 3 per cent rise in investment may be based on wishful thinking, and so too perhaps a predicted 2.7 per cent rise in GDP. A growth rate of 1.75 per cent would automatically add another $500m to the deficit.

We again need to ask whether indeed there will be a 7 per cent rise in the value of non-rural exports. An anticipated inflation rate of between 6 and 7 per cent is once again far above the rate of inflation of our major trading partners and is a major barrier to return to economic health, along with a rate of unemployment that is stalled at the 8 per cent mark. That is predicted by all sources in the Government. We should not forget that under this Government the average duration of unemployment has risen to 47 weeks, a 50 per cent rise since it took office. Despite all the fantastic super-duper training schemes that it has brought in, including Priority One, which was an absolute and utter national disaster-but a good publicity campaign by the Prime Minister-in terms of practicalities in helping young people find employment it has been a failure. The fact remains that no more than 4,000 extra places in tertiary institutions will be created this year. If we ask whether this Government is really laying the groundwork for a highly skilled, educated work force that is essential if we are going to pay our way in the world, I think the answer is unequivocally no. We will be faced with 20,000 school leavers in 1988 who simply will not be able to obtain places in universities or colleges of advanced education and who will not have the right to pay for tertiary education under this Government. Why can they not have that right? The answer is: simply because Senator Ryan and now, of course, Mr Dawkins say that they have not the right and that is that.

Where this Government has made real spending cuts, it has done so in those areas where it feels it has no votes to lose, which are commonly defence and the rural sector. The 2.7 per cent increase in defence spending amounts to a reduction in real terms and casts further doubts as to whether the Government can fulfil the promises of last year's White Paper. A ceiling of 2 per cent real growth per annum at the most until 1993 will not be adequate. We are faced, therefore, with the prospect of our most effective hardware being mothballed. But of far greater concern is the attrition of 900 service personnel, which means our manpower is being pared to the bone. An extra $62m for defence force retirement benefits may not be sufficient to cover the entitlements of 8,000 service personnel who leave each year. This amounts to an increase of $1m per week. An extra $70m for personnel may be totally insufficient to meet basic pay increases and maintain standard of conditions to staunch this continued loss of highly trained personnel.

As I said, the rural sector is always a good sector for this Government to clobber because it believes there are not too many votes in it. The point has been well made that with the reduction of $56m in support for agricultural industries, the sector of our economy that creates 40 per cent of export income draws less than half of one per cent in Budget outlays. That is an absolute disgrace on even straight equality terms. It may be true that the Bureau of Agricultural Economics has noted that farmer terms of trade have improved by 0.2 of a per cent, but that has to be set against an 8.6 per cent decline last year and indeed a continuous decline over the last seven years. It may be true that the wool industry is riding high but we search in vain for any provision for assistance and compensation for beef producers who have followed procedures that were approved at the time and who now find themselves the victims of a necessary campaign against chemical residues. In the past it has always been governments that have come to the aid of the producers who find themselves in positions such as this but no, not on this occasion; they will be levied and they will be levied very unfairly.

In my State of Western Australia they are looking down the gun barrel of having most of their profits consumed in the proposed levies that this Government is putting forward for residue testing. Sadly, the whole situation is very grim for the rural sector. It will be debated on another Bill in a few weeks time. The rural sector does not look to direct government assistance to solve its problems, such as with this supposed assistance in the disbursement of levies collected from producers, but what farmers do expect is that the overall economic management expressed through the Budget will allow them to be competitive in the export field. So long as inflation and interest rates, if improved, remain well above those of our trading partners and taxation bears heavily on farms, these conditions will remain. This is a consequence of the failure to impose real spending cuts in other areas.

Support for families has increased in this Budget by 10 per cent, following a 10 per cent decline last year, so I suppose we are back at a break-even level. It sounds good in one Budget to say, `We have increased it', but what the Government did not say is, `We knocked it off you last year so we will give it back to you this year'. We need to query very closely the treating of all such payments as social welfare; rather, the Opposition sees family allowances largely as a measure of horizontal equity, whereby the taxation system acknowledges that Australians who have chosen to raise families bear a cost that others on the same income level do not.

We must not forget that the system of family allowances which began in 1976 represented a conversion of tax rebates into a direct payment. Certainly, there is a need to give greater support to families with lower incomes and ask those at the top of the scale to forgo a benefit in difficult economic times. What Australia does not need, and what this Government has given us, is a system of family allowance supplement that will create a gigantic poverty trap for many families with modest incomes. Families with incomes above $19,500 will find that the taxation rate rises from 29 per cent to 40 per cent. I do not think that anyone in this place could say that incomes of $19,500 deserve to attract a 40 per cent taxation rate. Also, families will find that the Medicare levy phases in at an income level of $17,000. Eligibility for the family allowance supplement can start to disappear if one is in receipt of an income of above $15,600 a year. Therefore, many families will find themselves in a very serious poverty trap.

More than 40,000 Australian families will suffer an effective marginal tax rate of 110 per cent through the combined but unco-ordinated actions of the Australian Taxation Office and the Department of Social Security. Thus, 22,000 families with two children who earn between $374 and $394 a week will be severely penalised, as will 11,000 families with three children earning between $410 and $437 a week, nearly 7,000 families with four children earning between $450 and $480 a week, and 2,000 families with five children earning between $490 and $520 a week. So 8 per cent of the 500,000 families which the package was designed to help will be affected. It is a sad example of the inherently wasteful and futile result of seeking to alleviate hardship by relying on a welfarist approach.

We must look at the total situation. We will do so by moving an amendment to the motion for the second reading of Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1987-88. We say that this Bill is part of a continuing pattern of failure by the Government to face up to the need for adequate, timely adjustment of the economy to enable Australia to become more productive, so as to halt the incessant growth in our net foreign debt, which, as I said before, has quadrupled under the Hawke Government. Our amendment highlights the fact that this Government is continuing to run Australia into massive debt. We cannot afford it. We have to wake up sooner or later and I, as a very loyal Australian, sincerely hope that it is sooner rather than later.

Of course, the stock market collapse has exacerbated Australia's economic situation. The Government has increased Australia's gross foreign debt, which stood at almost 42 per cent of GDP at the end of June 1987, compared with 15.7 per cent in June 1982. It has not done a bad job of increasing that debt, has it? This is very serious. The interest on this debt is equivalent to 21 per cent of Australia's export earnings, compared with 8 per cent in June 1982. One can see from figures such as those that this Government has been particularly busy in creating a very unstable Australia for future generations to be able to start a life. We are borrowing simply to pay interest on our foreign debt. That is a situation which is clearly unsustainable.

We hear the Government saying dreadful things about how young people these days are opening more and more credit accounts. They open one account simply to pay off another one. That is exactly what this Government is doing to this country. It is borrowing to pay the interest. That does not seem to matter. It is all right for the Government to do it, but it is not all right for individuals to do it. How can it, once again, play God, stand on its pedestal and say, `Individuals cannot do it, but it is quite all right for us to hock the country from here to eternity'? The Opposition has called for substantial reductions in government spending by a reduction in the size of the public sector. But no, the Government simply will not do it. Spending cuts also mean that the public sector borrowing requirement would decline, which would tend to reduce interest rates. But no, that is all too hard for it as well.

Big government suffocates initiative and incentive and deprives people of opportunity. While the media has sold this as a very good news Budget and has said that it is a wonderful Budget, once one starts to scratch below the surface, one will see quite clearly that this country needs a massive turnaround. Some very hard decisions need to be made now, and not in three or four months time. Maybe it is time that the Prime Minister and the Treasurer both shed their arrogance and their know-it-all attitude and listened to people who might be better informed on the subject, to know exactly what will happen to this country in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) regularly claim, and have claimed during their 4 1/2 years in office, that they have turned the Australian economy around. This is certainly true, but it is not something for which credit is due. In fact, it is quite the reverse. Reference to a wide range of economic indicators demonstrates that when our economy is compared with the economies of our major trading partners, the record of economic management of the Fraser coalition Government was far superior to that of the present Hawke Labor Government. For most of the period during which the Fraser Government was in office, Australia's performance, with regard to a wide range of economic indicators, including rates of economic growth, rates of employment growth, declines in unemployment, rates of inflation and other key economic indicators, was far superior to that of other Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) countries. But during the 4 1/2 years of the Hawke Labor Government, its failed economic management has caused that situation to turn around disastrously.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia is now doing much worse than many other OECD countries. Our rate of inflation is more than twice that of our major trading partners. Our current account deficit is the second largest in the OECD. Our gross foreign debt has virtually doubled in the four years of the Labor Government from 21 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP) to 41 per cent of gross domestic product. So let us lay to rest the unjustified claim about competent economic management which is continually made by this Labor Government. The fact is that Labor Government policies have left Australia more exposed to damage from the recent world stock market shakeout than should have been the case.

The economic improvement which occurred in the early years of the Hawke Government was not due to some magical economic formula which it applied, nor to the accord with the trade union movement; rather, it was due to the dramatic increase in the value of rural production, resulting from an end, in 1983, to two years of one of the worst droughts in Australia's history. According to the June 1987 issue of the Quarterly Review of the Rural Economy, the gross value of crops during those two years of disastrous drought was $6,286,000,000 in 1980-81 and $5,009,000,000 in 1981-82. With the ending of the drought in 1983 the value of crop production jumped dramatically to $8,426,000,000 in 1983-84 and $8,092,000,000 in 1984-85. Thus, in the first two years of the Hawke Labor Government favourable seasonal conditions lifted the value of crop production in Australia to record levels-some $5,223,000,000 more or over 46 per cent greater than for the last two years of the Fraser Government.

Clearly, the early economic success of the Hawke Government was not so much based on sound economic management but rather on the productivity and efficiency of farmers, once they were blessed with favourable seasonal conditions. With the more recent downturn in prices for rural products, the chickens are coming home to roost. The Government's reputation for economic management was built on the backs of hard working farmers. The Government's failure as an economic manager has been laid bare by the changed international economic environment.

We are now debating a Budget, to which the Appropriation Bills relate, based on inadequate recognition of the crisis facing Australia. The Budget seeks to perpetuate the myth of competent economic management on the part of this Government. The Budget contains a number of myths. Perhaps the most significant of those myths is that it is a balanced Budget. But, of course, Keating's Budget is like one of those circus balancing acts-the crowd goes `ooh, aah' at the acrobat but no one sees the shoulders he is standing on; in this case, $1 billion in windfall taxes, the Reserve Bank of Australia like some rich uncle dying and leaving the lot to Paul and a billion dollar chook raffle of national assets.

The reality is that a number of the revenue items which are claimed to provide a balanced Budget for 1987-88 are indeed one-off in nature. There is a claimed $1 billion in asset sales, $2.6m from Reserve Bank profits and $212m from the minting of new coins. It is largely on this basis that the Treasurer is credited with pulling off what is regarded as the miracle of a nearly balanced Budget. Of course, as a result he received wide applause when the Budget was handed down. However, given the one-off nature of those revenue items, in fact his claim to a balanced Budget is false. The Reserve Bank itself has made clear in its annual report that we cannot expect that the profits made on currency trading in the past can be continued in the future. Therefore, this will not be an ongoing revenue item. Those profits can be made only when the Australian dollar varies in value. Those variations in value may continue as a result of the poor economic management of this Government but, as I said a moment ago, the Reserve Bank has made it clear that it cannot sustain the profits on currency trading which it has achieved in the past.

As I also mentioned, a major source of funding to achieve this apparently balanced Budget is the sale of assets which is expected to raise approximately $1 billion. However, the chance of further asset sales is now looking extremely dubious. The Government's privatisation ship has been torpedoed by Labor's Left. If the ship has not as yet sunk, it is certainly looking very shaky and is taking in an awful lot of water. The case for privatisation on a selective, case by case basis, with a range of checks and controls and a percentage of government ownership retained, where necessary, has been well established by debate and argument. But the Government is now stymied in its efforts to move constructively towards privatisation in any significant area of industry or activity by the activities of its left wing.

Senator Gareth Evans detailed in a recent speech in Sydney that he is not backing away from the issue. He stated that the Government is facing `a quite major budgetary problem'. This major budgetary problem to which he referred is that the Government needs to find some $1 billion over the next few years to fund the capital requirements of government owned authorities such as Qantas Airways Ltd, Australian Airlines and the Commonwealth Bank. On the other hand, Senator Peter Cook is reported to have put forward for Caucus consideration this week a motion that Government authorities `be retained in full public ownership'. It would appear that, even in the cases where there is clear justification for privatisation, the Government's economic managers will be powerless to act. This simply reinforces the inadequacy of the Government's present approach to economic management.

Mr John Langmore is chairman of the Labor back bench committee on privatisation. That is an interesting appointment. One would expect that, because of its title, such a committee would develop a positive approach to privatisation. However, in fact, it is chaired by someone who is bitterly opposed to privatisation. John Langmore has told his colleagues: `Reduction of the public debt is not a high priority'. It would seem that he is out of step not only with many people within the Government and the Government party but also with most sound economic analysts in this country at present. He claimed that it made absolutely no difference whether the public sector or the private sector borrowed the necessary funds for public utilities, provided that they could show a return on this investment. This is a frightening prospect. The whole rationale for the privatisation of some of these utilities is that they will be able to raise the necessary capital through share issue and, thereby, through increased equity or through some other source, whether it be borrowing or whatever, be directly accountable to shareholders for their actions.

It is competitive, privately owned firms which have incentives to achieve both productive and allocative efficiency. Privatisation tends to promote productive efficiency. The incentive to productive efficiency comes from the requirement on private firms to achieve profits and to stay in business in competitive product markets. This is not to say that all public utilities ought to be privatised, either fully or even partly. There can be no doubt that the economic rationale for privatisation has been well established.

The proper levels of regulation and control need to be established. This can be done, has been done and should be done on a case by case basis for operations that have the potential for privatisation. Of course, the first principal requirement to establish the desirability for privatisation must be that competition and efficiency will be better achieved. This is in marked contrast to the Government's approach to the privatisation issue in the context of its attempts to achieve a phoney balance to the present Budget. Its approach is to make a quick grab for revenue to achieve this balanced Budget. Rather, the Government ought to look at improving competition and efficiency in the economy as the motivation for privatisation of public utilities. Unless competition, efficiency and productivity are improved, a phoney attempt to balance the Budget through privatisation will be of no benefit to Australians whatsoever.

The underlying economic factors which will ensure long term economic growth must be put in order. The Government must pay much greater attention to productive efficiency in this economy. Among measures the Government should take to improve productive efficiency is to curb excessive wage claims. This is another area in which we have seen the Government fail with regard to its Budget strategy. Despite clear evidence that wage increases continue to be above productivity improvement and are thereby further depressing economic activity and our capacity to compete on the international economic stage, the Government has not abandoned the present wage case and, indeed, has indicated its support for the $7 wage increase. This flies in the face of our current economic circumstances and is another factor which introduces a mythical quality to this Budget. As a result of the Government's support for the wage case the economy will experience wage increases of the order of two times or greater than the wage increases which will be experienced among most OECD countries and, in particular, our major trading partners during the next 12 months.

Not only do we find that our present wage structure in relation to productivity is way out of kilter with that of our major trading partners but it is also being driven further out of kilter at an increasing rate because of that greater rate of increase in our wages than in overseas countries. That, of course, will further destroy the competitiveness of the economy.

The Government is attempting to perpetuate this myth of a balanced Budget by unreal analysis. Keating does his balancing act while the rest of the country walks on a tightrope between inflation and interest rates and between the national debt and international derision. Unless the Government begins to face reality we will find at the end of this financial year that the country will be much further down the chute than it already is.

Another myth that the Government is attempting to perpetuate in this Budget is that it is a Budget of significant expenditure restraint. The Government claims that there has been a 2.4 per cent cut in real expenditure and that government spending has fallen relative to gross domestic product. But if we exclude those potential asset sales, which, as I said earlier, are looking less and less likely as the left wing of the Government rails against privatisation, the expenditure restraint can be considered only as something of the order of 1.4 per cent. If we compare that situation with that which transpired during the Fraser Government period, as measured against GDP, we find that the claimed expenditure restraint nowhere near matches the restraint exercised by the Fraser Government. We find that we are barely back to the level of 1982-83 when expenditure is measured relative to gross domestic product.

The further myth that is created by this Budget is that it involves significant tax reform. Yet, if we again compare the record of this Government with that of the Fraser Government we find that, if the average tax rate that applied during the period of the Fraser Government still applied, this Government would be collecting some $16 billion less in taxation revenue in this Budget. So apart from those one off items, we find that to the extent the Government has come near to balancing its Budget, it has done so by increasing tax revenue, by increasing its take from the productive efforts of the Australian people. During the period that this Government has been in office, it has increased revenue from taxation by some $34 billion and expenditure by some $30 billion. Of course, the difference is the deficit inherited in 1982-83.

The Government has raised about $18 billion in additional taxation since 1984-85 but it has returned to the people only some $6.5 billion in tax cuts; that is, for every $3 it has taken from everyone it has kept $2 and returned $1-hardly adequate tax reform. A further myth on which this Budget is based is that it is paying out some of the accumulated government debt. It claims that it will retire about $2 billion in government debt, $1 billion from overseas debt and $1 billion from domestic debt. The truth is that the Government will run down its cash balances over the next 12 months by about $1 billion. These cash balances were built up last year through excessive borrowing. So we find that the Government will replace overseas debt through that medium. It will also issue about $1 billion worth of new Treasury notes. So the Government's claim that it will retire debt is based purely on the fact that it borrowed too much last year and is now substituting short term debt for long term debt this year.

A further myth created by this Budget is with regard to wage competitiveness. I have dealt with this matter in earlier debates this session. It seems that virtually all wage earners will receive both the first tier increase and the second tier increase, irrespective of productivity improvement. A significant segment of the work force is gaining those two tiers of wage increase largely through the application of industrial muscle rather than through the productivity improvement on which the second tier is supposed to be based. That simply will not do anything for Australia's competitiveness and our overseas trading position.

This Budget really fails in any concerted way to address the economic difficulties currently being faced by Australia. As I have said, it seeks to create a series of myths about the Budget which, in turn, are directed towards perpetuating the myth which the Government has created concerning its economic management over the four years it has been in office. This simply is not good enough. The Australian people deserve much better from the Government. That is why the Opposition has moved its amendment in relation to these Appropriation Bills. I fully support it. It seems that the Government is ignoring the advice it is receiving from the Opposition and the business community regarding the inadequacy of its Budget in the light of the recent international stock market crash.

While Australia recorded its highest ever trade deficit in October, the Treasurer was overseas telling other countries how to run their economies, throwing his weight around like some lounge lizard Luigi Locarno. Keating seems entirely unruffled by the present situation. He rec- kons that businessmen should look on the bright side of the stock exchange crash. At least now they will not be affected by the wealth inquiry. Australia deserves far better from its Treasurer and its Prime Minister and it deserves far better economic management from the Government as a whole. Only the approach which the Opposition has advocated consistently regarding economic management will ensure that Australia gets out of the dire economic circumstances in which it presently finds itself.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Telecom: Billing System-Boggo Road Gaol-1987 Maddison Lecture-Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome: Aborigines

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m. the debate is interrupted. Under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I want to draw the attention of the Senate to some extraordinary activities of Telecom Australia, emerging particularly from its new billing system. I have a letter from a major customer of Telecom. I will read this letter which conveys the burden of the problem. This is a copy of a letter written to Telecom at the end of last month:

SPEECH.PARA: Telecom's new billing system refers. The enclosed photographs show the most recent bill for our . . . PABX number.

This bill of 2,317 pages stands 45 cm high. One of the worst features is that 2,000 pages of this bill are for a $0.00 charge. Because of the obvious waste of paper alone. I have taken the liberty to send a copy of this letter and photographs of evidence to Senator Baume-
a very sensible decision, I might say-

We have made representation to Telecom on this matter before. Both through the recently disbanded Account Management team and the CPU, but obviously to no avail. Promises by Telecom to address this matter are clearly only made to pacify us on the day of confrontation. Beyond those occasions you appear to forge ahead without any regard for your customer's needs. Some of us see this as a typical approach shown by a monopoly.
That is a monopoly that seems ripe for privatisation. The letter continues:
We cannot live with this system any longer. Already we have found it necessary to increase staff-
that is one way to solve the unemployment problem-
to process these accounts and we often have difficulty meeting the payment date.
The letter continues to say that the company concerned is a substantial user of Telecom services, and it goes on:

. . . needs an itemised bill that clearly shows the base rental for a particular service, followed by charges for any additional equipment and/or services such as extra handsets, sockets, STD barring etc. Call charges should be broken down into local, STD, ISD, Operator assisted, etc.
That is a fairly naive request. It is actually the customer asking for something that he wants. No wonder that Telecom found great difficulty handling that. The company further suggested:
To make the bills more manageable we would like a larger format (preferably A4)-
that is a reasonable request-
This will mean fewer pages and will significantly enhance our ability to file these.
I can suggest one place where they could and should be filed.

TALK.START.PARA: —In that case, it would be better if it was not A4.

—Perhaps the perforations would get in the way of the charge. I approached Telecom about this matter and was told that it was true that when the August tariff change took place, a new sheet was produced, under its new software system, and as a result these 2,317 pages went to one customer. It admitted that this was not an isolated incident and that many large PABX exchanges in major companies have thousands of telephone lines, meaning that these companies also get mountains of high quality material like this. It is extraordinary that this should take place in the first instance. The waste of paper and stamps involved is obviously very large.
—All those trees.

—Yes, and all Senator Puplick's trees. He bleeds every time a tree is chopped down. The incredible thing is that this is not the first time, according to my informant, that this has happened. This company has had to raise this question with Telecom before, and it keeps on being mucked around. I have been told by Telecom that it is `doing something about it'. That is one of those marvellous phrases that always worry me, like `I am just a boy from the bush'. I always reach for my cast iron knickers when I hear anyone say anything like that. I hope that Telecom is not only doing something about it, but doing something useful that benefits the consumer. I did not dare press that point because I thought it might be going a little too far. It is ridiculous to have what are clearly bureaucratic malfunctions apparently on such a large scale. I urge Telecom not simply to do something about it but actually to fix this up so that customers get the sort of service to which they are entitled-after all, they are paying a fortune for it. Despite wasting money like this, Telecom still appears to be able to make money, so obviously being a monopoly is quite helpful. I urge Telecom to take great notice of this matter, and I seek leave to table the photographs of the telephone accounts to which I have referred.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a philosophical liberal, a long time civil libertarian and member of the Council for Civil Liberties I came into this Parliament believing in the principles of philosophical liberalism. SPEECH.PARA: Over the weekend, I became aware of television reports relating to events in Brisbane involving an Aboriginal with whom I worked when I was the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Ray Robinson. He was speaking on behalf of people demonstrating outside Boggo Road Gaol, and objecting to a proposal that certain underground cells, known as the black hole, be reopened as punishment cells. Today, on the front page of the Brisbane Courier-Mail, in between an article detailing the problems of the National Party of Australia and another article detailing the problems of the Australian Labor Party, appeared an item headed `Blacks planned armed jail uprising: Neal'. I take it that Neal is the name of the Minister in the Government of Queensland who was being quoted.

I just want to outline what I understand. I understand that there are some punishment cells in Boggo Road Gaol which were closed by a former Minister for Corrective Services, Mr Muntz, who promised that they would never be reopened or used again. He is no longer the Minister, and the Minister today is a Mr Neal. The cells admit no fresh air or light, and it is not possible for people who are incarcerated in those cells to know the time of day or whether it is day or night. It is well known that if one wishes to break people down psychologically, a good technique is to put them in punishment cells with no physical stimulus. Not letting them know whether it is day or night is one of the techniques used in other parts of the world. It may be fortuitous that these cells have that reputation and might have that effect. When I read the Courier-Mail article today, it alarmed me. It says:
Black activists in Brisbane Jail planned to smuggle in 10 semi-automatic rifles and take over the jail during World Expo 88, the Corrective Services Minister, Mr Neal, said last night.
The guns, to be bought with Federal Government money, were to be used to take hostages and embarrass the State Government over land rights and other Aboriginal issues, he said.

I want to be fair to the State Minister, because I am only going by what the Courier-Mail reported. Apparently, this is the justification for opening these underground cells. Later in the article the following quote is attributed to Mr Neal:

It can only be used as a deterrent to prisoners. In no way could it be used to house those legitimately demonstrating a particular cause during Expo and who are not even serving a sentence inside the prison.

It is clear from that quote that if it is to serve as a deterrent, it must be envisaged that the cells could be used. If that newspaper story is true at all, it is very serious. If it is true, the allegations require confirmation urgently, and action is required. Is it true that a plot by Aboriginals to smuggle rifles inside the goal has been uncovered? If that is true, we want to know. It is not commercially sensitive information. If that is true, the information should be laid out. We want to know what the information is. We want to know in this Senate particularly what Federal money is being talked about and on what basis it is being alleged that money appropriated by this Parliament is to be used for the purchase of firearms to take over the Boggo Road Gaol during Expo 88. I assure the Senate that I come to this matter as a civil libertarian, because even if those facts are set out it remains to be shown what kind of logical jump there is which then says that it is necessary to open these cells, occupancy of which would seem to constitute barbaric and inhumane punishment under any principles of penology.

The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, under the charter it has, could institute a commission of inquiry immediately if it wished to do so, but I think the Commission, being reasonable, would rather find out exactly what is going on: what are the facts behind this alleged plot involving unnamed people, except that they are Aboriginal; what are the facts behind the allegation that members of the Aboriginal community are going to misuse Federal funds which are made available them. If the allegations are true, then there is corrective action required by us in this Parliament and corrective action required in Queensland. We are entitled to know. If the allegations are untrue, that needs to be known as well, because if the allegations are untrue, then what we have had is a racial slur. I believe some statements are not consistent with the kinds of goals that we have been seeking to achieve over the last decade and are not consistent, when we have actions proposed by the Minister, with undertakings given by Mr Muntz, the previous Minister, who said that those cells were to be closed and never reopened. What is it that is so serious that requires their reopening today? I do not mind the Minister, Mr Neal, making these statements if he can back each of them up and if he will back them up and provide the evidence and put it out publicly, but if he cannot do that, then his allegations are in the tradition of racial slurs. If there is nothing to hide, if the Queensland Government is proceeding on proper information for proper reasons, then the allegations it has made should be laid out before us. In fact, the Queensland Government should allow the Chairman of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission to see the material it has now since he is responsible for the administration of the Radical Discrimination Act in this country. If there is a good case, reveal it. I cannot imagine that it is the kind of information that needs to be kept secret. If the Queensland Government has revealed this much to the Press, let it reveal it all. After today's statements it cannot be left where it is.

I make no judgments on the matter as I do not know whether the allegations are true. I can see nothing in what has been advanced by the Minister, Mr Neal, to justify the opening of underground cells containing neither light nor fresh air. I cannot believe that those are the kinds of punishment cells which are necessary for a prison in Australia today. I accept that any prison, as part of its plan of management, must have segregation facilities and may need special cells. I draw no firm conclusions as to the truth or otherwise of the allegations that are being made. All I demand is that we be told and that we be allowed to take whatever action is necessary.
