SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise briefly in the adjournment debate tonight to respond, in some way, to the adjournment speech made by Senator Peter Baume. The reason I do so is that I was pursuing privately today the very matter that Senator Baume has had the fortitude to raise tonight. I welcome it in the Senate tonight because it encourages me to pursue an inquiry into the allegations made by Mr Neal in a way that I can now be absolutely comfortable with, for reasons I will explain in a moment, and which will not involve any point scoring at all. I share the same concern. I saw the Courier-Mail article this morning and Mr Neal's statements and they struck a chord with me because I have had a similar experience in the Northern Territory with such stories.

SPEECH.PARA: I was concerned on two grounds. The first thing that struck me was that any Minister of any government would have the extraordinary insensitivity in the current climate of deaths of Aboriginal people in custody-one tragic death just in the last week of a 20-year-old in Western Australia-to even raise the reopening of those infamous cells that received so much publicity a few years ago in Queensland. The second thing that struck me was the proposition that people, Aboriginal or otherwise, would be able, with impunity, to smuggle automatic firearms into prisons. The reason I was curious about it is that that is not a particularly easy thing to accomplish. Indeed, if it were, then prisoners would not go to the extraordinary lengths they do to manufacture inside the prison the array of home-made weapons that prisoners occasionally do manufacture and which are discovered. The very thought of people being able to smuggle with impunity AK47s or whatever other automatic firearms from outside into the prison and then be able to conceal them successfully for any length of time within the prison was an extraordinary proposition.

The reason the story struck a chord with me and the reason I agree with Senator Baume deserves to be pursued just a little. I have two stories. I will not bore the Senate with any more than that. I can assure the Senate that there are more than that in the Northern Territory of a similar nature. One story in the Northern Territory News some years ago ran a headline which read, `Red alert at Maningrida'. The story was published that an armed insurrection of Aboriginal people was to begin in Arnhem Land . It was published at a time when, because of a number of other issues, there was a degree of tension in the community. The story alleged that a military aircraft had landed at Maningrida, that arms had been unloaded and that Aboriginal people were being armed and were going to create, by armed revolt, a black state in Arnhem Land. The matter was investigated and it was discovered that the military aircraft that landed in Maningrida was the military aircraft used once every couple of years. Senator Tambling would be well aware of this custom. I travelled on the aircraft on one occasion. It is a very peculiar custom. The heads of the Services travel around all the isolated communities of the Northern Territory on a regular basis. I do not know whether it is done annually; I think it is done every couple of years. The heads of the Royal Australian Navy, the Royal Australian Air Force, the Army and various other prominent people, such as I, judges and so on, go on that aircraft.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just stick to the believable parts.

—I think I am free to say that at 10.50 on a late night. Indeed that was the aircraft that had landed at Maningrida. I am sure that the naval commanding officer, the Army head and the Air Force wing commander were extremely surprised to find that they had been insurgents who were allegedly arming Aboriginal people. But of course, the story created a great deal of further tension in the community.

SPEECH.PARA: More recently in the Northern Territory there was a far more serious story. Indeed, I would have pursued it with the Press Council had I thought that such a course of action-having embarked on such once before-was worth the amount of effort that goes into it. It is not. The story was far more serious and, again, I am sure that Senator Tambling will recall the story and the subsequent events in the Legislative Assembly that resulted from it. A story appeared on the front page of the Northern Territory newspaper stating, `AIDS Epidemic in Aboriginal Communities'. This came at the height of the first real scare about the acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) in Australia. The story alleged that a special screening program for AIDS had been instituted by the Northern Territory Department of Health in Aboriginal communities in the Northern Territory. By any measure, it was an outrageous story in that it was based on absolutely nothing.

I can remember very well indeed that the front page story stated that the reason the special blood test screening program had been instituted-the article is burnt on my brain-was due to the `peculiar sexual practices of Aboriginal people'. I have known over many years that the sexual practices of Aboriginal people, by and large, are no more peculiar than our own. I also know that homosexuals are regarded-from personal experience I think it is reasonable to say this without people misinterpreting it-with a fair amount of derision in Aboriginal communities; I think `derision' is the right word. Indeed, in some Aboriginal communities they are regarded with a great deal more than that. If I can just be clinical about it for a minute, it is a fact that from the measures that can be used and are used routinely in the Northern Territory medical services for diagnosing problems of this sort-anal gonorrhoea and anal syphilis-the standards are well known.

Of course, the reality was that this was not a problem that was peculiar to Aboriginal people. Unfortunately, the newspaper went one step further. Having alleged in the story, quite specifically, that there was a secret report of the Northern Territory Department of Health which released this dreadful information that there was an AIDS epidemic in Aboriginal communities and that all these dirty Aboriginals were about to infect the nice clean white people of the Northern Territory with this life-threatening disease, the newspaper went one step further and published an editorial which went along with the front page story predicting an imminent catastrophe for the people of the Northern Territory. So I made inquiries, not surprisingly, of the Northern Territory Department of Health and I contacted Dr Ella Stack, the Secretary of the Department, a friend of mine over many years, and a prominent member of the Country Liberal Party of the Northern Territory, as a number of my friends are. Not only did she tell me that that story was outrageous nonsense and based on nothing whatever even approaching the truth, but also she told me that, at that time, there were 23 known cases of AIDS in the Northern Territory. Indeed, it is a very serious subject that concerns me and I will be saying something in respect of some recent discussions I have had with the Menzies School of Health in the Northern Territory at a later stage in the Senate. But there were 23 known cases, most of them in categories B and C. There were two category A cases of AIDS in the Northern Territory, and one of the 23 cases involved an Aboriginal person who was from South Australia. The rest were Caucasians, for what that is worth-which in my view is nothing. Nevertheless, those were the facts. The Acting Secretary of the Department of Health then went on Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) radio. In fact, it was the only time I have ever heard that gentleman, who was obviously provoked beyond endurance by this story, go on ABC radio. He categorically denied in an interview that there was any foundation of truth whatever in that story. At the time, the Minister for Health, Jim Robertson, got up in the Legislative Assembly in response to a question from me and asserted, in the Parliament, that there was not the slightest foundation in fact in the story. The story was totally and utterly untrue.

The reason that I labour all this is that the Acting Secretary of the Department of Health, in that interview, talked about the measures that were being used by the Health Department at the time for keeping an eye on this matter. I want to commend Dr Ella Stack for taking the unilateral decision that she did, I think very wisely, of putting, as she said, a canary down the mine, in that she had been very discreetly testing. I appreciate all the civil liberties arguments that are involved as they are serious ones, but she had been testing quietly for some time and this has been made public now so it is certainly no state secret. Blood tests had been made on pregnant women because of her concern for the women themselves and, of course, for their unborn children.

I believe that the Northern Territory was amongst the first of the States in Australia to bring in mandatory testing for AIDS in the prison population. Of course, as the Acting Secretary to the Department of Health explained very succinctly on ABC radio in response to this story, regrettably, 80 per cent of the Northern Territory's prison population are male Aboriginals, and a cross-section from the Northern Territory. So it is not a bad canary to have down the mine to be able to test the prison population of the Northern Territory for AIDS on a regular basis, to get a fairly good indication of just how prevalent this problem is in the male Aboriginal community. Indeed, not one positive case has been diagnosed, thank God, to this point in time, in the prison population of Aboriginal males.

Despite all of this absolutely overwhelming evidence, the newspaper concerned flatly refused to retract the story or print a correction. In my view and in the view of many others the newspaper stands alone. There were many letters to the editor and many phone calls. I, among others, was certainly one who, not unreasonably I felt, rang the newspaper concerned-a newspaper with which I have otherwise had quite a good relationship. It stands on the record. Despite statements in the Parliament and despite statements by the Acting Secretary of the Department of Health, it flatly refused to print a retraction. Of course, the difficulty with all of that is that it has caused an enormous degree of racial tension in the community. It has degraded and humiliated one section of the community. In a lot of cases, such action is designed to do so.

I will give one further example in closing. If anyone doubts the veracity of these stories, I will be happy to provide the material. A number of years ago the Darwin City Council purchased one of the most modern street sweepers available in the world, with some attendant publicity. This automatic machine went around the city early in the morning and swept the streets. The Alice Springs Council, amid some controversy, also purchased one of the machines. I am sure that Senator Tambling would remember the cartoon that appeared about the justification of the cost. A cartoon appeared in the Northern Territory News. Despite the reluctance of most politicians in regard to offending the media, especially when talking about the only daily newspaper one has in the Northern Territory, I have no hesitation. A cartoon appeared in the Northern Territory News, and I still have a framed copy of it. The caption underneath the cartoon was `Suggested use for the new street sweeper in Alice Springs'. The cartoon depicted a street sweeper, which had a bulk bin attached to the back of it, sweeping the streets of Alice Springs with a whole stack of black arms and legs and flagons and wine bottles projecting from the top of the bulk bin. In my view that stands as one of the most outrageously racist cartoons that I have ever seen printed in any newspaper in this country. But I found it extremely offensive that it was printed in the only daily newspaper of a place in Australia where one-quarter of the total population is Aboriginal.

I welcome the concern that Senator Baume has expressed in the Senate this evening. I will come out of the cupboard a little more on this one. As I have said, I made my own discreet approaches today to members of the Government in order to pursue that story and to try to find out whether it had any foundation in fact. I welcome the contribution by Senator Baume. By keeping politics out of this, hopefully it may be possible one way or the other for someone to stand up in the Senate at some later stage and indicate whether the story has a foundation in truth or whether it has simply heightened the degree of racial tension in Queensland for absolutely no good purpose whatsoever.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening we heard from Senator Michael Baume. I wish him well in his attempts to highlight some of the problems that people are having with Telecom Australia's new accounting system. Senator Puplick tabled the 1987 Maddison lecture, which I am sure honourable senators will find very useful in debating issues associated with ethics in medicine. But, with due respect to those two honourable senators and the issues they raised here this evening, I think the most important subject to be raised in this place for some considerable time was that raised by Senator Peter Baume and Senator Bob Collins.

SPEECH.PARA: Certainly, I also saw the quite outlandish headline-that is the only word I can use to describe it-relating to the alleged plan that the Queensland Minister for Corrective Services, Mr Neal, has spoken out about in justification for reopening the black hole. I find it very hard to accept that the plan that he alleges exists is any more than a figment of his imagination. I do not say that in an attempt to score political points. Like Senator Collins, I have lived for long enough in a State in which quite bizarre allegations are inclined to be made to be automatically suspicious when an allegation of this kind comes out. I say to the State Minister: if indeed there is anything at all to support this quite gross allegation, where are the facts? If a plan can be revealed, why has he not made those details public rather than just indulging in what I think was described by Senator Collins as yet another example of a racial slur.

I have had quite a deal to do with prison conditions in Queensland. I take this opportunity to pay tribute to the former Minister, Mr Muntz, who, while he was Minister, I believe really made tremendous progress in trying to clean up and to humanise the Queensland prison system to a far greater extent. After Mr Muntz went to considerable efforts to improve conditions in Queensland prisons-and, to his credit, he closed the black hole-it is certainly of great concern that Mr Neal should talk now of re-opening the black hole in such bizarre circumstances. I have spoken to a prisoner who spent several weeks in the black hole a number of years ago. In an interview that I had with him about 18 months ago, he described in detail just how absolutely appalling those conditions were, as I am sure anybody with any imagination and sensitivity could well understand.

There is absolutely no reason, no circumstance, that I can imagine in this country for that particular cell provision ever being reopened. I know that my colleague in the other place, Gerry Hand, has spoken out against the reopening of these cells. The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission has spoken out against it, and it certainly seems to me that the Minister responsible, Mr Neal, is out of his depth. He is relatively new to the particular portfolio. He seems to have backed off to an extent from his earlier statements about reopening these cells, but then he seemed to want to come forward with the justification for his being forced into that position.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would imagine it will do our international reputation at Expo a lot of good.

—Yes. The lack of sensitivity in even contemplating ever reopening the cells concerned is one thing. But to announce it the day before the opening of the royal commission which is inquiring into Aboriginal deaths in police custody is something that I think many Australians would find totally incomprehensible. I think Senator Collins mentioned a regrettable Aboriginal death in custody recently in Western Australia. Another death in custody that has not been generally publicised but which I think it is appropriate to mention here this evening is the apparent suicide of a Maori prisoner in the Stuart Prison last week. The prisoner was in fact married to an Aboriginal woman from North Queensland and the circumstances of that death in custody are of great concern to a number of people in Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: I would certainly commend the comments that have been made here this evening by Senator Peter Baume and Senator Collins and I hope that Minister Neal will listen very carefully to what is being said not just in this place but indeed all over the country about the way in which he is considering reopening these quite draconian prison cells. If he has any details of this quite bizarre take-over plan, if it is genuine-and I must admit that I totally doubt that-I believe that he has an obligation actually to produce the facts, if indeed there are any, and I call on him to do so. Otherwise, he owes Aboriginal people in this country an apology, because it is just totally unacceptable for a Minister of the Crown to make such bizarre allegations simply perhaps to protect his own back because he was insensitive enough to announce the reopening of the black hole on the eve of the royal commission.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not keep the Senate very long because it is already very late. I heard only part of the comments in the adjournment debate by both Senator Peter Baume and Senator Collins. I certainly support the request for the facts which Senator Baume has made and I welcome the fact that both honourable senators have raised issues which I think are very important to Aboriginal Australians and indeed to all of us. I was taken by Senator Collins's reference to the cartoon showing Aboriginals as part of the material in bins. I recall, when I was first appointed Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, being cartooned shoving Aboriginals into bins, a cartoon which I found particularly painful. Therefore, I have some additional sympathy with Senator Collins's concern about cartoons because that was a very vivid lesson to me about how painful a cartoon can be when it portrays one in that light. I am sure that for Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory the cartoon which he described will be utterly offensive, as it is to Senator Collins and me.

SPEECH.PARA: The additional point I want to make-I hope that it will not be taken in a negative spirit-is that the pleas for common sense and decency which we have heard in the chamber tonight do need to apply to all people who are involved in this area. I mention something which is of concern to me; that is, a further report I have seen of Mr Michael Mansell, again, involving himself with Libya. I raise that because I think nothing is more likely to give heart to those people who wish to portray Aboriginals in an unfortunate light than the efforts of Mr Mansell to behave in a way which is quite repugnant, I believe, to the great majority of Aboriginal people and utterly repugnant to most Australians. Sometimes those who purport to be the friends of Aboriginals and some people who are Aboriginal, as Mr Mansell is, do an enormous amount of damage to the cause that they claim to be trying to further. I come from the State of Western Australia where there are very strong feelings on Aboriginal affairs. I believe that the task of trying to achieve a better situation for Aboriginal Australians is made much more difficult by that very small group of Aboriginal people, of whom Mr Michael Mansell is one, who espouse approaches and actions which give rise to a great sense of fear and concern to the rest of the community.

I put that on the record at this time after the contributions to the debate by Senator Peter Baume, the Minister for Local Government (Senator Reynolds) and Senator Collins because I think that something that is absent from the debate too often is that those who are the friends of Aboriginals, or claim to be or wish to be, are very reluctant sometimes to point out that it is a two-sided thing and there does require to be a contribution from Aboriginal people and a very few can make a negative contribution. I make an appeal-a number of appeals have been made in the Senate-to Mr Michael Mansell to stop the sorts of activities that I have mentioned, because he does enormous harm on the way through and certainly tends to exacerbate the problems which Senator Peter Baume and Senator Collins have raised.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 7 October 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Department of Social Security recently conducted a review into the procedures and staffing levels in Regional Social Security offices throughout the country.
(2) What was the reason for the review.
(3) Who carried out the review.
(4) What was the cost of the review.
(5) What were the findings of the review.
(6) What action has been taken as a result of the review.
(7) What is the Department's estimate of a reasonable period before the public can be attended to in regional offices.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In 1986/87, a Joint Work Measurement Study was undertaken in regional offices of the Department.

(2) The main objective of the study was to develop principles and procedures for assessing the level and distribution of staffing among regional offices. This was to revise the first version of the staffing model which had become outdated.
(3) Participants were the Departments of Social Security and Finance, the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association and PA Management Consultants.
(4) The cost of the study was $650,000 including the salaries of Departmental officers who participated.
(5) The study has provided detailed information on the workload associated with processing social security payments in regional offices.
(6) Since work measurement was concluded in February 1987, the Department of Social Security has proceeded to build a comprehensive staffing model designed to:
predict, on the basis of projected client populations and workload, the Department's staffing needs for regional offices;
manage the distribution of resources according to changes in workload patterns; and
provide a tool to access the staffing effects of possible procedural changes;
Further meetings of the Steering Committee are scheduled with a view to the early finalisation of the model.

(7) The Department endeavours to attend quickly to the public in regional offices. A wait of less than ten minutes is desirable, but this will inevitably be exceeded from time to time because of peak demands, lags in staffing adjustments and, physical constraints such as counter capacity. The staffing model will facilitate more accurate and timely adjustment of staffing in accordance with workload and hence reduce the incidence of long delays.

The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

(1) I draw attention to the answer to question 2929 in the House of Representatives (Hansard (H of Reps) p. 1781, 20 March 1986) which sets out the Government's attitude towards the offshore constitutional settlement.

Of the Commonwealth legislation enacted to implement the Offshore Constitutional Settlement, only the Minerals (Submerged Lands) Act 1981 and associated Royalty, Exploration Permit Fees, Production Licence Fees, Works Authority fees and registration Fees Acts are currently unproclaimed.

(2) and (3) Under the Offshore Constitutional Settlement arrangements, the Commonwealth has jurisdiction over offshore mining beyond the three-mile territorial sea. Inside the outer limit of the territorial sea offshore mining is subject to State/Northern Territory jurisdiction. At present, no legislation has been enacted by any State or the Northern Territory to regulate mining within the territorial sea.

I understand that a Working Group of Australian Minerals and Energy Council Officials has proposed the amendment of the current Commonwealth legislation and the enactment of complementary legislation by each State and the Northern Territory. The Minister responsible for the Commonwealth legislation is the Honourable John Kerin, M.P., the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. If any further information is required, it should be sought from him.
